questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the surgical OPD after she notices a lump while bathing. On examination, the lump is painless and located in the upper left quadrant of the left breast. Skin tethering and nipple retraction are present. There have been no similar complaints in her family. Mammography shows the following image. What is the most likely diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a 32-year-old woman with a painless lump showing skin tethering and puckering along with mammography showing egg-shell calcification is most likely to be traumatic fat necrosis.

Traumatic fat necrosis :

  • Traumatic fat necrosis may be acute or chronic and
  • It usually occurs in stout, middle-aged women.
  • Following a blow, or even indirect violence (e.g. contraction of the pectoralis major), a lump, often painless, appears.
  • A history of trauma is not diagnostic as this may merely have drawn the patient’s attention to a pre-existing lump
  • This may mimic a carcinoma, even displaying skin tethering and nipple retraction, and biopsy is required for diagnosis.
  • Fat necrosis is a frequently encountered cause of benign calcifications, particularly when there is a history of trauma or previous surgery. It presents as ‘egg shell’ calcifications within the wall of an oil cyst or as coarse dystrophic calcifications associated with areas of scarring.

Radiological findings in other diseases of the breast :

  • Popcorn calcification is seen in fibroadenoma.
  • Broken-needle type of calcification is seen in duct ectasia.
  • Tea-cup calcification is seen in fibrocystic disease.

Microcalcifications are frequently encountered on routine screening mammograms. Some calcifications have a characteristic benign appearance and require no further action.

Mammography findings in invasive carcinoma of the breast :

Carcinomas typically appear as ill-defined or spiculate masses on mammography

Popcorn calcification:

Broken-needle type of calcification 

Tea-cup calcification-On a lateral magnification view, layering of calcific fluid contained within microcysts can be appreciated, producing a characteristic ‘teacup’ appearance.

Invasive carcinoma of the breast : An ill-defined mass lying centrally in the breast, containing some microcalcifications. Calcifications, representing DCIS, may be found in association with invasive carcinoma

questions.text: A 34-year-old male patient presented with severe dyspnea, mild fever, joint pains, and joint swelling. He has had similar episodes in the past. Examination revealed mitral stenosis and left atrial hypertrophy. Echocardiography showed small warty vegetations along the lines of the closure of the mitral valve leaflets. How long will you give secondary prophylaxis to this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with repeated episodes of severe dyspnea, mild fever, arthralgia, joint swelling, mitral stenosis, and warty valvular vegetation is likely to have rheumatic heart disease. Since he is a 34-year-old with carditis with residual valve disease, he should receive prophylaxis until he is 44 years of age. 

Secondary prophylaxis is given to patients with acute rheumatic fever (ARF) and rheumatic heart disease (RHD). These patients are at a higher risk of developing a further episode after a group A streptococcal infection. Hence they should receive long-term penicillin prophylaxis to prevent recurrent infections. 

In those with rheumatic fever with persistent valvular disease, prophylaxis should be given for 10 years after the last episode or till they attain 40 years of age (whichever is longer). As he is 34 years of age, providing prophylaxis for 10 years till he attains 44 years of age is longer than until he turns 40.

Lifelong medication can be continued in severe valvular disease or postintervention (after valve surgery) patients.

The best antibiotic for secondary prophylaxis is benzathine penicillin G (1.2 million units) given every 4 weeks. Oral penicillin V (250 mg) can be given twice daily instead, but is less effective than benzathine penicillin G. Patients who are allergic to penicillin can receive erythromycin (250 mg) twice daily.

Related Pearl: American Heart Association (AHA) recommendation for duration of secondary prophylaxis of rheumatic fever

5 years or until 21 years of age (whichever is longer)

Rheumatic fever with carditis but no residual heart disease (no valvular disease)

Rheumatic fever with carditis and residual heart disease (persistent valvular disease)

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with Alzheimer's disease was brought by his daughter for a consultation. He has no difficulty in speaking and his comprehension of speech is intact. However, his daughter reports that he is unable to understand written instructions and pictures.  He also forgets the names of common objects. Which part of the cerebral cortex is responsible for this?
questions.solution:
The inability to name objects and the inability to understand written instructions and pictures suggest anomic aphasia, which is seen with lesions in the angular gyrus. This is because visual information is not processed and transmitted to the Wernicke area.

 The angular gyrus processes information from words that are read in such a way that they can be converted into the auditory forms of the words in Wernicke's area. When a lesion damages the angular gyrus, without affecting Wernicke or Broca areas:

  • Speech is intact
  • Comprehension is intact
  • Repetition is intact
  • Confrontation naming impaired (there is difficulty in understanding written language or pictures)
  • Word-finding and spelling are impaired. 

The lesion sites can be anywhere within the left hemisphere language network, including the angular gyrus, middle and inferior temporal gyri. Anomic aphasia is commonly seen in the following conditions:

  • Alzheimer's disease
  • Metabolic encephalopathy
  • Head trauma

Other options:

Option B: Wernicke’s area is located at the parieto-temporal junction. A lesion here causes fluent aphasia. The speech itself is normal but it is full of jargon and neologisms that make little sense. The patient also fails to comprehend the meaning of spoken or written words, so other aspects of the use of language are compromised.

Option C: Lesions at the superior temporal gyrus cause pure word deafness. Comprehension of spoken language and repetition is impaired. Naming and fluency is preserved. Most commonly due to bilateral or left-sided MCA strokes

Option D: Lesions at the right inferior temporal lobe can cause prosopagnosia, which is the inability to recognize faces. The storage and recognition of faces are strongly represented in the right inferior temporal lobe in right-handed individuals.

questions.text: A 54-year-old male patient presented with features of quadriparesis for one year he now presents with dysarthria. On examination,  the deep tendon reflexes were absent. His sensory perceptions and the autonomic system are intact.  Which of the following is the only drug known to improve survival in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). The only known drug to have a positive impact on survival in ALS patients is riluzole.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is the most common progressive motor neuron disease. It occurs due to the death of the affected corticospinal upper motor neurons(UMN) of the motor cortex, lower motor neurons(LMN) of the anterior horn of the spine, and cranial nerves innervating the bulbar muscles.

 Clinically, the patient presents with :

  • LMN findings: fasciculations, muscle cramps, asymmetric distal weakness, atrophy of the muscles 
  • UMN findings: spasticity, increased reflexes.
  • Cranial nerve findings: Difficulty in speaking, chewing, swallowing, breathing, and slurred speech
  • Pseudobulbar affect: degeneration of corticobulbar projections manifested as inappropriate laughing, crying, or yawning which is often mood incongruent or may be triggered by stimuli that would not have elicited such a response.

Interestingly, even during the late stages sensory, bowel and bladder, ocular motility, and cognitive functions are preserved.

Treatment of ALS:

  1. Riluzole (100mg/day) reduces excitotoxicity by diminishing glutamate release and improving survival.
  2. Edaravone is a newer drug approved by the FDA that has the capability of slowing down ALS progression and improving survival.

Other options:

Option A: IV immunoglobulin is the recommended initial therapy for patients in the treatment of Guillain-Barre syndrome(GBS).

Option C: Memantine is used in Alzheimer's disease.

Option D: Ropinirole is a dopaminergic agonist approved for Parkinson's disease and restless leg syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following ions are present at the maximum concentration in the perilymph of the inner ear?
questions.solution:
Perilymph is similar to extracellular fluid and has high concentrations of sodium.

Perilymph fills the space between the bony and the membranous labyrinth. It communicates with CSF through the aqueduct of cochlea which opens into the scala tympani near the round window. There are two theories regarding the formation of perilymph:

  • It is a filtrate of blood serum and is formed by capillaries of the spiral ligament
  • It is a direct continuation of CSF and reaches the labyrinth via the aqueduct of cochlea.

Endolymph is akin to intracellular fluid and hence high in potassium. It fills the entire membranous labyrinth. There are two theories regarding its flow:

  • Longitudinal: Endolymph from the cochlea reaches the saccule, utricle, and endolymphatic duct and gets absorbed through endolymphatic sac.
  • Radial: Endolymph is secreted by the stria vascularis and also gets absorbed by stria vascularis.

The cochlea consists of a bony canal that makes 2.75 spiral turns around an axis of bone known as the modiolus. A shelf of bone from the modiolus forms a ridge known as the spiral lamina.

The basilar membrane supporting the organ of Corti extends from the spiral lamina to the outer wall of the cochlea. The vestibular membrane runs from the spiral lamina to the outer wall above the basilar membrane. These two membranes divide the bony labyrinth into three cavities:

  • The scala vestibuli, located between the roof of the labyrinth and the vestibular membrane, is lined by mesenchymal cells and contains perilymph.
  • The scala media, located between the vestibular membrane and basilar membrane, contains endolymph.
  • The scala tympani, located between the basilar membrane and the floor of the labyrinth, is lined by mesenchymal cells and contains perilymph.

Related Pearl: Inner ear fluids

  Perilymph Endolymph
Found in Bony labyrinth Membranous labyrinth
Similar to Extracellular fluid Intracellular fluid
Rich in Na+ ions K+ ions
Formation Filtrate of blood/ directly from CSF Produced by stria vascularis
Drainage Into CSF via cochlear aqueduct Absorbed through endolymphatic sac

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman presents with severe acute pain in the abdomen. She has an old ultrasonography report, which is shown below. Which among the following would be false in case of red degeneration?
questions.solution:
The ultrasound image shows a well-defined rounded tumor, which is suggestive of a fibroid in the uterus. If red degeneration occurs, the WBC count will be elevated and not normal.

Red degeneration is the most common complication of fibroids in pregnancy. It is due to the breakdown of the fibroid, resulting in ischemia and pain. It is an aseptic condition. Key clinical features of this condition:

  • Low-grade fever
  • Tender uterus on palpation
  • Elevated WBC count
  • Elevated ESR

The diagnosis is confirmed with an ultrasound. It is usually self-limiting and can be managed with non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.

Note: Torsion fibroid is a close differential of red degeneration of fibroid. The patient will similarly present with acute pain abdomen, but the WBC count will be normal.

 

Related Pearl: Secondary changes and complications in fibromyomas

  • Hyaline change, cystic degeneration and atrophy
  • Calcareous degeneration, osseous degeneration
  • Red degeneration
  • Sarcomatous change
  • Torsion, hemorrhage
  • Infection/ ulceration, particularly in the dependent part of a submucous polyp
  • Inversion of the uterus
  • Endometrial carcinoma associated with fibromyoma
  • Endometrial and myohyperplasia
  • Accompanying adenomyosis
  • Parasitic fibroid

Related Pearl: Complications of pregnancy due to fibroids

  • Increased risk of abortion or miscarriage
  • Preterm labor
  • Abnormal presentation
  • Accidental hemorrhage
  • Dystocic labor
  • Postpartum hemorrhage
  • Puerperal sepsis
  • Uterine inversion

questions.text:
The smoking history for the past 6 years of a patient with emphysema is given in the table below. If a pack has 20 cigarettes, what is the mean, median and mode of the given data?
 Year   No of cigarettes per day
2015 Quarter pack
2016 Half a pack
2017 Half a pack
2018 Half a pack
2019 One pack
2020 Two packs
questions.solution:
The distribution in this scenario in terms of the number of cigarettes smoked is 5, 10, 10, 10, 20, 40.

The mean here is ∑x/n = 95/6 = 15.833 rounded off to 16.

The median here is the central value = average of 3rd and 4th values since the distribution has an even number of values. This comes to (10 + 10) / 2 = 10.

The mode here is 10 which has a frequency of 3 in the given dataset.

Related Pearl: The Mean (Arithmetic) in Biostatistics

  • The mean is also called the average or arithmetic mean.
  • It is the sum of all elements in the distribution divided by the number of all the elements in it.
  • It is usually denoted by μ in a population and by x̄ (x-bar) in a sample.
  • The formula for sample mean is given as:

where the sigma sign denotes summation and n is the total number of elements.

  • The arithmetic mean responds to the exact value of every element in the distribution.
  • This makes it over-sensitive to extreme values, i.e., outliers thus making it an inappropriate measure for skewed distributions.
  • The advantage of the arithmetic mean is that if repeated samples are taken from the same populations, they will have very similar means, i.e., the measure of central tendency that best resists the influence of fluctuation between samples is the mean.
  • The mean can be calculated only on quantitative data on an interval or a ratio scale.

Related Pearl: The Median in Biostatistics

  • The median is the central element in a distribution when all the elements are arranged in order.
  • In a distribution that has an odd number of elements, the median is the middle value.
  • In a distribution that has an even number of elements, the median is the average of the middle values, i.e., the arithmetic mean of the two middle values.
  • The median is not sensitive to extreme values, i.e., outliers and thus it is preferred measure of location for very skewed distributions.
  • The drawback of the median is that it doesn’t respond to the actual values of the elements but only to the number of values above or below it.
  • The median is the same as the 50th centile.
  • It is sometimes symbolized by Mdn.
  • The median can be arrived at in ordinal, interval and ratio data scales.

Related Pearl: The Mode in Biostatistics

  • The mode is most frequently occurring observed value in a distribution.
  • A distribution with a single mode is called unimodal.
  • If two values occur with the highest frequency, then the distribution is bimodal.
  • If more than two values occur with the highest frequency, then the distribution is multimodal.
  • The mode is the preferred measure of central tendency for nominal data.
  • It is sometimes symbolized by Mo.
  • Mode can be arrived at from all data scales, i.e., nominal, ordinal, ratio and interval.

questions.text: A patient of bipolar disorder on lithium therapy presented with polydipsia and polyuria. Investigations revealed increased 24-hour urine output and low urinary osmolality. Water deprivation test suggested diabetes insipidus. Which of the following aquaporin (AQP) channels are involved here?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of lithium induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. AQP-2 is involved here. 

Diabetes insipidus (DI) is a condition in which there is the absence of or poor response to anti-diuretic hormone (ADH). This results in reduced permeability of the distal tubules and collecting ducts to water. This furthermore leads the kidneys to excrete large amounts of dilute urine that clinically manifests as polyuria and polydipsia. 

DI can be:

  • Central DI - due to vasopressin deficiency or
  • Nephrogenic DI - due to failure of kidneys to repond to ADH

Lithium decreases the kidney's ability to concentrate urine. Lithium enters the distal tubular cells in the kidney via luminal ENaC. However, it accumulates in the distal tubular cells due to the inability of Na+K+ATPase to secrete lithium via the basal membrane. High levels of lithium in the cells inhibits GSK-3ß. This inhibition leads to vasopressin insensitivity, downregulation of AQP 2 channels, and nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.

Other options:

Option A: AQP-1 is located on the basolateral and apical membrane of the proximal tubules. It regulates rapid movement of water out of the tubule along the osmotic gradients set up by the active transport of solutes. This helps in maintaining the isotonicity. 

Options C and D: AQP-3 and AQP-4 are present on the basolateral side of the cell membrane. They provide a path for water to rapidly exit the cells, and are not regulated by ADH.

questions.text: The following graph shows the response to 4 drugs at different concentrations. Arrange these drugs in the decreasing order of their efficacy.
questions.solution:
In the given image, drug B has maximum efficacy (maximum height) followed by drug A> drug D> drug C.

Efficacy is the capacity of a drug to activate a receptor and generate a cellular response. If the response is more, the drug is said to be more efficacious. Since the response of drug B (height) is maximum in the given graph, it has the highest efficacy.

The potency of the drug is defined as the concentration of the drug which produces half of the maximal effect. The drug which produces half of the maximum effect in the least concentration is said to be more potent. More the curve is towards the left, more is the potency. Therefore, in the graph drug A has maximum potency followed by drug B> drug C> drug D.

Efficacy reflects the capacity of a drug to activate a receptor and generate a cellular response. With respect to the efficacy, a drug can be called as

  • Full agonist- The drug has very high efficacy.
  • Partial agonist- The drug has low efficacy
  • Antagonist- The drug binds to the receptor but has zero efficacy

questions.text: An infant presents with delayed milestones, irritability, seizures, and weak limb movements. On examination, there is macrocephaly, prominent occiput, and bulging fontanelles.  MRI brain is shown below. Which of the following is seen in this condition?

choices.text: Failure of closure of rostral neuropore
Developmental failure of roof of fourth ventricle

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points to Dandy-Walker syndrome, in which developmental failure of the roof of the fourth ventricle is seen. The MRI shows a cystic expansion of the fourth ventricle in the posterior fossa.

Dandy-Walker syndrome is a posterior fossa anomaly that includes cystic dilation of the fourth ventricle, cerebellar vermis hypoplasia, and hydrocephalus. The clinical features are macrocephaly, prominent occiput, delayed developmental milestones, and cerebellar ataxia. Features of hydrocephalus such as irritability, brisk deep tendon reflexes, seizures, bulging fontanelle, and spasticity are the other clinical manifestations. It can be due to chromosomal abnormalities, teratogen exposure, or single gene disorders. 

Hydrocephalus is a group of conditions that arise due to impaired circulation or absorption of cerebrospinal fluid. In some cases, it can be due to increased production as seen in choroid plexus papilloma. Other causes include congenital aqueduct stenosis, neural tube defects, and posterior fossa malformations.

The image below depicts the circulation of cerebrospinal fluid.

Acetazolamide and furosemide can be used for the medical management of hydrocephalus temporarily. Extracranial shunts such as ventriculoperitoneal shunt is the definitive management. Complications of shunts include occlusion and infections. 

Other options:

Option A: Failure of closure of rostral neuropore produces anencephaly. There is an absence of cerebral hemispheres and cerebellum. Anencephalic infants usually die within a few days of birth.

Option B: Displacement of the cerebellar tonsils into the cervical canal produces type 1 Chiari malformations.  Symptoms include headaches, neck pain, urinary frequency, and spasticity. They usually present during late childhood.

The following image shows type 1 Chiari malformations.

Option C: Failure of pontine flexure development during embryogenesis produces type 2 Chiari malformations. Presenting features during infancy include stridor, weak cry, and apnea. During childhood, it can present with spasticity and incoordination.

questions.text: All of the following are defence against professional negligence except
questions.solution:
Vicarious liability is not a defence against professional negligence.

Vicarious liability(liability for act of another): An employer is responsible not only for his own negligence but also for the negligence of his employees.

Defences Against Negligence

  • No duty owed to the plaintiff
  • Duty discharged according to prevailing standards
  • Misadventure - may be therapeutic, diagnostic and experimental
  • Error of judgement
  • Contributory negligence - absence of ordinary care on the part of the patient or his personal attendant

Option B :

Res judicata (S.300, Cr.P.C.) -

  • If a question of negligence against a doctor has already been decided by a Court in a dispute between the doctor and his patient, the patient will not be allowed to contest the same question.

Option A :

Limitation (Res indicata) -

  • A suit for damages for negligence should be filed against the doctor within two years from the date of alleged negligence. A suit filed after two years will be dismissed.

questions.text:
A diabetic patient diagnosed with COVID-19 infection, with an SpO2 of 87% in room air is treated with methylprednisolone. After a week the patient complains of severe pain and reddening of her face as shown in the image below. Histopathology of the affected tissue showed the presence of broad, ribbon-like, non-septate hyphae with hyphal elements branching at right angles. Which of the following statements are true regarding the first-line antifungal used in the management of this condition?
  1. The liposomal formulation has a very poor nervous system penetration
  2. It inhibits fungal DNA and RNA synthesis
  3. It is also active against Pseudallescheria boydii
  4. It is a nephrotoxic drug
  5. It is produced by Streptomyces nodosus
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of mucormycosis. The first-line agent used in the treatment of this condition is amphotericin B. Statements 4 and 5 are true regarding amphotericin B.

It is an antifungal agent produced by Streptomyces nodosus. It is a polyene macrolide. It alters the permeability of the fungal cell membrane by binding to the ergosterol and forming pores in it.

It has the broadest spectrum of antifungal activity and is used in a majority of life-threatening fungal infections. However, Candida lusitaniae and Pseudallescheria boydii are intrinsically resistant to this antifungal agent.

This is available in 3 forms

  • Amphotericin B deoxycholate- It is inexpensive but is highly toxic and has poor nervous system penetration
  • Liposomal amphotericin B- It has better nervous system penetration, a better outcome than amphotericin B deoxycholate. It is very expensive.
  • Amphotericin B lipid complex- It is less nephrotoxic than amphotericin B deoxycholate but expensive.

Important side effects are:

  • Infusion-related toxicity- fever, chills, muscle spasms, vomiting, headache, and hypotension.
  • Nephrotoxicity- It is seen in nearly all patients treated with amphotericin B.
  • Liver damage
  • Seizures and arachnoiditis may develop after intrathecal therapy.

Mucormycosis

It is a group of life-threatening infections caused by fungi of the order Mucorales. Important fungi are rhizopus, mucor, actinomucor, etc. These Mucorales are present almost everywhere in the environment

Important risk factors are diabetes mellitus, glucocorticoid treatment, solid organ or hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT), prolonged neutropenia, or malignancy.

It can present as

  • Rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis- It is the most common form. The initial symptoms of rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis are nonspecific and include eye or facial pain and facial numbness followed by the onset of conjunctival suffusion and blurry vision. If untreated it can spread from the sinuses to the orbit, and then to the frontal lobe.
  • Pulmonary mucormycosis- It is the second commonest form and presents with fever, dyspnea, cough, and chest pain.
  • Cutaneous mucormycosis- It usually results after trauma or any penetrating injury to the skin. The infection can penetrate into fascia, muscle, and bone.
  • Gastrointestinal mucormycosis- It primarily occurs in premature neonates who have disseminated disease or necrotizing enterocolitis.
  • Disseminated mucormycosis- The infection from the primary site can disseminate to the brain, bones, mediastinum, etc.

Diagnosis can be made by culturing the organisms from the sterile sites like needle aspirate, pleural fluid, or a tissue biopsy specimen. The biopsy is most sensitive. It reveals characteristic wide, thick-walled, ribbon-like, aseptate hyphal elements that branch at right angles.

Important aspects in the management of mucormycosis involve

  • Initiation of antifungal therapy- Amphotericin B is the first line, antifungal agent. Other antifungal agents used are isavuconazole and posaconazole
  • Treatment of the underlying risk factors
  • Surgical debridement

Invasive Mucormycosis has recently emerged as a life-threatening complication of COVID-19 in India. It is an opportunistic infection seen even in mild to moderate COVID patients with strong predisposing factors like hyperglycemia/uncontrolled diabetes. Diabetic patients receiving corticosteroids/immunosuppressants for COVID-19 treatment are exceptionally vulnerable to develop mucormycosis due to the risk of steroid-induced hyperglycemia.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of Antifungal drugs

questions.text: The baby in the image below was born at 37 weeks gestation with a birth weight of 4.9 kg to a mother diagnosed with gestational diabetes. Which of the following complications is likely to be seen in this neonate?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the baby born to a mother with gestational diabetes has macrosomia i.e. the baby is large for gestational age. The neonate is likely to develop polycythemia as a complication.

Polycy­themia occurs as a fetal response to relative hypoxia. Fetal hypoxia is due to a hyperglycemia-mediated increase in maternal affinity for oxy­gen and fetal oxygen consumption. Along with insulin-like growth factors, this hypoxia leads to increased fetal erythropoi­etin levels and red cell production.

Other neonatal complications of gestational diabetes include:

  • Hypocalcemia
  • Hypoglycemia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Hyperbilirubinemia
  • Respiratory distress syndrome 
  • Cardiomyopathy
  • Cardiac malformations - ventricular or atrial septal defect, transposition of the great vessels, truncus arteriosus, double-outlet right ventricle, tricuspid atresia, coarctation of the aorta
  • Neural tube defects, sacral agenesis, caudal regression syndrome, microcephaly, anencephaly
  • Renal agenesis, duodenal atresia, single umbilical artery

Later complications include childhood obesity, diabetes and neuropsychological effects.

questions.text: An X-ray skull of a patient with marked hypercalcemia is shown below. Which of the following laboratory parameters is consistent with his diagnosis?

choices.text: High alkaline phosphatase and normal ESR
High alkaline phosphatase and elevated ESR
Normal alkaline phosphatase and normal ESR
Normal alkaline phosphatase and elevated ESR

questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario, hypercalcemia along with the skull demonstrating typical 'punched out' lesions is characteristic of multiple myeloma. Normal alkaline phosphatase and elevated ESR are consistent with multiple myeloma.

Multiple myeloma is a malignant plasma cell dyscrasia with the proliferation of plasma cells derived from a single clone. It is associated with an increased osteoclast activity with suppression of osteoblast activity, causing punched-out lytic lesions in the bone and hypercalcemia.

Signs and symptoms:

  • Bone pain is the most common symptom
  • Pathologic fractures
  • Recurrent bacterial infections
  • Renal failure
  • Normocytic normochromic anemia, elevated ESR, hypercalcemia, normal ALP (ALP is a marker of bone growth and hence is not increased in multiple myeloma)
  • Radiography: Punched-out lytic lesions on X-ray. The lesions are purely osteolytic with little or no osteoblastic activity. Hence alkaline phosphatase (ALP) is normal. The most common site of lytic lesion in multiple myeloma is the vertebral column.
  • Electrophoresis: M spikes
  • Urinalysis: Bence Jones proteinuria
  • Bone marrow biopsy: Plasma cells

questions.text: Choose the incorrect statement about cadaveric rigidity:

choices.text: It is a sign of death
Helps to estimate time since death
Indicates body position at time of death

questions.solution:
The incorrect statement about cadaveric rigidity is that it suggests the manner of death. 

Cadaveric spasm suggests the manner of death i.e. if the death occurred due to a homicide, suicide, or accident. 

Cadaveric rigidity refers to the state of stiffening of muscles after death. Individual cell death occurs during this stage. It is also known as postmortem stiffening, rigor mortis, or cadaveric stiffening. It usually begins 1-2 hours after death and gets well established by 9-12 hours.

Rigor mortis in all the muscles of the body does not begin simultaneously. The sequential order in which rigor mortis appears is given by Nysten's rule. Muscles are affected in the given order:

  • Involuntary muscles - heart
  • Eyelids
  • Neck and lower jaw
  • Face
  • Chest
  • Upper extremities
  • Abdomen
  • Legs
  • Fingers and toes

Medicolegal importance of rigor mortis:

  • It is a sign of death
  • Its extent helps in the estimation of the time of death. However, it may not be reliable.
  • It depicts the position of the body at the time of death

Muscles involved All muscles – both voluntary and involuntary Single group of voluntary muscles
Muscle stiffening Not marked: can be overcome by moderate force Marked: Great force is required to overcome
Molecular death Occurs Doesn't occur
Body heat Cold Warm
Electrical stimuli Muscles do not respond Muscles respond
Muscular reaction Acidic Alkaline

questions.text: A truck driver presents with a painless, circumscribed ulcer over the penis. He had unprotected sexual intercourse two weeks ago. Examination reveals a non-tender ulcer with an indurated base. Exudate shows the following picture on microscopy. What type of motility is exhibited by the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The causative agent is Treponema pallidum, which exhibits corkscrew motility.

The clinical vignette of a painless, non-tender, circumscribed ulcer over the penis with an indurated base that developed subsequent to unprotected sexual intercourse, and the finding on darkfield microscopy are suggestive of primary syphilis.

It is caused by Treponema pallidum, a spirochete that is actively motile. The motility is best observed on dark ground or phase-contrast microscopy.

The movement is described as corkscrew-like with the organism moving backward and forward while rotating around the long axis. In addition, secondary curves are observed to appear and disappear, as the organism moves.

Primary syphilis occurs subsequent to inoculation of treponema pallidum following sexual contact. It manifests as a local, nontender ulcer over the genitalia called a hard chancre, in 2-10 weeks. 

It can be diagnosed using VDRL, RPR test and can be confirmed by FTA – ABS testing or TPHA, TPI testing.

The bacteria can be demonstrated by darkfield microscopy. Smear specimens are stained using Fontana stain and pathological tissues are stained using Levaditi stain. Silver impregnation technique can also be used. 

Other options : 

Option B: Darting motility is exhibited by Vibrio cholerae. It is the causative agent of cholera, an acute diarrheal disease characterized by vomiting and stool that is colorless and watery called 'rice water stool'.

Option C: Gliding motility is exhibited by Mycoplasma. It can cause primary atypical pneumonia and genital infections in humans.

Option D: Tumbling motility is exhibited by Listeria monocytogenes. It is the causative agent of listeriosis, which can manifest as meningitis or sepsis in neonates, meningoencephalitis in the elderly, and immunocompromised.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with acidity, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and weight loss for the past few months. Her symptoms are not relieved by taking antacids. An endoscopic evaluation shows ulcers on the second part of the duodenum. Which of the following conditions should be suspected in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of symptoms not improving with antacids, associated diarrhea, and the unusual location of ulcers are highly suggestive of Zollinger Ellison syndrome.

Zollinger Ellison syndrome (ZES) is a peptic ulcer disease caused by unregulated gastrin release from a neuroendocrine tumor/gastrinoma. About 60% of the tumors are malignant, hence, it is important to identify ZES.

The clinical presentation of ZES is very similar to that of peptic ulcer disease. The features which help in suspecting ZES include:

  • Unusual locations- the second part of the duodenum and beyond
  • Refractory to medical therapy
  • Recurrence after acid-reducing surgery
  • Presenting with complications like bleeding and perforation
  • Not associated with H. pylori or NSAID ingestion

Patients of ZES often have associated diarrhea and involvement of the esophagus (esophagitis, ulceration, or stricture).

Related Pearl: Diagnostic tests in Zollinger Ellison Syndrome

To confirm the diagnosis of ZES,

  • Gastric pH <2.5 and
  • Serum gastrin >1000pg/ml (normal <100pg/ml)

Provocative tests can be done like the secretin stimulation test when the diagnosis is in doubt. An increase in serum gastrin >200pg/ml following an IV bolus of secretin (2U/kg) is diagnostic.

Other tests:

  • BAO >15mEq/h (or >5mEq/h if they have had a procedure for peptic ulcer)
  • BAO: MAO ratio is increased (>0.6)

(BAO=Basal acid output; MAO=Maximal acid output)

For localization

  • Initial investigation - CT or MRI
  • Best investigation - Endoscopic ultrasound
  • If the tumor is not localized - Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy.

questions.text: Your senior consultant advises you to prescribe a painless topical antimicrobial for a patient suffering from burn wounds. You can consider prescribing any of the following topical antimicrobials in this patient except __________
questions.solution:
All the above topical antimicrobials have painless action when used for the treatment of burn wounds except Mafenide acetate.

Mafenide acetate:

  • Mafenide acetate either in cream or solution form is an effective topical antimicrobial.
  • It is effective even in the presence of eschar as it can penetrate burn eschar to reach the interface with the patient's viable tissue.
  • It has the disadvantage of being painful on topical application.
  • It is also a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor and can result in metabolic acidosis when it is applied over large surfaces.

Other options:

Option b: Silver sulphadiazine: It is a most commonly used agent having a wide range of antimicrobial activity because it's silver and sulfa moieties cover gram-positive, most gram-negative, and even some fungal forms. In a few patients, transient leukopenia develops 3 to 5 days after its continued use. This leukopenia is generally harmless and resolves with or without treatment cessation.

Option c: Neomycin: Painless but antimicrobial spectrum is not as wide as the above agents.

Option d: Silver nitrate: Effective against Pseudomonas colonization. It has the advantage of being painless on application. However prolonged topical application leads to electrolyte extravasation with resulting hyponatremia. It also causes staining of all the furniture surrounding the patient.It may cause methemoglobinemia in few.

questions.text:
A consultant asks one of his patients to keep his fingers as shown in the image to elicit a clinical finding. Which of the following conditions are likely to cause an abnormal sign pertaining to this clinical finding?
  1. Irritable bowel syndrome
  2. Lung abscess
  3. Cystic fibrosis
  4. Aortic aneurysm
  5. Hemiplegia
questions.solution:
The consultant, by asking the patient to keep the dorsal surfaces of his fingers opposed (Schamroth sign), is trying to elicit clubbing. Clubbing is seen in conditions like lung abscess, cystic fibrosis, aortic aneurysm, and hemiplegia, but not in irritable bowel syndrome.

Digital clubbing is a focal bulbous enlargement of the terminal segments of the fingers and/or toes. It occurs due to the proliferation of connective tissue between the nail matrix and the distal phalanx. Clubbed fingers are also known as watch-glass nails, drumstick fingers, and Hippocratic fingers/nails.

Hypoxia causes increased release of platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF) and vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF). This leads to increased vascularity, permeability, and connective tissue changes.

The image below shows finger clubbing.

Clinical methods to elicit clubbing are:

  • Schamroth sign: It is performed by placing the dorsal surfaces of terminal phalanges of corresponding right and left fingers together. Normal fingers create a diamond-shaped window, but this window is obliterated in clubbed fingers. 
  • Lovibond's angle/Profile sign: It is the angle made by the nail as it exists from the proximal nail fold. Normally, this angle is usually less than 180°. In true clubbing, it is more than 180°.
  • Hyponychial angle: This is constructed by drawing a line from the distal digital crease to the cuticle and another line from the cuticle to hyponychium (the thickened stratum corneum of epidermis under the free edge of the nail). The normal angle is less than 192°.
  • Phalangeal depth ratio: This is defined by the ratio of the digit's depth measured at the nail bed and distal interphalangeal joint. Normally, the depth at the distal interphalangeal joint is more than that at the nail bed. A phalangeal depth ratio of more than 1 is indicative of clubbing.
  • Digital index: This is the sum of the phalangeal depth ratios for all 10 fingers. A digital index of 10.2 or more is indicative of clubbing. This is more specific for clubbing than the phalangeal depth ratio.

Causes of clubbing are:

  • Pulmonary
    • Bronchogenic carcinoma
    • Mesothelioma
    • Lung abscess, empyema, bronchiectasis
    • Cystic fibrosis
    • Sarcoidosis
    • Diffuse pulmonary disease - pulmonary fibrosis, asbestosis
  • GI
    • Inflammatory bowel disease - ulcerative colitis, Crohn's disease
    • Sprue, celiac disease
    • Gastric and colonic carcinoma
    • Cirrhosis
    • Chronic active hepatitis
  • Cardiovascular
    • Cyanotic congenital heart disease
    • Infective endocarditis
    • Aortic aneurysm
    • Arteriovenous malformations
    • Atrial myxoma
  • Endocrine
    • Hyperthyroidism - Grave’s disease
  • CNS
    • Hemiplegia (unilateral clubbing)

Clubbing may occur as isolated finding, but when it occurs along with subperiosteal new bone formation in the long bones and painful joint enlargement, it is known as the syndrome of hypertrophic osteoarthropathy. This is seen in conditions like bronchogenic carcinoma, mesothelioma, bronchiectasis, and hepatic cirrhosis.

Pseudoclubbing is asymmetrical involvement of the fingers. It is seen in conditions like chronic renal failure, subungal hemangioma, and systemic sclerosis. Radiologically, there is acro-osteolysis (resorption of the terminal tufts) due to soft-tissue collapse.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves does not supply the external auditory canal?
questions.solution:
The external auditory canal is not supplied by the IX cranial nerve/ Glossopharyngeal nerve.

Nerve supply of External Auditory Canal (EAC):

  • Anterior wall and roof are supplied by: auriculotemporal branch (V3) of V cranial nerve.
  • The posterior wall and floor are supplied by: auricular branch of the vagus nerve (X cranial nerve).
  • The posterior wall of the auditory canal also receives sensory fibers of cranial nerve VII through the auricular branch of the vagus nerve.

Applied significance:

  • In herpes zoster oticus, lesions are seen in the distribution of the facial nerve. That is why the concha, posterior part of the tympanic membrane, and postauricular region are also involved. 
  • In the case of acoustic neuroma, the facial nerve is affected. That is why there is hypoaesthesia of the posterior meatal wall (Hitzelberger’s sign) in acoustic neuroma. 

The length of the external auditory canal is about 24 mm.

It extends from the bottom of the concha to the tympanic membrane. It has two parts:

  • Outer cartilaginous part - 8mm
  • Inner bony part- 16mm

questions.text: Which type of choledochal cyst presents with a diverticulum within the pancreas?
questions.solution:
According to the Todani classification, Type III is the type of choledochal cysts which present as a diverticulum within the pancreas.

Choledochal cysts :

  • Choledochal cysts are congenital dilations of the intra- and/or extrahepatic biliary system.
  • The common presenting symptoms are jaundice, fever, abdominal pain, and a right upper quadrant mass on examination.
  • Pancreatitis is also seen in some cases.
  • They can present at any age but 60% of the cases are diagnosed before the age of 10
  • Ultrasonography will confirm the presence of an abnormal cyst and MRI/MRCP will reveal the anatomy of the cyst.

Choledochal cyst classification

The original classification for choledochal cysts by Alonso–Lej, and colleagues have been modified by Todani and associates to include intrahepatic cystic disease.

Related Pearl: Classification of Choledochal Cysts

Type

Feature

Type I

The most common choledochal cyst type; it involves only the extrahepatic biliary tree and is generally a fusiform dilation.

Type II

Saccular diverticulum off the common bile duct and may be mistaken for an accessory gallbladder.

Type III

A cystic dilation of the intramural common bile duct, within the wall of the duodenum, known as choledochoceles.

Type IV

Type IVa: Cysts involving the intrahepatic and extrahepatic biliary tree

Type IVb: Multiple cysts limited to the extrahepatic biliary tree.

Type V

Also known as Caroli disease, involve the intrahepatic ducts only.

questions.text: The ferrous form is converted to ferric form in the basolateral aspect of the intestinal mucosal cell by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Hephaestin (Hp) present in the basolateral aspect of the intestinal mucosal cell converts Fe2+(ferrous) to Fe3+(ferric). Associated with ferroportin 1, Hephaestin facilitates the basolateral transport of iron but is not a transporter itself. Fe3+ is then transported in the plasma bound to transferrin.

Other Options:

  • Ferric Reductase (DCYTB): Converts dietary Fe3+ to absorbable Fe2+ in the apical/luminal aspect of the intestinal mucosal cell.
  • Divalent Metal Transporter 1 (DMT1): Transports Fe2+ from the intestinal lumen into the intestinal mucosal cell.
  • Ferroportin 1 (FPN1): Transports Fe2+ from the mucosal cell into the interstitial fluid and then into the plasma.

The below image depicts the process of iron absorption.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child is infected with the organism whose life cycle is as shown below and is diagnosed with visceral larva migrans. The causative organism is an example of which of the following?
questions.solution:
The life cycle portrayed in the image is suggestive of Toxocara canis (dog roundworm) which is an example of an aberrant parasite. It is defined as a parasite that infects a host where they cannot develop further.

Parasites can be classified as:

  • Ectoparasites - inhabit only the body surface of the host without penetrating the tissue. The term infestation is often used for parasitization. e.g., lice, ticks, and mites.
  • Endoparasite - lives within the body of the host and causes infection.

Endoparasites are further classified as follows:

  • Obligate parasite - cannot exist without a host. e.g., Toxoplasma gondii and Plasmodium.
  • Facultative parasite - are either parasitic or free-living forms. e.g., Naegleria fowleri.
  • Accidental parasite - parasite that infects an unusual host. e.g., Echinococcus granulosus infects man
  • Aberrant/Wandering parasites - parasite that infects a host where they cannot develop further. e.g., Toxocara canis (dog roundworm) infecting humans.

Visceral Larva Migrans :

  • It is a syndrome caused by nematodes that are normally parasitic for nonhuman host species
  • In humans, these nematode larvae do not develop into adult worms, but, instead, migrate through host tissues and elicit eosinophilic inflammation
  • Common causes:
    • Toxocara canis (dog roundworm)- most common
    • Taxocara cati (cat roundworm)
    • Ascaris suum (pig ascaris)
    • Angiosrrongylus cantonensis
    • Gnathostoma spinigerum
    • Anisakis simplex
    • Baylisascaris procyonis
  • Fever, hepatomegaly, pneumonitis, hyperglobulinemia, and pica are the common findings.
  • Patients may develop neurological disturbances (neural larva migrans) and endophthalmitis (ophthalmic larva migrans)
  • Treatment : Diethylcarbamazine (DEC), 100 mg TDS for 3 weeks in an adult, kills the larva and arrests the disease.

questions.text: A 5-year-old male child who underwent an appendicectomy is brought to the emergency with complaints of abdominal distension and vomiting. The mother also gives a history that the child passed stools that looked like currant jelly. The pediatrician ordered an ultrasound which revealed the finding as shown in the image. What would be the most likely location of this pathology in this child?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and the USG showing the doughnut sign(target sign) are suggestive of postoperative intussusception and the most likely location is ileoileal in postoperative cases.

Intussusception occurs when a portion of the alimentary tract is telescoped into an adjacent segment. The most common location of intussusception is ileocolic. Ileoileal location is seen postoperatively and in Henoch–Schönlein Purpura.

90% of cases of intussusception in children are idiopathic in nature. It can be seen in infants during the weaning period following the introduction of new food, vaccination, or upper respiratory tract infection. The currently approved rotavirus vaccines are associated with a slightly increased risk of intussusception.

Lead points are more common in children older than 2 years of age and can cause recurrent intussusception. Some recognizable lead points are as follows: enlarged submucosal Peyer's patch, Meckel's diverticulum, intestinal polyp, neurofibroma, intestinal duplication cysts, leiomyomas, hamartomas, anastomotic suture line, enterostomy tube, hemangioma, or malignant conditions such as lymphoma or Kaposi sarcoma.

Clinical features:

The characteristic clinical triad includes:

  • Pain
  • Palpable sausage-shaped mass
  • Red currant jelly stools

USG findings in intussusception include:

  • Target sign (also known as the doughnut sign)- The appearance is generated by concentric alternating echogenic and hypoechogenic bands. The echogenic bands are formed by mucosa and muscularis whereas the submucosa is responsible for the hypoechoic bands
  • Pseudokidney sign: this is seen in the longitudinal section of the bowel:
    • the edematous bowel resembles renal parenchyma and
    • the mesentery which is dragged into the intussusception resembles renal hilum.
  • Crescent in a doughnut sign.

Barium enema shows the characteristic coiled spring appearance.

The above image shows the coiled spring appearance

Treatment:

  • Reduction of intussusception should be done immediately after the diagnosis.
  • Radiologic hydrostatic reduction has a success rate of 80-95% in cases of ileocolic intussusception
  • Surgical reduction is only done in the presence of refractory shock, suspected bowel necrosis or perforation, peritonitis and multiple recurennces.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presented with the following lesions. Her serum angiotensin-converting enzyme levels were found to be higher than normal. What is the likely systemic disease associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with cutaneous red-purple indurated plaques and nodules over the nose and cheeks and elevated angiotensin-converting enzyme levels is likely to have lupus pernio. The likely systemic disease associated with this condition is sarcoidosis. 

Cutaneous sarcoidosis presents as red‐brown or red violaceous nodules or plaques, generally multiple, and does not cause symptoms. Diascopy reveals the subtle brown‐yellow or ‘apple jelly’ color characteristic of granulomatous diseases but is usually more opaque than in lupus vulgaris. At diagnosis, at least 60% of patients have an increased serum angiotensin‐converting enzyme level.

Lupus pernio is the most distinctive manifestation of cutaneous sarcoidosis. It presents as infiltrated erythemato-violaceous plaques involving the nose, cheeks, ears, lips, forehead, and fingers. On the cheeks, a prominent telangiectatic component is characteristic. The clinical appearance is due to the presence of epithelioid cell granulomas in the dermis.

Lupus pernio is usually painless and, as it does not tend to ulcerate, is not as mutilating as lupus vulgaris. In more than half of cases, it is associated with sarcoidosis of the upper respiratory tract, especially in patients with involvement of the nasal rims. It is also frequently associated with pulmonary fibrosis, chronic uveitis, and bony cysts, particularly affecting the terminal phalanges.

The image below shows the apple jelly appearance on diascopy:

Other options:
Option A: Heliotrope rash presents as violaceous lesions around eyelids. It is seen in dermatomyositis.

Option B: Lupus vulgaris is a manifestation of cutaneous tuberculosis. The lesions are usually plaques with soft, reddish-brown papules. The lesions gradually become elevated, infiltrated, and grow by slow peripheral extension to become gyrate or discoid in shape with areas of atrophy. The following image depicts the lesions of lupus vulgaris.

Option C: Erysipelas presents as erythematous raised lesions with sharply demarcated edges. It is caused due to streptococcal skin infection.

questions.text: A 75-year-old female patient presented with complaints of poor vision, eye pain, photophobia, and watering from her right eye along with headache for the past one week. Examination reduced visual acuity with only light perception, a deep anterior chamber, and the finding as shown in the image. Intraocular pressure increased. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette describes a patient with signs and symptoms of glaucoma (diminution of vision, eye pain, photophobia, watering, headache, corneal edema, mid-dilated pupils, raised intraocular pressure) occurring in association with a senile hyper mature Morgagnian cataract (as shown in the image). Presence of a deep anterior chamber points towards the diagnosis of secondary open-angle glaucoma - phacolytic glaucoma.

Phacolytic glaucoma is secondary open-angle glaucoma occurring in association with hyper mature morgagnian cataracts.

Trabecular obstruction is caused by high molecular-weight lens proteins that leak through the intact capsule in cases of the hyper mature cataract into the aqueous humour; macrophages containing lens proteins may also contribute to this.

Presentation:

  • Eye pain
  • Diminished vision
  • Photophobia
  • Lacrimation 
  • Headache
  • Increased intraocular pressure
  • Deep anterior chamber with fine white protein particles which may settle as pseudohypopyon
  • Open-angle seen on gonioscopy
  • Lens: Milky white cortex with sunken brownish nucleus (Morgagnian cataract)

Treatment:

  1. Medical therapy to lower the intraocular pressure
  2. Surgery to extract the lens.

Option A: 

Phacogenic (previously phacoanaphylactic) glaucoma is an autoimmune granulomatous reaction to lens proteins following exposure due to incomplete cataract extraction, trauma, or rarely capsular degeneration. The patient usually presents with a history of trauma or ocular surgery and a latent period following which the symptoms of glaucoma manifests. It is also a type of secondary open-angle glaucoma. 

Option B: 

Phacomorphic glaucoma is an acute secondary angle-closure glaucoma caused by an intumescent cataractous lens due to rapid maturation of cataract or following traumatic capsular rupture. The swollen lens obliterates the angle by forcing the root of the iris against the cornea. The patient presents with features of acute glaucoma with a shallow anterior chamber and a swollen cataractous lens.

Option D:

Phacotopic glaucoma is an acute secondary angle-closure glaucoma due to anterior subluxation or dislocation of the lens into the anterior chamber and spherophakia. Examination reveals a shallow anterior chamber.

questions.text: A young male patient is admitted with sudden onset of loss of vision, restricted movements, and severe pain in his right eye, following a penetrating injury. Slit-lamp examination shows a cloudy cornea and pus in the anterior chamber. Visual acuity shows no light perception. What is the treatment of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a patient presenting with sudden loss of vision and severe eye pain following a penetrating eye injury, along with features of restricted eye movements, pus in the anterior chamber, and cloudy cornea, is suggestive of panophthalmitis. The treatment of choice for panophthalmitis is evisceration.

In evisceration, the contents of the eyeball are removed, leaving behind the sclera. It is done to avoid the risk of intracranial dissemination of infection. 

Panophthalmitis is an intense purulent inflammation of the entire eyeball, including the Tenon’s capsule. Infection can occur as a result of exogenous penetrating injuries, perforation of corneal ulcers, hematogenous spread of infections, or direct spread of infection from surrounding structures (e.g. orbital cellulitis). 

Clinical features include

  • Severe ocular pain and headache
  • Complete loss of vision
  • Marked redness and swelling of eyes
  • Profuse watering, purulent discharge
  • Constitutional symptoms - fever, malaise

Ocular examination:

  • Vision - no perception of light
  • Lids - edematous, hyperemia
  • Eyeball - proptosis
  • Ocular motility - grossly restricted, painful
  • Conjunctiva - chemosis, congestion
  • Cornea - cloudy, edematous
  • Anterior chamber - hypopyon
  • Intra-ocular pressure - raised

Treatment

  1. Anti-inflammatory drugs and analgesics to relieve pain
  2. Broad-spectrum antibiotics
  3. Evisceration is the definitive surgical procedure and the treatment of choice since it has superior long-term cosmetic outcomes and faster recovery when compared with enucleation.

Other options:

Option B: Enucleation - This procedure involves the removal of the entire eyeball with the major part of the optic nerve, leaving behind the extraocular muscles. It is done in cases of retinoblastoma and malignant melanoma. It can be done with a painful blind eye but evisceration is the treatment of choice.

Option C: Exenteration- This is a mutilating surgery in which all the orbits' contents and periorbita are removed. It is indicated for malignant tumors arising from the orbital structures or spreading from the eyeball.

Option D: Debulking- This procedure is done for the reduction of as much of the bulk (volume) of a tumor as possible. Nowadays, debulking of the orbit is preferred over exenteration.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the casualty with a lacerated wound that required suturing. The wound was cleaned and aseptic precautions were taken before bupivacaine infiltration was given. Which of the following nerve fibers are should ideally be most sensitive to the effects of the infiltration?
questions.solution:
C fibres are supposed to be the most susceptible to local anaesthetics.

Type C fibers are small unmyelinated nerve fibers. They are postganglionic sympathetic fibers that carry pain and temperature sensations. They are least susceptible to hypoxia and pressure.

  • Pressure A>B>C
  • Hypoxia is B>A>C
  • Local anaesthetic B >A > C
*Note: Although theoretically, C fibres are supposed to be the most susceptible to local anaesthetics, practically it was found to be the least susceptible.

Controversial: There is a difference in the opinion quoted by various standard textbooks and authors.

Majority of the sources quote the order of susceptibility of nerve fibres as B >A-γ > A-δ > A-β > A-α > C

questions.text: 1 yr old boy presents with biphasic stridor, barking cough and difficulty in breathing and fever. Image given below depicts his Xray findings. All of the following are true about this condition except_____________

choices.text: Most common in age group of 6 months to 3 years
Most common organism responsible is Parainfluenza virus

questions.solution:
The clinical picture of biphasic stridor, barking cough and difficulty in breathing, and fever in the child along with the steeple sign on x ray, is suggestive of croup or laryngotracheobronchitis. Biphasic stridor suggests subglottic involvement (not supraglottis).

Croup or laryngotracheobronchitis is an inflammatory condition of the larynx, trachea, and bronchi caused by the parainfluenza virus (Option D). It is characterized by the subglottic swelling of loose areolar tissue leading to respiratory obstruction and stridor. It commonly affects children between 6 months and 3 years of age, more often male children. (Option A and B)

Laryngotracheobronchitis is characterized by a barking cough, hoarseness, and inspiratory stridor. Agitation and crying aggravate the symptoms and signs. A hoarse voice, coryza, normal to moderately inflamed pharynx, and a slightly increased respiratory rate can be revealed in the physical examination. The upper airway obstruction may progress and the child can present with an increased respiratory rate, nasal flaring; suprasternal, infrasternal, and intercostal retractions; and continuous stridor. On X-ray a Steeple/Church top/pencil top sign (obstruction in subglottis) is seen.

Biphasic stridor is seen in lesions of the glottis, subglottis, and cervical trachea, e.g. laryngeal papillomas, vocal cord paralysis, and subglottic stenosis.

questions.text:
A 64-year-old female patient is brought to the casualty with a history of slip and fall in the bathroom. The patient is having pain in the left hip and is not able to walk. On examination, the left lower limb is shortened and externally rotated. An X-ray of the patient is given below. Which of the following are the other radiological findings that can be seen in this condition?

1) Prominent lesser trochanter 

2) Intact Shenton's line 

3) Displacement of greater trochanter

4) Break in the trabecular stream

5) Break in the medial cortex of the neck
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and x-ray are suggestive of fracture neck of femur and statements 1,3,4 and 5 are correct.

Plain radiograph of fracture neck of the femur may show the following features:

  • Fracture in the neck of femur
  • Break in the medial cortex
  • External rotation of the femur with the lesser trochanter appearing more prominent
  • Displacement of the greater trochanter
  • Break in the trabecular stream
  • Break in Shenton's line

Fracture of neck of the femur:

Clinical features:

  • Painful movements of the hip joint
  • Shortening and external rotation of the affected limb
  • Tenderness in the hip 
  • Active straight leg raising is not possible

Risk factors:

Common risk factors for femoral neck fractures include:

  • Elderly age
  • Female sex
  • White population of Europe and North America
  • Smoking
  • Decreased level of physical activity

Comorbidities that can cause femoral neck fractures are:

  • HIV
  • Celiac disease
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Hypo and hyperthyroidism
  • Primary hyperparathyroidism
  • Chronic kidney and liver disease

Medications that can cause femoral neck fractures are:

  • Corticosteroids
  • Proton pump inhibitors
  • Antipsychotic medication
  • Aromatase inhibitors
  • Gonadotropin-releasing hormone inhibitors
  • Long-acting progesterone-only pill

questions.text: A 73 years old patient with a history of chronic congestive cardiac failure and secondary pulmonary hypertension was admitted in the ICU for severe breathlessness and pedal edema. The patient dies on the 2nd day of admission and an autopsy was done. On examination of abdominal viscera the liver was found to be enlarged with the following appearance on the cross-section of the specimen. False about this condition is:

choices.text: The pathology here is cirrhosis of liver
Diagnosis is based on Clinical evaluation

questions.solution:
This is an image of a "nutmeg" liver seen with chronic passive congestion of the liver. Note the dark red congested regions that represent the accumulation of RBC's in centrilobular regions.

Congestive hepatopathy is diffuse venous congestion within the liver that results from right-sided heart failure (usually due to cardiomyopathy, tricuspid regurgitation, mitral insufficiency, cor pulmonale, or constrictive pericarditis).

Pathogenesis:

  • Moderate or severe right-sided heart failure causes raised central venous pressure, which is transmitted to the liver via the inferior vena cava and hepatic veins.
  • Chronic congestion leads to atrophy of hepatocytes, distention of sinusoids, and centri zonal fibrosis, which, if severe, progresses to cirrhosis (cardiac cirrhosis).
  • The basis for liver cell death is probably sinusoidal thrombosis that propagates to the central veins and branches of the portal vein, causing ischemia.

Clinical Picture:

  • Most patients are asymptomatic.
  • However, moderate congestion causes right upper quadrant discomfort (due to stretching of the liver capsule) and tender hepatomegaly.
  • Ascites may result from the transmitted central venous hypertension; infrequently, splenomegaly results.
  • With transmitted central venous hypertension, the hepatojugular reflex is present, unlike in hepatic congestion due to Budd-Chiari syndrome.

Diagnosis:

  • Based on Clinical evaluation
  • Congestive hepatopathy is suspected in patients who have right-sided heart failure, jaundice, and tender hepatomegaly.
  • Laboratory test results are modestly abnormal: unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia (total bilirubin < 3 mg/dL), elevated (usually < 2- to 3-fold) aminotransferases, and prolonged PT/INR.
  • Ascitic fluid, if present, has a high albumin content (typically > 2.5 g/dL); in contrast, only 10% of patients with cirrhotic ascites have ascitic albumin levels that high.
  • Because the laboratory abnormalities are nonspecific, recognition of congestive hepatopathy is ultimately clinical.

questions.text: At what age, basiocciput fuses with basisphenoid?
questions.solution: Basiocciput fuses with basisphenoid around 18-22 years.

questions.text:
An infant born via breech delivery is brought to the pediatric OPD with a deformity as shown in the image given below. Which of the following statements are true regarding clinical manifestations of this condition?

1) The condition is usually associated with dolichocephaly.

2) It is more common on the right side

3) It is commonly localized near the clavicular attachment of the muscle

4) A palpable mass is usually seen in the first 2 weeks after birth

5) The characteristic position of the head is known as cock-robin position.
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation and the image show congenital torticollis and here statements 2,3,4, and 5 are correct.

Congenital torticollis (infantile torticollis) 

This condition is caused due to sternocleidomastoid (SCM) muscle fibrosis. it is also associated with malposition in utero, birth injury in difficult labour or breech delivery.

Clinical features:

  • Head tilt towards the affected side, face rotated towards the contralateral shoulder (cock robin position).
  • A palpable nodule in the affected sternocleidomastoid muscle may be present at birth or usually in the first 2 weeks after birth. The mass reaches its maximum size in 1 or 2 months and usually disappears within 1 year.
  • It commonly affects the right side than the left side.
  • It can involve the muscle diffusely, but commonly it is localized to the clavicular attachment of the muscle.
  • Asymmetry of the face (hemi-hypoplasia) and flattening of one side of the skull (plagiocephaly) may be present.

Management:

  • Conservative treatment: It is the only modality of treatment indicated during infancy. Stretching of the SCM muscle by manipulating the infant’s head manually. This would be more successful in infants with restriction of motion less than 30 degrees and having no facial asymmetry.
  • Operative management: Release of SCM muscle. Unipolar release of the muscle is done for mild deformities and bipolar release is done for moderate to severe torticollis. Surgical correction is delayed until school age.

Related Pearl: Torticollis

Torticollis is a cervical deformity in which the head is rotated and tilted towards one side, with some lateral rotation.

Causes:

  • Congenital torticollis (infantile torticollis)-
    • More common
    • Caused due to:
      • Malposition in utero
      • Birth injury in difficult labour or breech delivery
    • It is due to sternocleidomastoid (SCM) muscle fibrosis
  • Secondary torticollis is an acquired condition and can result due to infections, tumours, inflammatory disorders or trauma.

Clinical features:

  • Head tilt towards the affected side, face rotated towards the contralateral shoulder (cock robin position).
  • A palpable nodule in the affected sternocleidomastoid muscle in the first few weeks after birth, disappearing within a few months.
  • Asymmetry of the face (hemihypoplasia) and flattening of one side of the skull (plagiocephaly) may be present. 

Management:

  • Conservative treatment: Stretching of the SCM muscle by manipulating the infant’s head manually. 
  • Operative management: Release of SCM muscle. It is delayed until school age.

questions.text: A lady with 2 weeks of amenorrhea and a positive urine pregnancy test came for medical termination of the pregnancy. Menstrual aspiration is being performed. Which is the instrument used for this procedure?
questions.solution:
Karman’s cannula (image 3) is used for menstrual aspiration.

Menstrual regulation or aspiration is the aspiration of the endometrial cavity 1-3 weeks after a missed period in a woman with a previous normal cycle and a positive urine pregnancy test. It is performed using Karman's cannula.

Procedure -

  • Under aseptic precautions, the cervix may be gently dilated using 4-5 mm size dilators.
  • Then 5-6mm Karman’s cannula is inserted and attached to a 50ml syringe for suction.
  • The cannula is rotated, pushed in and out with gentle strokes.

This procedure is contraindicated in advanced pregnancy and in the presence of local pelvic inflammation.

The drawback of the procedure - an implanted zygote can be missed, an ectopic pregnancy can be unrecognized.

Other options:

  • Instrument 1 is Rubins cannula. It is used for hysterosalpingography.
  • Instrument 2 is Leech Wilkinson's cannula. It can be identified by the spiral cone at the tip and is used for hysterosalpingography.
  • Instrument 4 is Simpson's uterine sound. It can be identified by the markings used for measurement and is used to measure the length of the uterus.

Related Pearl: Instruments in OBG

questions.text: A 33-year-old patient with Crohn’s disease has had a disappointing response to glucocorticoids and 5-aminosalicyclic acid (5-ASA) agents. He is interested in steroid-sparing agents. He has no liver or renal disease. You prescribe once-weekly methotrexate injections. In addition to monitoring hepatic function and complete blood count, what other complication of methotrexate therapy do you advice the patient of?
questions.solution:
The patient must be advised regarding possible pneumonitis while on methotrexate therapy.

Methotrexate, azathioprine, cyclosporine, tacrolimus, and anti-tumour necrosis factor(TNF) antibody are reasonable options for patients with Crohn disease, depending on the extent of macroscopic disease. Pneumonitis is a rare but serious complication of methotrexate therapy.

Other options:

  • Primary sclerosing cholangitis is an extraintestinal manifestation of IBD and not a complication of methotrexate therapy.
  • Pancreatitis is an uncommon complication of azathioprine, and IBD patients treated with azathioprine are at four-fold increased risk of developing a lymphoma.
  • Anti-TNF antibody therapy is associated with an increased risk of tuberculosis, disseminated histoplasmosis, and a number of other infections.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient was referred to the dermatology outpatient department with painful, erythematous nodular lesions on the extensor surface of the upper limbs. He also complains of fever and malaise. He had completed treatment for leprosy six months ago. This condition is caused by __________.
questions.solution:
The given scenario of painful, erythematous nodules over the limbs (extensor surface) in a patient with leprosy is suggestive of erythema nodosum leprosum (ENL) or type II lepra reaction. It is caused by type III hypersensitivity reaction which is immune-complex mediated.

Type II lepra reactions (ENL) are mainly seen in multibacillary disease; LL (50%) > BL (15%). They can occur before, during, or after treatment, and are commonly recurrent. These reactions are caused by immune complexes (type III hypersensitivity). ENL presents with painful, erythematous nodules on the face and extensor surfaces of limbs. Systemic manifestations like fever, malaise, anorexia, neuritis, uveitis, dactylitis, arthritis, myositis, etc. can also be seen. Treatment of type II lepra reactions includes high-dose steroids, thalidomide (drug of choice in young men with severe ENL), and clofazimine.

Type I lepra reaction, on the other hand, is caused by type IV hypersensitivity reaction, i.e. cell-mediated immune inflammation within existing skin lesions.

questions.text: Which of the following layers of the skin plays a major role in protection against water loss from our body?
questions.solution:
Stratum granulosum plays a major role in protection against water loss from the body and is marked as "2" in the image given in the question.

The image shows the histological appearance of the epidermis of the skin. The structures marked are respectively:

  • 1- Stratum corneum
  • 2- Stratum granulosum
  • 3- Stratum spinosum
  • 4- Stratum basale

The above 4 layers are present in the thin hairy skin. 

The thick glabrous skin over the palms and the soles alone contains a clear homogenous 5th layer between the stratum corneum and stratum granulosum, called the stratum lucidum. 

The epidermis of the skin is made of stratified squamous keratinized epithelium and consists of the following layers. 

  • Stratum basale- It is the deepest layer of the epidermis and is made of a single layer of columnar cells that rest on a basal lamina. It contains keratinocytes and is also called stratum germinativum. 
  • Stratum spinosum-Contains several layers of polygonal keratinocytes. These cells are connected to each other with the help of desmosomes. This is also called as prickle cell layer or Malpighian layer.
  • Stratum granulosum- These are made up of flattened cells that have deeply staining granules in their cytoplasm. The granules contain keratohyalin. The cells of this layer have Golgi-derived lamellar granules that undergo exocytosis and form a lipid-rich impermeable layer around the cells. This material plays a major role in skins barrier against water loss.
  • Stratum lucidum- It lies superficial to the stratum granulosum. The cell boundaries are indistinct and this layer appears homogenous.
  • Stratum corneum- It is the most superficial layer of the epidermis. This layer is acellular. It is made up of flattened scale-like elements (squames) containing keratin filaments within a protein. The squames are held together by a glue-like material that contains lipids and carbohydrates.

questions.text:
A newborn is evaluated by a neonatologist due to the presence of an abdominal anomaly. On examination, there is an evisceration of bowel loops covered by a sac in the umbilical region. Which of the following statements are true regarding this condition?

1) It is associated with raised AFP (alpha-fetoprotein) levels

2) It occurs due to failure of body wall closure in the abdominal region

3) The contents are covered by an outer layer of amnion and an inner layer of peritoneum

4) It is associated with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome

5) The size of the defect is usually less than 4 cm
questions.solution:
Extravascated bowel loops covered by a sac in the umbilical region are suggestive of omphalocele and statements 1,3 and 4 are correct.

Omphalocele:

It occurs when the bowel loops fail to return from the physiologic umbilical hernia. (It is not due to failure of closure of body wall).

The defect in this condition is generally greater than 4 cm.

Since the umbilical cord is covered by a reflection of the amnion, the omphalocele is also covered by the amnion, which helps to differentiate it from gastroschisis where the bowel loops are not covered by the amnion. The covering sac is composed of an outer layer of amnion and an inner layer of peritoneum.

It is associated with severe malformations such as cardiac anomalies, neural tube defects, and chromosomal anomalies. Also associated with trisomies 13,15,18 and 21.

Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome: It is characterized by macroglossia, gigantism, and an umbilical defect- which can be either an omphalocele or hernia.

Both omphalocele and gastroschisis are associated with elevated AFP levels.

Other abdominal wall defects:

Gastroschisis: It occurs when there is a failure in the closure of the body wall in the abdominal region. The intestinal loops herniate through the defect in the abdominal wall. The defect usually lies to one side of the umbilicus (right side commonly). The loops of the bowel are not covered by amnion as they herniate through the abdominal wall directly into the amniotic cavity. The affected bowel loops can be damaged by exposure to amniotic fluid.
