questions.text:
A 30-year-old male patient is set to undergo a daycare procedure. Which of the following statements regarding daycare procedure are incorrect?
  1. Intravenous (IV) anesthetic agent of choice is propofol
  2. Inhalational anesthetic of choice is sevoflurane.
  3. The preferred muscle relaxant used is succinylcholine.
  4. Thiopental is the preferred intravenous anesthetic.
  5. Morphine increases the risk of postoperative nausea and vomiting
questions.solution:
Statements 3 and 4 are incorrect.

The correct statements are:

  • Intravenous (IV) anesthetic agent of choice is propofol
  • Inhalational anesthetic of choice is sevoflurane.
  • Morphine increases the risk of postoperative nausea and vomiting.

Day surgery is defined as the admission and discharge of a patient for a specific procedure within a 12-hour working day. Success in day surgery requires each component of the pathway to be safe and efficient and to be performed in sequence. Unplanned overnight admissions are minimized by ensuring that:

  • The patient is informed and fit for the procedure
  • The procedure itself is achievable as a day case
  • The procedure is scheduled early on the operating list to allow safe recovery and discharge
  • The home environment can support a postoperative ambulatory patient.

Anesthetic considerations:

The IV anesthetic of choice for daycare surgery is propofol due to its smooth induction and rapid recovery. The antiemetic action is also beneficial. Thiopental results in prolonged postoperative sedation and is not preferred in ambulatory anesthesia Benzodiazepines and ketamine are avoided for similar reasons.

The inhalational anesthetic of choice for daycare surgery is sevoflurane. The low blood-gas partition coefficient, blood-brain coefficient, and minimal airway irritation of sevoflurane promote rapid induction and rapid recovery. Desflurane is also associated with faster recovery but its irritant effect on the upper airway with risk of laryngospasm prevents its use as an induction agent.

Rocuronium is an intermediate-acting muscle relaxant with a rapid onset which is used in daycare anesthesia to facilitate endotracheal intubation and provide surgical relaxation. Its actions can be terminated by the reversal agent sugammadex which produces a rapid and complete reversal of neuromuscular blockade.

Succinylcholine is the shortest-acting muscle relaxant but it has a high incidence of postoperative myalgia. So its use in daycare anesthesia is discouraged.

Analgesics: Paracetamol and other NSAIDs are preferred to manage pain in daycare procedures since opioids increase the risk of postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV). However, short-acting opioids like remifentanil can be used if adequate pain control is not achieved with NSAIDs. Morphine is a long-acting opioid and therefore it should be avoided in daycare surgery to reduce the incidence of PONV.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old boy is being evaluated for recurrent episodes of abdominal pain. On examination, the following finding is noted in the lips and in the buccal mucosa. His vitals are normal and the abdomen was soft and non-tender. An endoscopic study was done and it revealed multiple hamartomatous polyps in the intestine. Which of the following malignancies are associated with this condition?

1) Breast

2) Cervix

3) Pancreas

4) Testicles

5) Thyroid
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of Peutz–Jeghers Syndrome and all the malignancies given in the question can be associated with this condition.

It is an autosomal dominant condition characterized by hamartomatous polyps of the intestinal tract and melanosis of the mouth and the lips.

It germline defects in the tumor suppressor serine-threonine kinase 11 (STK11) gene on chromosome 19.

Clinical features:

  • Hamartomatous polyps of the intestinal tract
  • Hyperpigmentation of the buccal mucosa, lips, perianal skin, and digits
  • Increased (2% to 10%) risk for cancer of the intestinal tract, with cancers reported throughout the intestinal tract, from the stomach to the rectum.
  • Increased risk for extraintestinal malig­nant neoplasms, including cancer of the breast, ovary, cervix, fallopian tubes, thyroid, lung, gallbladder, bile ducts, pancreas, and testicles.

Management:

  • Surgery is indicated in cases where there are bleeding, obstruction, or adenomatous changes of the polyp.
  • If surgery is done for these indictions attempts should be made to remove as much as polyps as possible. 
  • Regular screening with endoscopic studies should be done due to the increased risk of malignancies.
  • Screening of other malignancies like breast and cervix are also important.

Related Pearl: Peutz–Jeghers Syndrome

  • Autosomal-dominant disease
  • Germline defects in the tumor suppressor serine-threonine kinase 11 (STK11) gene on chromosome 19.

Features:

  • Hyperpigmentation of the buccal mucosa, lips, and digits
  • Hamartomatous polyps of the intestinal tract
  • Increased (2% to 10%) risk for cancer of the intestinal tract (stomach - rectum).
  • Increased risk for extraintestinal malig­nant neoplasms, including cancer of the breast, ovary, cervix, fallopian tubes, thyroid, lung, gallbladder, bile ducts, pancreas, and testicles.

Screening: Baseline colonoscopy and upper endoscopy at age 20 years, followed by annual flexible sigmoidoscopy thereafter.

questions.text: During a radiographical imaging procedure a person is positioned as shown in the image given below. Which key structure(s) that would be visualized best with this view?

choices.text: Antrum and upper part of attic

questions.solution:
The view in the given image is Schuller’s view. The key area seen in this view is antrum and upper part of attic.

Schuller's view is a lateral radiographic view of skull. The central beam of X-rays passes from one side of the head at angle of 30° to radiographic plate in the cranio-caudal direction.

Other areas seen in this view include:

  • External canal superimposed on internal canal
  • Mastoid air cells
  • Tegmen
  • Lateral sinus plate
  • Condyle of mandible
  • Sinodural angle

This angulation prevents overlap of images of two mastoid bones. Radiograph for each mastoid is taken separately.

The Schullers view serves as an alternative view to the Law projection which uses a 15 degree angle of patient's face toward the image receptor and a 15 degree caudal angulation to achieve the same result, a lateral mastoid air cells view without overlap of the opposite side. 

Law's view

Related Pearl: Radiographic views of temporal bone

questions.text: You are an intern performing clinical rounds in the casualty. The casualty receives a call asking for arrangements to receive the patients of a road traffic accident that occurred nearby. The trauma PG wants you to assess the severity of the patients, taking the mechanism of injury into account. Which of the following scoring systems will you use?
questions.solution:
The Trauma and Injury Severity Score takes into consideration the "injury mechanism" to calculate the severity of the patient.

The components of TRISS include:

  • Injury Severity Score (ISS)
  • Revised Trauma Score (RTS)
  • Age
  • Mechanism of Injury (blunt/penetrating)

Other options :

Injury Severity Score (ISS):

The Injury Severity Score (ISS) is calculated by summing the squares of the Abbreviated Injury Scale (AIS) severity codes for the three most severely injured body regions. The ISS ranges from 1 to 75, with severity groupings being defined as minor injury (ISS less than 9), moderate injury (ISS between 9 and 16), serious injury (ISS between 16 and 25), and severe injury (ISS more than 25). 

Revised Trauma Score (RTS):

The Revised Trauma Score (RTS) is a well-studied physiologic scoring system that characterizes the injured patient’s condition by incorporating the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS), systolic blood pressure, and respiratory rate. These scores have been of value for research purposes and have been successfully used to make triage decisions.

Mangled Extremity Severity Score (MESS):

The Mangled Extremity Severity Score (MESS) is the most widely validated classification system. It takes into consideration the following,

  • Energy that caused the injury, skeletal and soft tissue injury
  • Limb ischemia
  • Shock
  • Patient’s age

A score of 7 or higher consistently predicted the need for amputation, whereas all limbs with initial scores of 6 or less remained viable in the long term.

Related Pearl: Trauma Scoring Systems

  • Glasgow coma scale
  • Respiratory rate
  • Systolic BP

Glasgow coma scale  - Total score 3-15 :

  • Eye-opening
  • Verbal response
  • Motor response

Abbreviated Injury Scale: AIS severity code – 1(minimal severity) to 6 (presumably fatal)

Injury Severity Score – Total score 1 to 75. Calculated summing the squares of the AIS severity codes for the three most severely injured body regions

Score Severity of injury
3-8 Minor
9-16 Moderate
16-24 Serious
>25 Severe/ Critical

  • Energy that caused the injury, skeletal and soft tissue injury
  • Limb ischemia
  • Shock
  • Patient’s age

TRISS (Trauma and Injury Severity Score) : Mnemonic - IRMA

  • Age

questions.text: A 44-year-old man is brought to the casualty with a suspected whiplash injury following a road traffic accident. Which ligament would be injured in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a whiplash injury. In this, the anterior longitudinal ligament of the spine is damaged.

Whiplash is a form of cervical acceleration-deceleration injury. There is hyperextension followed by flexion in the recoil. The main pathological features seen in these cases include tear (strain) of the anterior longitudinal ligament and the capsular fibers of the facet joints in the spine. In some cases, the intervertebral discs may be damaged. Fracture is seen in severe cases only.

Anterior longitudinal ligament:

  • It is a strong band that extends along the anterior surface of the vertebral bodies
  • It extends from the basilar part of the occipital bone to the upper sacrum
  • It is attached to the anterior tubercle of C1 and the body of C2

 

Infantile whiplash syndrome: Child being gripped in a rough manner, between the perpetrator's hands and shaken, often resulting in subdural hematoma & intraocular bleeding in battered babies.

questions.text: A 60-year-old homeless and malnourished man was admitted to the hospital with a high grade fever and night sweats. He tested positive for HIV on admission. He also complained of a productive cough, with small amounts of thick, purulent sputum. He mentions that he has reduced appetite and has lost weight. He is a chronic alcoholic and smoker. His sputum sample was collected and sent for microscopy and culture. Staining and microscopy showed the following image. How does the person get infected in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette showing pneumonia in a HIV-positive patient and microscopy showing modified acid-fast positive and branching, filamentous rods is suggestive of Nocardia asteroides. Transmission is thought to be through inhalation of contaminated soil.

Nocardia are gram-positive strict aerobes found particularly in the soil and are found to produce lung infections mostly in the immunocompromised.

Nocardia is frequently found in the soil and infection is exogenous. Person-to-person transmission does not occur. It is found worldwide in soil and infection can occur in animals as well.

They are gram-positive and are also positive in Kinyoun's acid-fast staining technique.

Clinical manifestations:

Cutaneous infections may lead to local abscesses, cellulitis, or lymphocutaneous lesions

Pleuropulmonary nocardiosis usually manifests as pneumonia, lung abscess, or other lesions resembling tuberculosis. Symptoms may include fever, night sweats, weight loss, chest pain, cough with or without sputum production, and shortness of breath.

Hematogenous spread from the lung is most frequently to the brain. Other common sites include skin, kidneys, bones, muscles, and eyes, but almost any organ can be involved. Cutaneous infection may lead to local abscesses, cellulitis, lymphocutaneous lesions or actinomycotic mycetoma.

Treatment - Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (Cotrimoxazole) is the drug of choice.

Other options :

Close differentials to Nocardia include

  • Actinomyces species that causes Actinomycosis is endogenous in human beings. They are gram-positive filamentous bacteria similar to Nocardia but are not acid-fast positive.
  • Nocardia mimics tuberculosis in clinical presentation, but tuberculosis is transmitted by an infected person. 
  • Nocardia species infect animals but transmission from animals to human beings does not take place.

questions.text: An intern noticed the following findings while removing the catheter in a 30-year-old patient.  A manual reduction was attempted but was unsuccessful and hence a dorsal slit was made. Surgery was planned 3 weeks later.  Which of the following statements is false regarding the condition and the definitive procedure, done for this patient?

choices.text: It is precipitated after sexual intercourse
It is associated with dorsal chordee

questions.solution:
The clinical history and the image showing swollen glans are suggestive of paraphimosis and circumcision is the definitive procedure done after 3 weeks. It is not associated with dorsal chordee but can lead to ventral chordee. 

Paraphimosis is a condition in which the retracted prepuceal skin over the glans cannot be placed back as a result of which a ring-like constriction is seen proximal to the corona and prepuceal skin. 

This leads to pain and swelling of the glans. Sexual intercourse and urethral catheterization can precipitate the condition. 

Treatment includes manual reduction of the skin. When it is not possible, a dorsal slit has to be made to relieve the pain and compression along with analgesics and antibiotics. This is followed by circumcision after 3 weeks. Alternatively, Sedation and multiple hyaluronidase injection in 10 ml saline are injected to reduce edema followed by circumcision. 

Circumcision is a surgical procedure which involves cutting the dorsal skin up to the corona later extending it circumferentially and ventrally. 

Indications for circumcision include

  • Religious
  • Phimosis - In this condition, the prepuce cannot be retracted over the glans.
  • Paraphimosis after doing initial dorsal slit
  • Balanitis and balanoposthitis - Balanitis is the inflammation of the glans, whereas balanoposthitis involves both glans and prepuce
  • Early carcinoma of the glans penis or prepuce—Here it is both diagnostic as well as therapeutic
  • Certain sexually transmitted diseases, e.g. herpes infection

Complications:

  • Infection
  • Reactionary hemorrhage - It can be due to slippage of ligature from the frenular artery and dorsal vein
  • Urethral stricture near the external meatus in children
  • Chordee due to removal of excess skin on the ventral aspect-Ventral chordee
  • Priapism can occur rarely

questions.text: A 72-year-old man who is a known case of hypertension and diabetes was admitted to the hospital with complaints of sore throat and cough for the past 4 days. His SpO2 at the time of admission was 90% at room air. His CT-lungs showed CORADS -5. He was given supplemental oxygen and other medications, despite which his SpO2 deteriorated. Mechanical ventilation was planned and the patient was intubated. What is the target PaO2 to be maintained during mechanical ventilation?
questions.solution:
A target PaO2 of 55 - 80 mmHg should be maintained in a patient with ARDS who is being mechanically ventilated.

In patients with ARDS, mechanical ventilation should be implemented using lower tidal volumes (4–8 ml/kg predicted body weight, PBW) and lower inspiratory pressures (plateau pressure <30 cmH2O).

The initial tidal volume is 6 ml/kg PBW but tidal volume up to 8 ml/kg PBW is allowed if undesirable side effects occur (e.g. pH <7.15).

In patients with moderate or severe ARDS, a higher PEEP is suggested. PEEP titration requires consideration of benefits (improving alveolar recruitment) vs. risks (end-inspiratory over distension leading to lung injury).

Lung protective ventilation strategy by ARDS net protocol recommends:

Tidal volume  6ml/kg
RR  15-35/min
PEEP  5-15cm H2O
Target plateau pressure < 30cm H2O
Target SpO2 88-95%
Target PaO2  55-80mmHg

questions.text: A 54-year-old female patient came with complaints of neck and upper limb pain. She also gives a history of weakness, incoordination, and clumsiness of upper limbs. Her CT scan is as given below. The diagnosis is

choices.text: Ossification of the anterior longitudinal ligament
Ossification of the posterior longitudinal ligament

questions.solution:
The CT scan shows an ossified posterior longitudinal ligament. 

Patients typically present with symptoms of neck and upper-limb pain, weakness, incoordination, clumsiness, muscle wasting, and bladder-bowel dysfunction, etc and are typically older than 50 years of age

It occurs mainly in the cervical spine, most commonly at the level of C5. It can result in spinal stenosis and cervical myelopathy causing pain and weakness in the limbs. X-ray shows dense ossification along the back of the vertebral bodies in the mid-cervical spine. Cervical spinal cord injury can be induced by minor cervical trauma in these patients.

Treatment is needed if the symptoms are progressive. Posterior decompression is the operation of choice.

questions.text: You are an intern at a hospital that has adopted Baby-friendly Hospital Initiative (BFHI). This global initiative aims to:
questions.solution:
The Baby-friendly Hospital Initiative (BFHI) is a global initiative that aims to promote breastfeeding. It is sponsored by the World Health Organization and the United Nations Children's Fund.

It recommends 10 steps to successful breastfeeding.

They are split into critical management procedures and key clinical practice. Integration of all these steps ensures good breastfeeding practices. The implementation guidance for BFHI emphasizes the strategies to promote universal coverage and ensure sustainability over time. The guidance focuses on the integration of the programme in the healthcare system and ensures the implementation of these steps in all levels of health facilities in the nation. 

Related Pearl: Baby-friendly hospital initiative (revised 2018)

Ten steps to successful breastfeeding (Revised 2018)

Critical management procedures

1  a. Comply fully with the International Code of Marketing of Breast-milk Substitutes and relevant World Health Assembly resolutions.

    b. Have a written infant feeding policy that is routinely communicated to staff and parents.

    c. Establish ongoing monitoring and data-management systems.

2. Ensure that staff has sufficient knowledge, competence, and skills to support breastfeeding.

Key clinical practices

3. Discuss the importance and management of breastfeeding with pregnant women and their families.

4. Facilitate immediate and uninterrupted skin-to-skin contact and support mothers to initiate breastfeeding as soon as possible after birth.

5. Support mothers to initiate and maintain breastfeeding and manage common difficulties.

6. Do not provide breastfed newborns any food or fluids other than breast milk, unless medically indicated.

7. Enable mothers and their infants to remain together and to practice rooming-in 24 hours a day.

8. Support mothers to recognize and respond to their infants’ cues for feeding.

9. Counsel mothers on the use and risks of feeding bottles, teats, and pacifiers.

10. Coordinate discharge so that parents and their infants have timely access to ongoing support and care.

questions.text: Which of the following is a property of the cell wall of the organism that stains as shown below?

choices.text: Absence of aromatic and sulphur containing amino acids

questions.solution:
The given image shows Gram-negative bacilli, the cell walls of which contain lipopolysaccharides.

The table below gives a comparison of the cell walls of gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria.

  Gram-positive Gram-negative
Teichoic acid, lipoteichoic acid Present Absent
Thickness (Peptidoglycan) Thicker Thinner
Variety of amino acids Few Several
Aromatic and sulphur-containing amino acids Absent Present
Lipopolysaccharides and outer membrane Absent Present

Lipopolysaccharides present on the cell walls of gram-negative bacteria account for the endotoxic activity and O antigen specificity. The outermost layer of the gram-negative bacterial cell wall is called the outer membrane and contains several proteins called outer membrane proteins. 

Gram-positive bacteria contain teichoic acid, which is a major surface antigen containing ribitol or glycerol polymers.

The procedure of Gram staining :

  1. Primary staining with a pararosaniline dye such as crystal violet, methyl violet, or gentian violet.
  2. Application of a dilute solution of iodine - fixes the primary dye by forming a crystal violet-iodine complex to prevent easy removal of dye.
  3. Decolourisation with an organic solvent such as ethanol, acetone, or aniline
  4. Counterstaining with a dye of contrasting colour, such as carbol fuchsin, safranine, or neutral red

The gram-positive cell wall is thicker with several layers of peptidoglycan, which helps retain the primary stain and hence appear violet. The gram-negative cell wall has more lipids, which are dissolved by the decolourising agents, causing rapid decolourisation and taking up the counterstain, hence appearing red.

questions.text: A 10-month-old baby is being evaluated for sensorineural hearing loss after an episode of meningitis. The patient is screened for the threshold of hearing using a test that comprises the following waveforms. Which waveform represents the lateral lemniscus?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the waveforms seen in brainstem evoked response audiometry (BERA), and wave V represents the lateral lemniscus.

Brainstem evoked response audiometry (BERA) is an objective and non-invasive method of hearing assessment that detects electrical activity occurring in the auditory pathway. Stimuli are applied in the form of clicks or tone bursts, which then elicit brainstem responses. Normally, 7 waves are produced in the first 10 minutes. 

  • Wave I by the distal part of the vestibulocochlear nerve
  • Wave II by the proximal part of the vestibulocochlear nerve
  • Wave III by the cochlear nucleus
  • Wave IV by superior olivary complex
  • Wave V by lateral lemniscus
  • Waves VI and VII by the inferior colliculus

The first, third, and fifth waves are the most stable and are used in measurements.

Uses of BERA are:

  • As a screening procedure for infants.
  • To determine the threshold of hearing in infants also in children, and adults who do not cooperate and are malingerers.
  • To diagnose brainstem pathology, e.g. multiple sclerosis or pontine tumors.
  • To monitor VIII cranial nerve intraoperatively in surgery of acoustic neuroma to preserve the function of the cochlear nerve.

Related Pearl: BERA (Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry) or ABR (Auditory Brainstem Response)

It is an objective test that records electrical activity occurring in the auditory pathway.

Normally, 7 waves are produced in the first 10ms. 

  • Wave I – distal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave II –proximal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave III – cochlear nucleus
  • Wave IV – superior olivary complex
  • Wave V – lateral lemniscus
  • Wave VI & VII – inferior colliculus

Findings:

  • Conductive or cochlear pathology- delayed wave-I but inter-peak latency of I-V is normal
  • Retrocochlear pathology- wave-I present, rest of the waves absent
  • Acoustic neuroma or vestibular schwannoma- increased inter-peak latency of wave I-V and increased inter-aural latency of wave V > 0.2ms.

Uses:

  • To objectively find hearing threshold- wave-V appears 10dB above the hearing level obtained through PTA
  • Best audiometric test for:
    • Confirming hearing loss in infants
    • Diagnosing acoustic neuroma
    • Differentiating cochlear and retro-cochlear hearing loss
    • Diagnosing non-organic hearing loss.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient with a history of coronary artery disease is posted for surgery by intravenous anesthesia. Etomidate was chosen as the induction agent of choice for this patient. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the effect of this drug?

choices.text: Does not cause pain on injection.

questions.solution:
The incorrect statement regarding the effect of etomidate is, it does not cause pain on injection.

Etomidate is usually dissolved in propylene glycol which causes pain on injection. This can be reduced by prior administration of lidocaine.

It is an intravenous anesthetic agent used for induction. It has minimal effects on the cardiovascular system, hence it is preferred for patients with a history of previous myocardial infarction or coronary artery disease (CAD). It decreases peripheral vascular resistance thereby decreasing blood pressure.

It decreases cerebral blood flow, cerebral metabolic rate, and intracranial pressure. Cerebral perfusion pressure is maintained. Ventilation is less affected.

When used for induction, etomidate inhibits enzymes involved in cortisol and aldosterone synthesis which produce consistent adrenocortical suppression. Postoperative nausea and vomiting are common.

Fentanyl prolongs the half-life and increases the plasma level of etomidate.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman comes with complaints of warty lesions on the vulva as shown in the image below. Which of the following etiological agents is the most common cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Warty lesions on the vulva as seen in the given image is suggestive of Condyloma accuminata (venereal warts), most commonly caused by infection with human papillomavirus (HPV) types 6 and 11. 

Genital warts/venereal warts/condyloma acuminata are verrucous growths that affect the skin of the labia majora, perineum, perianal region, and vulva. The growths may be discrete or coalesce to form cauliflower-like growth. The disease is sexually transmitted. The growth of the warts is favored by vaginal discharge, use of oral contraceptives, and pregnancy.

HPV causes structural changes in the epithelial cells of the skin. These abnormal epithelial cells are called koilocytes, and their presence is characteristic of HPV infection. The koilocytes have large hyperchromatic nuclei and a perinuclear halo.

Diagnosis is made by colposcopic studies. The lesions on the vulva are stained by toluidine blue. The skin with abnormal nuclei retains the blue dye. These abnormal areas are then biopsied for histopathological examination.

Treatment: 

  • Local application of podophyllin 25% in alcohol or podophyllin 20% in tincture benzoin or podophyllin cream
  • 25% trichloracetic acid plus 5% fluorouracil
  • Diathermy loop, laser ablation, cryotherapy for larger lesions
  • Surgical excision
  • Interferon ointment or local injection

questions.text: A patient presenting with diabetic ketoacidosis was treated with IV insulin along with a bolus of normal saline. The initial serum glucose concentration of 350 mg/dL dropped to 250 mg/dL after two hours. BP, pulse, and urine output are normal. Which of the following intravenous fluids is administered next?
questions.solution:
In this patient, half-normal saline with 5% dextrose is administered.

Once the patient is hemodynamically stable, the normal saline infusion is replaced with half-normal saline infusion. It is done to prevent hyperchloremia that can develop from administering large volumes of saline needed to correct dehydration.

Additionally, 5% dextrose is added to half-normal saline when serum glucose concentration is 250 mg/dl and the glucose concentration is maintained between 150-200 mg/dl. This is done to avoid cerebral edema caused by a rapid change in plasma osmolality.

Steps in the management of diabetic ketoacidosis:

1) IV bolus of regular insulin (0.1 units/kg). Avoid insulin and correct potassium level first if below 3.3 meq/L. An IV bolus of normal saline until vitals become stable.

2) Titrate IV infusion of insulin according to a drop in serum glucose.

3) Once vitals are stable, switch to half normal saline. Once serum glucose concentration reaches 250 mg/dl, add 5% dextrose.

4) Treat underlying condition

5) Replace potassium loss and administer bicarbonate if acidosis is severe (pH < 7)

6) Switch to subcutaneous long-acting plus short-acting insulin regimen and wean from IV insulin infusion once a patient resumes eating.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man who had witnessed a terrorist attack has been experiencing frequent intrusive flashbacks and nightmares about the incident. He avoids the places that remind him of it.  He is significantly distressed, has difficulty falling asleep and frequently feels anxious for the last 6 months. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with re-experiences (flashbacks and nightmares), avoidance of the stimuli associated with the attacks, and hyperarousal (impaired sleep and anxiety) for more than one month are suggestive of post-traumatic stress disorder(PTSD).

PTSD is a psychiatric disorder characterized by increased stress and anxiety occurring after a stressful or traumatic event, (e.g., witnessing or being involved in violent accidents, crime, war, assault, kidnapping, natural disaster, life-threatening illness, physical or sexual abuse). 

The predisposing factors for this condition include:

  • Presence of childhood trauma
  • Borderline, paranoid, dependent, or antisocial personality disorder traits
  • Inadequate family or peer support system
  • Female gender
  • Genetic susceptibility to psychiatric illness
  • Recent stressful life changes
  • Recent excessive intake of alcohol

Symptoms of PTSD can be divided into four types:

  • Intrusion symptoms
    • Flashbacks- The individual may act and feel as if the traumatic event is reoccurring 
    • Nightmares of the event
  • Hyperarousal 
    • Increased startle response
    • Insomnia
    • Hypervigilance
    • Difficulty concentrating
    • Reckless and self-destructive behavior
    • Irritability and anxiety
  • Avoidance symptoms:  
    • avoiding memories, thoughts, and feelings of the event
    • avoiding external reminders of the traumatic event
  • Negative cognitions and mood associated with the traumatic event
    • Inability to remember an important aspect of the traumatic event
    • Feelings of depersonalization and derealization
    • Anhedonia
    • Negative emotional state- fear, horror, anger, guilt, or shame

The duration of these symptoms should be > 1 month to label it as PTSD.

Psychotherapies found to be effective for PTSD include exposure therapy, trauma-focused cognitive-behavioral therapy, eye movement desensitization, and abreaction. SSRIs may be prescribed as first-line treatment.

Other options:

Option A: Adjustment disorder is an emotional response to stressful situations like financial issues, medical illnesses, or relation­ship problems that develop within 3 months of the stressor. The stressor in adjustment disorder can be of any severity. In adjustment disorder, the individual does not experience intrusive symptoms like flashbacks and nightmares, hyperarousal symptoms, and avoidance symptoms.

Option B: Acute stress disorder presents with the same symptoms as PTSD, but the symptoms usually occur immediately after the trauma and persist for a period of 3 days to upto 1 month after the trauma.

Option C: Persistent complex bereavement disorder occurs after the death of a loved one. Since the death, for 12 months or more, the individual may experience persistent yearning/longing for the deceased, intense sorrow, and emotional pain, preoccupation with the deceased, and the circumstances of the death.

questions.text: A patient presented to an ophthalmologist with complaints of crowding of words, while reading for long hours. The results of the test that was performed are shown below  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given test is a Maddox rod test, and the pattern of the appearance of white dot/light in relation to the red line denotes a case of left eye exophoria. In the given image, the above image refers to the examiner's view and the below image refers to the patient's view. 

The Maddox rod can be used to test for horizontal and vertical deviations, and when used in conjunction with another Maddox rod, for cyclo-deviations.

Interpretation: 

To test for horizontal deviations, the Maddox rod is placed in front of one eye (for this example, the left eye) with the cylinders in the horizontal direction. The patient fixates a point source of light and then sees a vertical red line with the left eye and white dot/light with the right eye:

  • Orthophoria: if the light/dot superimposes the line.
  • Exo-deviation/exophoria: In this example, light/dot is on the left side of the line (rod placed on left eye)
  • Eso-deviation/esophoria: if the light was on the right side of the line (rod placed on left eye)

Maddox Rod Test involves the use of a Maddox rod and the Maddox tangent scale. It uses a specially constructed device, consisting of a series of parallel cylinders, that converts a point source of light into a line image. The optical properties of the cylinders cause the streak of light to be situated 90° to the orientation of the parallel cylinders.

 

In the image given below, the interpretation of the result is based on how the patient visualizes it. It would appear to be crossed to the patient. Pictorial representation of the eyes are as seen by the examiner. Imagine you are looking through a Maddox rod over your left eye while interpreting the images.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman was admitted for a retrosternal goiter which had been detected when she was evaluated for symptoms of chest discomfort and dyspnea. After routine investigations, fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC), and imaging studies it is decided that she is at high risk to convert from a transcervical approach to a median sternotomy by the surgical team. The presence of which of the following conditions in the patient would not warrant a median sternotomy?

choices.text: Goiter extending into the posterior mediastinum
Diameter of goiter > Diameter of thoracic inlet
Goiter extending up to the superior margin of the aortic arch

questions.solution:
A goiter extending up to the superior margin of the aortic arch is not a high risk for conversion into open sternotomy. Goiters that extend below the inferior margin of the aortic arch are at high risk of conversion to median sternotomy.

Retrosternal goiter is an extension of the multinodular goiter into the mediastinum. It receives its blood supply from the inferior thyroid arteries and venous drainage through the inferior thyroid veins. This condition is usually asymptomatic and may not require surgery. If the gland enlarges within the thoracic inlet, the pressure may lead to dysphagia, tracheal compression, and eventually airway symptoms. But the majority of retrosternal goiters are asymptomatic or show very few symptoms.

Patients considered for surgery :

  • Significant airway compression
  • Symptoms are present
  • In young patients in whom symptoms are likely to develop

Elderly patients where retrosternal goiters are incidentally found, it observed rather than treated.

>95% of retrosternal goiters can be removed through the transcervical approach.

Retrosternal goiters that are at most risk of requiring conversion to an open sternotomy approach :

  • Malignant cases
  • Revision cases
  • Goiters extending into the posterior mediastinum (Option A)
  • Diameter of the goiter exceeding that of the thoracic inlet (Option C)
  • Goiters that reach the carina
  • Goiters that extend below the inferior margin of the aortic arch

If the gland is fixed and immobile (Option B) or too large to deliver through a cervical approach, a midline sternotomy is performed and the gland can be dissected from below to achieve a safe total thyroidectomy.

questions.text: During the cardiovascular examination of a pregnant woman, which among the following findings is not considered physiological change?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, exaggerated splitting of S2 is not a physiological change seen in pregnancy.

Physiological changes in the cardiovascular system in pregnancy:

  • Exaggerated splitting of S1 and increased loudness of both components
  • Loud, easily heard third heart sound (S3)
  • A sys­tolic murmur that intensifies on inspiration or expiration
  • Soft diastolic murmur
  • Mammary souffle- continuous murmur at 2nd to 4th intercostal space
  • A shift of the cardiac apex laterally
  • ECG changes: 
    • Left axis deviation
    • Q waves in leads 2, 3 and avF
    • Flat or inverted T waves in lead 3, V1-V3
  • Increased cardiac output, heart rate, and ejection fraction
  • Decreased systemic vascular resistance and blood pressure

Related Pearl: Cardiovascular changes in pregnancy

  • The resting pulse rate increases by 10 beats/min
  • The apex is moved laterally 
  • Cardiac output remains elevated throughout (maximum in the immediate postpartum period)
  • X-Ray shows a larger cardiac silhouette (due to benign pericardial effusion and shifted apex)
  • ECG: Slight left axis deviation

Heart sounds:

  • First heart sound: Loud with an exaggerated split
  • Second heart sound: Normal but loud
  • Third heart sound: Loud and easily heard

Murmurs:

  • A systolic murmur that was intensified during inspiration or expiration
  • A soft diastolic murmur (in 20%)
  • Continuous murmur arising from the breast vasculature (in 10%)

questions.text: A 24-year-old male patient with multiple ill-defined hypopigmented patches over the face and hands presents to a medical camp. Examination reveals associated sensory loss, loss of hair growth, and sweating in that area. A Lepromin test was performed. Which of the following is not the purpose of the test?

choices.text: To classify the lesions in patients
To indicate prior contact with the causative organism
To assess the prognosis and response to treatment
To assess the resistance of individuals to the disease

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette showing hypopigmented patches with associated sensory loss, loss of hair growth and sweating in the area is suggestive of leprosy, for which the lepromin test is performed, as shown in the image given. The test does not indicate prior contact with the lepra bacilli.

The lepromin test is a prognostic test used in the classification of Leprosy. It has no diagnostic purpose.

  • It involves performing an intradermal injection of the lepromin antigen (synthesized from M. leprae) on the flexor surface of the forearm.
  • It is a skin test for delayed hypersensitivity and is the only method for studying immunity in leprosy. 
  • A positive test indicates good cell-mediated immunity and towards the tuberculoid side of the spectrum
  • A negative test indicates poor cell-mediated immunity and towards the lepromatous side of the spectrum.

The antigens used in the lepromin test are

  • Lepromin A (from armadillo-derived lepra bacilli)
  • Dharmendra antigen

First is the early reaction of Fernandez, which consists of erythema and induration developing in 24-48 hours and usually remaining for 3-5 days; it is usually poorly defined and carries less significance.

The second and more meaningful result is the late reaction of Mitsuda, starting at 1-2 weeks (7-10 days), reaching a peak in three or four weeks, and gradually subsiding over the next few weeks. At the end of 21 days, if there is a nodule more than 5 mm in diameter, the reaction is said to be positive. 

The lepromin test is not used to diagnose leprosy, nor does it indicate prior contact with the lepra bacillus.

The test is used for the following purposes: 

  • To classify the lesions of leprosy patients. The lepromin test is positive in tuberculoid, negative in lepromatous, and variable in dimorphous and indeterminate types of disease.
  • To assess the prognosis and response to treatment. A positive reaction indicates a good prognosis while a negative reaction reflects a bad prognosis. If a patient converts to lepromin-positive during treatment, it is evidence of improvement.
  • To assess the resistance of individuals to leprosy. Lepromin-positive persons are recruited for work in leprosaria as lepromin-negative persons are more prone to develop the disease
  • To verify the identity of candidate lepra bacilli. Cultivable AFB diagnosed to be lepra bacilli should give matching results when tested in parallel with standard lepromin.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male patient presents to the OPD with complaints of pain in the elbow for the past 4-6 weeks. He gives a history that the pain worsens while lifting weights in the gym. On examination, there is tenderness over the medial epicondyle, and reverse Cozen's test is positive. Which of the following is incorrect regarding this condition?

choices.text: Pain is elicited on resisted forearm supination
The origin of pronator teres is usually affected
This is also known as Swimmer's elbow.

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and a positive reverse cozen test is suggestive of medial epicondylitis (Golfer's/ Swimmer's elbow). In this condition, pain is elicited on resisted forearm pronation in extension.

 Medial epicondylitis/ epitrochleitis is also known as golfer's elbow, baseball elbow, suitcase elbow, or forehand tennis elbow/ medial tennis elbow.

Medial epicondylitis (Golfer's elbow)

Clinical features:

  • Less common than tennis elbow
  • It is also called Swimmer's elbow
  • Pain is felt over the medial epicondyle of the humerus where pronators have their origin
  • Pain is elicited on resisted forearm pronation in extension
  • Well localized tenderness is seen when compared to tennis elbow
  • Associated with ulnar nerve neuropathy
  • The origin of pronator teres is usually affected. The other muscle that can be affected is the flexor carpi radialis. 

Tests:

  • Reverse Cozen: The elbow is kept in slight flexion with the hand and wrist in supination. The examiner attempts to extend the elbow, while the patient is asked to resist this movement with active flexion. If pain is elicited at the medial epicondyle, it suggests the golfer’s elbow.

Treatment: 

  • Conservative treatment: Activity modification and pain killers is sufficient in most cases.
  • Operative treatment:  Excision of the abnormal tendons at the flexor-pronator origin

Related Pearl: Medial and lateral epicondylitis

Tennis elbow or Lateral epicondylitis

  • Pain is felt over or below the lateral epicondyle of the humerus
  • Pain is aggravated by lifting movements
  • It is common among tennis players and in those who perform repetitive wrist extension
  • Extensor carpi radialis brevis tendon is commonly involved

Tests:

  • Cozen's test: The patient is asked to pronate the forearm and make a tight fist.  Wrist extension against resistance causes pain at the lateral epicondyle
  • Mills sign: Pain at the lateral condyle when the elbow is extended in pronation with a flexed wrist
  • Wringing test: The patient is asked to wring a towel. Pain is felt at the lateral epicondyle in the tennis elbow
  • Maudsley's test: Resisted extension of the middle finger produces pain at the lateral epicondyle

Treatment: 

  • Conservative treatment: Activity modification and usage of a tennis elbow clasp are sufficient in most cases. Corticosteroid and local anesthetic injections into the tender area may reduce the pain, but is not curative
  • Operative treatment: Detachment of the common extensor muscle from the lateral epicondyle

 

Golfer's elbow or Medial epicondylitis

  • Pain is felt over the medial epicondyle of the humerus where pronators have their origin
  • Associated with ulnar nerve neuropathy
  • Less common than tennis elbow

Tests:

  • Reverse Cozen: The elbow is kept in slight flexion with the hand and wrist in supination. The examiner attempts to extend the elbow, while the patient is asked to resist this movement with active flexion. If pain is elicited at the medial epicondyle, it suggests golfer’s elbow

Treatment: 

  • Conservative treatment: Activity modification and pain killers is sufficient in most cases
  • Operative treatment:  Excision of the abnormal tendons at the flexor-pronator origin

questions.text:
The given waveform is reflective of pressure changes in the atria transmitted to the great veins. Identify the incorrect statements about it.
  1. Wave 1 is due to atrial contraction
  2. Wave 2 is due to ventricular contraction when the tricuspid valve bulges 
  3. Wave 3 is due to venous filling at the end of ventricular contraction
  4. Wave 4 is due to the fall in atrial pressure after the tricuspid valve opens 
  5. Wave 5 is due to the fall in atrial pressure during ventricular systole
questions.solution:
Statements IV and V are incorrect. The waveform in the image is the jugular venous pulse (JVP) waveform or the atrial pressure curve, which is reflective of pressure changes in the atria.

Characteristics of JVP :

  • a wave (wave 1 in the image) corresponds to atrial systole which causes regurgitation of some blood into the great veins. It occurs just after the ECG P wave, and just before the first heart sound (S1). Clinical significance:
    • Prominent waves are seen in reduced right ventricular compliance. 
    • Cannon a waves are seen in heart block, right atrial contraction against a closed tricuspid valve
    • Absent 'a' wave in atrial fibrillation
  • c wave (wave 2 in the image) occurs due to the increase in atrial pressure caused by bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction.
  • The first part of x descent following the “a” wave in the JVP is due to atrial relaxation during ventricular systole due to atrial relaxation in atrial diastole. The second part of the x descent (x’- marked as wave 3 in the graph) occurring after the “c” wave is due to the final phase of right ventricular contraction which allows the right atrium to expand and allows venous filling.
    • Prominent 'x' descent seen in cardiac tamponade and constrictive pericarditis
  • v wave (wave 4 in the image) is seen at the end of ventricular contraction and occurs due to the slow venous filling which causes an increase in atrial pressure. Clinical significance:
    • Prominent 'v' wave in tricuspid regurgitation.
  • y descent (wave 5 in the image) occurs due to the fall in right atrial pressure after the opening of the tricuspid valve. 
    • Rapid 'y' descent in tricuspid regurgitation
    • Absent/prolonged 'y' descent in tricuspid stenosis



Related Pearl: JVP waveform and the abnormalities

Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions

Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

questions.text: A child was brought to the pediatric emergency with complaints of him appearing lethargic and irritable when touched. On examination, his skin is dry, eyes are sunken and hyperreflexia is present. Blood reports show serum sodium to be 150 mEq/L and high serum osmolarity. Which of the following is correct regarding the initial resuscitation of this case?
questions.solution:
The given scenario describing a lethargic child with hyperreflexia, irritability, dry skin, and sunken eyes in the setting of hypernatremia is suggestive of hypernatremic dehydration. The initial resuscitation should include a slow infusion of normal saline rather than ringer lactate.

Hypernatremic dehydration is the most dangerous type of dehydration. Children are often lethargic, and they may be irritable when touched. Hypernatremia may cause fever, hypertonicity, and hyperreflexia. 

Hypernatremia causes the movement of water from brain cells into the hypertonic extracellular fluid, causing brain cell shrinkage and shearing of blood vessels within the brain. If not treated can lead to central nervous system hemorrhages and thrombosis.

The fluid deficit is corrected slowly as rapid treatment of hypernatremic dehydration causes the movement of water from the extracellular space into brain cells, leading to cerebral edema, seizures, brain herniation, and even death. To minimize the risk of cerebral edema during the correction of hypernatremic dehydration, the serum sodium concentration should not decrease by >10 mEq/L every 24 hr. The deficits in severe hypernatremic dehydration may need to be corrected over 2-4 days.

The initial resuscitation requires the restoration of intravascular volume with normal saline (NS). Ringers lactate should not be used as it is more hypotonic than NS and may result in a very rapid decrease in serum concentrations, especially if multiple fluid boluses are necessary.

(Note: Vice versa for hyponatremic dehydration, if hyponatremic dehydration is treated rapidly with 3% saline, it increases the risk of central pontine myelinolysis)

questions.text:
Match the following viruses with their vectors.
Virus Vector
1. Hanta virus A. Aedes aegypti
2. Chikungunya virus B. Culex tritaeniorhynchus
3. Kayasanur Forest disease virus C. Field mice
4. Japanese encephalitis virus D. Haemaphysalis ticks
questions.solution:
The correct answer is option B (1-C, 2-A, 3-D, 4-B). The viruses matched to their respective vectors are as follows :

Virus Vector
1. Hanta virus C. Field mice
2. Chikungunya virus A. Aedes aegypti
3. Kayasanur Forest disease virus D. Haemaphysalis ticks
4. Japanese encephalitis B. Culex tritaeniorhynchus

 

The Hantaan virus belongs to the genus Hantavirus and causes severe hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome (HFRS) in the Far East, North Asia, and Russia. They are a rodent-borne (robo) virus maintained in nature and transmitted by rodents. Hantavirus species are natural pathogens of rodents - field mice (Apodemus agrarius)

Chikungunya virus belongs to the genus Alphavirus. All of the viruses belonging to this genus are mosquito-borne. In India, it caused very extensive epidemics in Kolkata, Chennai, and other areas. The vector is Aedes aegypti. The disease presents with a sudden onset of fever, joint pain, lymphadenopathy, and conjunctivitis. A maculopapular rash is common, although hemorrhagic manifestations are rare. The fever is typically biphasic with a period of remission after 1-6 days.

Kayasanur Forest disease (KFD) virus causes a hemorrhagic fever found in the state of Karnataka, India. KFD has an abrupt onset of fever, headache, conjunctivitis, myalgia, and severe prostration. Some cases develop hemorrhages in the skin, mucosa, and viscera. Infection is transmitted by the bite of ticks, the principal vector being Haemaphysalis spinigera.

Japanese encephalitis is endemic to 15 states including Uttar Pradesh, Assam, West Bengal etc. It is transmitted by Culex tritaeniorhynchus mosquito (which breeds in rice fields) and Culex vishnuii mosquito.  Ardeid birds like herons and egrets are reservoir hosts, while the amplifier hosts are pigs. Human infection is a tangential ‘Dead end’. The disease has an abrupt onset with fever, headache, and vomiting. After 1-6 days, signs of encephalitis set in with nuchal rigidity, convulsions, altered sensorium, and coma. The fever is high and continuous. Infection in pregnant women during first and second trimester can lead to fetal death.

questions.text: A male patient who presented with decreased vision is examined as shown in the image below. Which of the following value is measured by this procedure?
questions.solution:
The procedure performed in the given image is A-scan ultrasonography. It is used for determining the axial length of the eyeball and can be done by direct contact (as shown in the image) or by using a water bath over the eye (immersion ultrasonography).

The sound beam must be aligned with the visual axis for maximal precision. Each reflecting surface is represented by a spike on the oscilloscope monitor.

The power of an intraocular lens (IOL) is calculated by a biometer and the procedure is termed biometry.

The most common method of determining IOL power uses a regression formula called SRK (Sanders-Retzlaff-Kraff) formula, which is given below:

 P = A - 2.5L - 0.9K

Where,

  • P is the power of IOL.
  • A is a constant which is specific for each lens type.
  • L is the axial length of the eyeball in mm determined using the A-scan ultrasonography.
  • K is the average corneal curvature, which is determined by keratometry.

The image given below shows a biometer. 

 

The image below shows A scan ultrasonography for determining the axial length of the eyeball.

 

Option B: Corneal thickness is measured by pachymetry (image below).

 

Option C: Corneal curvature is measured by keratometry or opthalmometry (image below).

 

Option D: Intraocular pressure is measured by tonometry (image below).

questions.text: An obese diabetic female patient is posted for surgery. The anesthetist performs a BURP maneuver during intubation. Identify the true statement regarding this maneuver.

choices.text: It is a technique of internal laryngeal manipulation.
It is useful for rapid-sequence induction.
It is a method of assessment of airway.
In this technique, pressure is applied on the thyroid cartilage.

questions.solution:
The true statement regarding the BURP maneuver is that pressure is applied to the thyroid cartilage.

BURP is a technique of external laryngeal manipulation of the airway during intubation for better visualization of the larynx. This involves Backward, Upward, and Rightward Pressure on the thyroid cartilage.

The illustration shown below shows the BURP maneuver.

Other options : 

Option B: The BURP maneuver should not be confused with Sellick's maneuver (cricoid pressure), which involves the application of pressure to the cricoid cartilage, thus occluding the esophagus. This technique is used in rapid-sequence induction to reduce the risk of aspiration.

Option C: BURP is not a method of assessment of the airway. Various methods of airway assessments are Mallampati grading, Cormack and Lehane grading, and Wilson’s scoring.

questions.text: A man presents with pain and swelling of the right knee and ankle joint for one week with the following lesions on his soles. He gives a history of diarrhea 4 weeks ago. Which of the following is not commonly seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario with arthritis, preceding gastrointestinal infection and the above image showing keratoderma blennorrhagica are suggestive of reactive arthritis/Reiter's syndrome. Posterior uveitis is not seen in this condition. Instead, anterior uveitis is seen. 

Reactive arthritis (ReA) comes under the spectrum of seronegative spondyloarthropathies and is an acute asymmetric nonpurulent arthritis precipitated by an antecedent gastrointestinal or genitourinary infection. It usually occurs in young men and chronic ReA is associated with HLA-B27. Bacterial triggers for ReA are caused by Salmonella, Shigella, Yersinia, Campylobacter, Chlamydia trachomatis, Clostridium difficile, certain toxigenic Escherichia coli, Ureaplasma urealyticum, and Mycoplasma genitalium. There is a typical antecedent history of infection 1-4 weeks before the onset of arthritic symptoms.

Clinical features of ReA include constitutional symptoms like fever, malaise, fatigue and weight loss. There may be asymmetric arthritis with the involvement of a new joint within a few days. It involves large weight-bearing joints like knee and ankle. Dactylitis/sausage digit is a distinctive feature of reactive and psoriatic arthritis.

Extraarticular manifestations include keratoderma blennorrhagica presents as vesicles and pustules that lead to hyperkeratotic lesions/crusting on the palms and soles, enthesitis, anterior uveitis, and conjunctivitis. Circinate balanitis which consists of vesicles that rupture to form painless superficial erosions on the glans penis can be seen. Genitourinary symptoms like urethritis and prostatitis may occur. Cardiac conduction defects and aortic regurgitation may rarely occur.

Elevated ESR and CRP can be seen during the acute phase. Joint X-rays show juxta-articular osteoporosis, marginal erosions, loss of joint space, periostitis with new bone formation, and comma-shaped syndesmophytes.

High-dose NSAIDs have been shown to have some degree of benefit. Antibiotics during the antecedent infection may prevent the emergence of ReA. Intralesional glucocorticoids have been shown to benefit tendinitis and other enthesitic lesions.

questions.text: An elderly man is diagnosed with ischemic heart disease and is started on propranolol. After some days, he is brought to the emergency department with a history of difficulty in breathing. He says that he is a smoker and has had difficulty breathing for the past several years. However, it has worsened after taking propranolol. The mechanism that is mainly responsible for worsening his breathing difficulty is
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the symptoms of respiratory difficulty in the patient have worsened after the intake of propranolol. The mechanism that is mainly responsible for worsening his breathing is β2 blockade. Propranolol is a non-selective beta-blocker. It blocks the β2 receptors in bronchial smooth muscle and prevents bronchodilation. Therefore, it should not be given to patients who have asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.

Other important side effects of beta-blockers are:

  • Cardiovascular system- 
    • Beta blockade decreases myocardial contractility. Therefore, it can exacerbate decompensated heart failure.
    • Decreased heart rate- Bradycardia, In patients with heart block it can cause fatal bradyarrhythmias
    • Abrupt discontinuation of β receptor antagonists after long-term treatment can exacerbate angina
  • Respiratory system- bronchospasm due to blockade of β2 receptors in the bronchial smooth muscles.
  • Central nervous system- fatigue, sleep disturbances, and depression.
  • Exacerbation of peripheral artery disease occurs due to the blockade of β2 receptors in the vascular smooth muscles.
  • It can slow the recovery from insulin-induced hypoglycemia as they inhibit catecholamine-mediated glycogenolysis.
  • This class of drugs is also known to mask the hypoglycemia symptoms in diabetic patients. The symptoms of hypoglycemia which are mediated by the adrenaline release will be masked as beta-blockers will not allow adrenaline to react and interact with its beta 1 receptor.  
  • Hyperkalemia- blockade of β2 receptors prevents the entry of extracellular potassium into the cells.
  • Sexual dysfunction in males
  • They can also alter the serum triglyceride and HDL-cholesterol concentrations. Beta-blockers such as atenolol, metoprolol, and propranolol increase the levels of triglycerides and decrease the levels of high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol. Other beta-blockers like labetalol, pindolol, and acebutolol do not have any effect on lipid levels.

Autonomic innervation of the lung.

Relaxation of the tracheal and bronchial smooth muscles is brought by β2 receptors. Contraction is by the M2 and M3 cholinergic receptors. Therefore, important drugs that used for bronchodilation are 

  • β2 selective agonists like salbutamol, terbutaline, salmeterol, formoterol, etc,
  • Antimuscarinic agents like ipratropium bromide, tiotropium, aclidinium, and umeclidinium.

Propranolol is a non-selective beta-blocker. It acts equal affinity to both β1 and β2 receptors. It does not have intrinsic sympathomimetic activity and does not block α receptors.

Important adverse effects of propranolol are:

Cardiovascular system- It can cause or exacerbate heart failure in patients with compensated heart failure, acute myocardial infarction, or cardiomegaly. In patients with partial or complete AV conduction defects, β antagonists may cause life-threatening bradyarrhythmias. Sudden discontinuation of beta-blockers after prolonged use can exacerbate angina and may increase the risk of sudden death.

Respiratory system- It blocks the β2 receptors in bronchial smooth muscle and can cause bronchospasm.

Nervous system- It causes fatigue, sleep disturbances (including insomnia and nightmares), and depression.

Metabolism- It delays the recovery from insulin-induced hypoglycemia.

Overdosage may lead to hypotension, bradycardia, prolonged AV conduction, and widened QRS complexes, seizures, depression, hypoglycemia, and bronchospasm.

questions.text: A 2-month pregnant woman undergoes a sonographic evaluation of fetal parameters. The parameter marked in the USG shown below best measures ____________.
questions.solution:
The parameter shown in the ultrasonography image is crown-rump length (CRL), which is the most accurate parameter used for the sonographic estimation of gestational age in the first trimester. It has an accuracy range of ± 5 days.

Parameters for estimation of fetal age

Trimester

Parameter

First

Second
  • Biparietal diameter (BPD)
  • Abdominal circumference (AC)
  • Head circumference (HC)
  • Femur length (FL) 

Third

      Femur length

Other options:

Fetal aneuploidy is assessed by measuring the nuchal translucency (NT) on ultrasound. It represents the maximum thickness of the subcuta­neous translucent area between the skin and soft tissue overly­ing the fetal spine at the back of the neck. NT is measured in the sagittal plane between 11 and 14 weeks.

Fetal growth profile can be assessed by the ratio of head circumference (HC) to abdominal circumference (AC). In asymmetric intrauterine growth retardation (IUGR), HC/AC ratio is elevated. In symmetric IUGR, HC/AC ratio remains normal. Abdominal circumference is the most sensitive in detecting IUGR.

Fetal weight is estimated ultrasonographically by combining a number of biometric data like BPD, HC, AC, and FL using Hadlock and Shepard formulae.

It can also be calculated using Johnson’s formula which is the height of the uterus above the symphysis pubis in centimeters minus 12, if the vertex is at or above the level of ischial spines or minus 11, if the vertex is below the level of ischial spines — multiplied by 155, in either case, gives the weight of the fetus in grams.

questions.text: A female patient is being evaluated for right-sided amastia.  On examination, it was found that her right arm was shorter than her left arm and there is an elevation of the shoulder blade on the right side. Poland's syndrome is amastia with the absence of the sternal portion of the pectoralis major marked as "3" in the image. It is identified by its attachment to the clavicle and its bulky muscle mass.

Poland syndrome is associated with unilateral:

  • Absence of breast (amazia or amastia)

In some cases, associated skeletal abnormalities may also be present, such as underdevelopment or absence of upper ribs, the elevation of the shoulder blade (Sprengel deformity), shortening of the arm, or underdevelopment of the forearm bones (ulna and radius). It commonly affects males than females.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement about cytochrome P450.

choices.text: Involved in biosynthesis of cholesterol and steroids
Hydroxylates vitamin D to the biologically active form
It is a heme containing dioxygenase

questions.solution:
The incorrect statement about cytochrome P450 is that it is a heme containing dioxygenase. Cytochrome p450 is a heme-containing monooxygenase. It is located mainly in the endoplasmic reticulum in the liver and intestine but is also found in the mitochondria in some tissues.  

Mitochondrial cytochrome P450 systems are found in steroidogenic tissues such as the adrenal cortex, testis, ovary, and placenta and are concerned with the biosynthesis of steroid hormones and cholesterol. It hydroxylates intermediates in the conversion of cholesterol to steroid hormones. The liver uses this system in bile acid synthesis, and the kidney uses it to hydroxylate vitamin D to its biologically active hydroxylated form.

Micro­somal cytochrome P450 in the endoplasmic reticulum of the liver detoxifies xenobiotics like drugs, carcinogens, and pesti­cides. The cytochrome P450 monooxygenase system hydroxylates these toxins, using NADPH as the source of reducing equivalents. The purpose is to activate or inactivate a drug or to make a toxic compound more soluble, thus facilitating excretion.

The induction of cytochrome P450 is the reason for drug interactions. For example, warfarin is metabolized by CYP2C9, which is induced by phenobarbital. The induction of CYP2C9 thus increases the metabolism of warfarin, which reduced its efficacy.

Naturally occurring compounds in foods such as grapefruit also affect cytochrome P450. Grapefruit contains furanocoumarins, which inhibit cytochrome P450 and affect the metabolism of many drugs like statins, omeprazole, antihistamines, and benzodiazepines.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the OPD with complaints of decreased urine output, cola-colored urine, and swelling of the hands and face. On examination, there is elevated blood pressure and pitting edema in the lower limbs. His mother gives a history of skin infection 4 weeks back. A diagnosis of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis is made.  Which of the following is best used to detect the previous streptococcal skin infection in this case?
questions.solution:
Anti-DNAase B antibody level is the best indicator of previous streptococcal skin infections in PSGN cases.

Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) usually occurs following an infection of the throat or skin by nephritogenic strains of group A β-hemolytic streptococci and is characterized by the sudden onset of gross hematuria, edema,  hypertension, and renal insufficiency. Diagnosis of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis(PSGN):

  • Urine analysis shows RBCs, along with RBC casts, proteinuria, and neutrophils.
  • Hemodilution and low-grade hemolysis may produce mild normocytic normochromic anemia.
  • Serum C3 levels are decreased in the acute phase and return to normal in 6-8 weeks.
  • Throat swab (Streptococcal Antigen Detection) for prior streptococcal infection or carrier state identification.
  • Raised ASO titers are commonly seen following pharyngeal infection. An increase in ASO levels is rarely seen with skin infections.
  • Anti-DNAase B antibody level is the best indicator of previous streptococcal skin infections.
  • MRI may be done in patients with neurological manifestations and it can demonstrate posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome.

Note: CAMP Test is used to identify Streptococcus agalactiae (Group B streptococci).

Microscopic Findings in PSGN:
  • Light microscopy: Enlarged, pale glomeruli with diffuse mesangial proliferation and an increase in the mesangial matrix. 
  • Immunofluorescence: Lumpy-bumpy deposits of immunoglobulin and complement on the glomerular basement membrane(GBM)and in the mesangium. 
  • Electron microscopy: Electron-dense deposits, or humps, are observed on the epithelial side of the GBM.

Treatment:

Managing the acute effects of renal insufficiency (sodium restriction and prescribing diuretics - usually with intravenous furosemide) and hypertension is the mainstay. Antibiotic therapy with a 10-day course of penicillin is recommended to limit the spread of nephritogenic pathogens. But antibiotics do not alter the natural course of PSGN.

questions.text: A lethargic infant was presented with vomiting and irritability. He was diagnosed with an X-linked recessive disorder due to the deficiency of ornithine transcarbamoylase. What is the likely disorder?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with a deficiency in enzyme ornithine transcarbamoylase is likely to have a diagnosis of type 2 hyperammonemia inherited in an X-linked recessive manner.

In the urea cycle, the enzyme ornithine transcarbamoylase catalyzes the condensation of carbamoyl phosphate with ornithine to form citrulline. The deficiency of this enzyme leads to the accumulation of carbamoyl phosphate leading to elevated levels of glutamine in the blood, urine, and cerebrospinal fluid. 

Infants present with vomiting, irritability, lethargy, hypothermia, and apnea due to high ammonia levels in the plasma. Mothers also have an aversion to protein-rich foods. 

Urea cycle disorders are all characterized by hyperammonemia, encephalopathy, and respiratory alkalosis. This is due to an accumulation of the precursors of urea namely ammonia, and glutamine.

The enzymes involved in the urea cycle with their related disorders are given below:

  1. Carbamoyl-phosphate synthetase (CPS) 1 deficiency (hyperammonemia type 1) - rare and characterized by severe hyperammonemia.
  2. Ornithine transporter deficiency (HHH syndrome) - is characterized by hyperornithinemia, hyperammonemia, and homocitrullinuria.
  3. Ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency (hyperammonemia type 2) - is inherited as an X-linked trait. Characterized by hyperammonemia and elevated glutamine levels in blood and CSF.
  4. Argininosuccinate synthetase deficiency - is characterized by increased citrulline, citrullinuria, and hyperammonemia.
  5. Argininosuccinate lyase deficiency- leads to argininosuccinic acidemia and metabolic acidosis. Hyperammonemia is less severe and argininosuccinate is found in urine and CSF.
  6. Arginase deficiency- mild variety. Characterized by hyperargininemia and argininuria.

Clinical features of urea cycle disorders are common to all and include vomiting, avoidance of high-protein foods, intermittent ataxia, irritability, lethargy, and severe mental retardation. 

Long terms treatment consists of a protein-restricted diet.

Related Pearl: Urea Cycle and its disorders

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct order of frequency of incidence of carcinoma colon from the image given below?
questions.solution:
The correct order of frequency of incidence of carcinoma colon is sigmoid colon>caecum>transverse colon>ascending colon, 4>1>3>2.

Structures marked in the image are 

  • 1 - Caecum
  • 2 - Ascending colon
  • 3 - Transverse colon
  • 4 - Sigmoid colon

The sites of carcinoma in order of frequency are:

  • Rectum - most common
  • Sigmoid colon
  • Caecum
  • Transverse colon
  • Ascending colon
  • Descending colon
  • Splenic flexure
  • Hepatic flexure

Note:

The rectum is not a part of the colon and hence sigmoid is the most common site for carcinoma colon.
