questions.text: A patient has been treated for the lesion shown in the picture below for the past 12 months but there has been no response to treatment. What is the next line of treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a patient with keloid, refractory to the first line of treatment after 12 months of therapy should be considered for surgical exci­sion in combination with adjuvant therapy (postoperative electron beam irradiation).

A keloid scar is defined as excessive scar tissue that extends beyond the boundaries of the original incision or wound. Its etiology is unknown, but is associated with elevated levels of growth factor, deeply pigmented skin, and inherited tendency and certain areas of the body (triangle whose points are the xiphisternum and each shoulder tip).

Keloid scars do not improve spontaneously with time and excision of the keloid scar has a high rate of recurrence.

Treatment of keloids :

  • First-line treatments include silicones in combination with pressure therapy and intralesional corticosteroid injections.
  • Intralesional 5-fluorouracil, bleomycin, and verapamil should be used in accordance with established treatment protocols.
  • Refractory cases after 12 months of therapy should be considered for surgical excision in combination with adjuvant therapy.
  • Excision alone results in a high recurrence rate of 50% to 100% and enlargement of the keloid.
  • Immediate postoperative electron beam irradiation or brachytherapy with iridium-192 reduces recurrence rates. The risk of malignancy attributable to keloid radiation therapy is minimal.
  • An additional new invasive treatment modality is internal cryotherapy, in which a metal rod is introduced into the keloid and the subsequent extreme cooling leads to tissue necrosis.

questions.text: Identify the characteristic radiographic finding shown in the image
questions.solution:
The image shows the drooping lily sign on the right side, a urographic sign observed in patients with a duplicated collecting system. 

The drooping lily sign refers to the inferolateral displacement of the opacified lower pole moiety due to an obstructed upper pole moiety.

 

Other options: 

Option A - Fish hook ureter: 

  • Bilateral Fishhook ureters ("J-shaped ureters" or "hockey stick ureter") describe the course of the distal ureter in patients with significant benign prostatic hypertrophy.
  • Right-sided fish hook ureter describes the appearance of the retrocaval ureter as the right ureter hooks behind the IVC, it has also been referred to as an S-shaped ureter.

The image given below shows right-sided fish hook ureter

 

Option C - Bouquet of flowers appearance: It is a characteristic IVP finding in the medullary sponge kidney. The ectatic distal collecting ducts contain the microcalcification giving this appearance. It is also known as the bunch of grapes appearance.

The following image shows the bouquet of flowers appearance:

 

Option D - In vesicoureteric reflex, there is an abnormal flow of urine from the bladder into the upper urinary tract. It is seen in children. It is graded as the following: 

Grade 1: reflux limited to the ureter

Grade 2: reflux into the renal pelvis

Grade 3: mild dilation of ureter and pelvicalyceal system

Grade 4: tortuous ureter with moderate dilatation, blunting of fornices with preserved papillary impressions

Grade 5: tortuous ureter with severe dilatation of the ureter and pelvicalyceal system, loss of fornices and papillary impressions

The following image shows unilateral vesicoureteric reflex.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old woman presents with a unilateral throbbing headache associated with nausea and vomiting. She has had similar episodes in the past where the headache usually lasts for 1-2 days. Bright light increases her discomfort and she prefers sitting in a dark room. Which of the following are used to prevent further episodes of this condition?
  1. Sumatriptan
  2. Propranolol
  3. Naproxen
  4. Topiramate
  5. Transcranial magnetic stimulation
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario featuring unilateral throbbing headache with aura (photophobia, nausea, vomiting) is suggestive of migraine with aura. Options 2,4, and 5 i.e. propranolol, topiramate, and transcranial magnetic stimulation are used for prophylaxis against migraine.

Sumatriptan and naproxen are used in the acute management of migraine (not used as preventive medication).

Other drugs used in the prophylaxis of migraine:

  • Beta-blockers - propranolol, metoprolol
  • Antidepressants - amitriptyline, venlafaxine
  • Anticonvulsants - valproate, topiramate
  • Serotonergic drugs - pizotifen
  • Flunarizine, Candesartan
  • CGRP antagonists - erenumab, fremanezumab, galcanezumab, eptinezumab.

Other modalities of preventive treatment:

  • Onabotulinum toxin A 
  • Neuromodulation: A single-pulse transcranial magnetic stimulation (sTMS) is delivered with a hand-held device (FDA approved) that creates a fluctuating magnetic field that triggers an electric current that modifies cortical excitability.

Drugs with no role in prophylaxis :

  • Calcium channel blockers - verapamil, nimodipine
  • α2 adrenergic agonist - clonidine
  • Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors - fluoxetine

Related Pearl: Simplified diagnostic criteria for migraine

Repeated attacks of headache lasting 4-72 h in patients with a normal physical examination with no other reasonable cause for the headache, and

At least 2 of the following features:

  • Unilateral pain
  • Throbbing pain
  • Aggravation by movement
  • Moderate or severe intensity

Plus at least 1 of the following features:

  • Nausea/vomiting
  • Photophobia and phonophobia

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is brought to the casualty with an injury to his leg. On examination, bruises and ecchymoses of varying ages are noted all over the body. The x-ray shows a spiral fracture of the femur. Which of the following is less likely to be seen in this condition?

choices.text: Head injury as the most common cause of death

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario with a spiral fracture of the femur and bruises of various ages points to a diagnosis of battered baby syndrome, where evidence of strangling or stabbing is less likely to be seen.

A battered child is one who has received repetitive physical injuries as a result of non-accidental violence, produced by a parent or guardian, there may also be deprivation of nutrition, care, and affection. The syndrome is also known as child abuse syndrome, non-accidental injury of childhood, Caffey's syndrome, and maltreatment syndrome in children.

The syndrome must be considered in any child:

  • In whom the degree and type of injury vary with the history given
  • When injuries are of different ages and in different stages of healing
  • When there is a purposeful delay in seeking medical attention despite serious injury
  • Who exhibits evidence of fracture of any bone, subdural hematoma, or skin bruising
  • Who dies suddenly

Classical features:

  • Multiple bruises, lacerations, and abrasions of varying ages and shapes all over the body
  • Round pitted burns from cigarette stubs
  • Tear of the frenulum resulting from efforts to silence a crying or screaming child
  • Infantile whiplash syndrome - subdural hematoma and intraocular bleeding as a result of shaking the child, as described by Caffey
  • Subgaleal hematoma
  • Traumatic alopecia, appearing as bald patches
  • Perforations and rupture of abdominal viscera
  • Retinal separation, vitreous, subconjunctival, and retinal haemorrhages and black eye

Skeletal injuries that are commonly seen:

  • Skull fractures
  • Large periosteal hematomas
  • Epiphyseal separation and periosteal shearing in the limbs
  • Transverse and spiral fractures of long bones - Due to compression, bending, and direct forcible blows
  • Fractures of ribs in the midaxillary line due to anteroposterior compression of the chest
  • Fractures at the costochondral junctions due to violent squeezing of the chest from side to side
  • Multiple rib fractures (called knobbing fractures) along the posterior angles of the ribs, in the paravertebral gutter, giving rise to the string-of-beads appearance on x-ray (Option B)

A skeletal survey, which includes the following, should be done in a case of suspected child abuse:

  • AP views of the entire skeleton
  • Dedicated views of hands and feet
  • Lateral views of the appendicular skeleton, skull, and spine

Head injury is the most common cause of death in battered baby syndrome (Option C), followed by rupture of an abdominal organ(Option D).

questions.text: A 38-year-old man presented with complaints of a rash in the elbows and knees as shown below. It has been associated with intense itching for a few weeks. On further evaluation, direct immunofluorescence  shows IgA deposition in the dermal papillae and serology revealed the presence of anti-TTG.  Which of the following drugs will you prescribe as first line for this patient along with dietary modification?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a middle-aged male patient with positive anti-TTG, multiple pruritic erythematous macules and papules on the knees and elbows (as shown in image) and IgA deposition in dermal papillae are suggestive of dermatitis herpetiformis in association with gluten-sensitive enteropathy. Dapsone will be the first-line drug in this case.

Dapsone helps in short-term management of dermatitis herpetiformis by its effects on neutrophil function and recruitment.

Adverse side effects:

  • Hemolysis especially in patients with G6PD deficiency
  • Methaemoglobinaemia
  • Agranulocytosis
  • Dapsone hypersensitivity syndrome
  • Peripheral neuropathy

Dapsone should always be used in combination with a gluten‐free diet. It doesn't show any effect on the gastrointestinal symptoms of the associated gluten-sensitive enteropathy.

Dermatitis herpetiformis is a chronic, intensely pruritic, skin condition associated with gluten‐sensitive enteropathy. 

  • It can also be associated with autoimmune thyroid disease.
  • It is associated with HLA‐DQ2.
  • It typically appears in the 4th decade, and the patients present with itching and rash, most typically over the extensor surfaces of the elbows, knees, buttocks, and scalp.
  • They may also have symptoms associated with gluten-sensitive enteropathies, like bloating, diarrhea and other gastrointestinal complaints.

On examination, multiple erythematous macules and papules can be seen over the extensor aspects. They appear symmetrical and heal without scarring. The oral cavity may show mucosal abnormalities and enamel pits.

Diagnosis can be made by clinical features, histopathology, direct immunofluorescence testing, and serology.

The histopathology of an intact vesicle in dermatitis herpetiformis will show subepidermal blister formation with neutrophils located at the tips of the dermal papillae. Perivascular infiltrates can also be seen.

Direct immunofluorescence can be done to the skin samples taken from the lesion and perilesional skin. It will show the deposition of IgA antibodies in the papillary dermis in a granular or fibrillar pattern. Complement 3 may also be found along with the IgA deposits.

Serology many show the presence of IgA anti-endomysial autoantibodies that target epidermal transglutaminase 3.

Treatment ladder for Dermatitis herpetiformis:

First-line:

  • Gluten-free diet is the mainstay of treatment
  • Dapsone - short term management of the symptoms
  • Potent topical steroid

Second-line:

  • Sulphamethoxypyridazine

Third-line:

  • Sulphasalazine 
  • Sulphapyridine  

The below image shows the deposition of IgA antibodies in the papillary dermis in a granular pattern. These antibodies are epidermal transglutaminase 3.

questions.text: An ENT surgeon is performing submucosal resection in a patient with a deviated nasal septum. As an intern posted in the department, you are asked about the various contraindications of this procedure. In which of the following patients, will the surgery not be contraindicated?

choices.text: A 20-year-old patient with acute respiratory infection
A 35-year-old patient with controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus

questions.solution:
In a 35-year-old patient with controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus, submucosal resection (SMR) of the deviated nasal septum (DNS) is not contraindicated.

Contraindications of SMR surgery:

  • Patients within the age of 17 years- conservative surgery like septoplasty is preferred in such cases
  • Acute episode of respiratory infection
  • Bleeding disorders
  • Untreated or uncontrolled diabetes mellitus or hypertension

Surgery in a case of DNS is indicated when the condition causes recurrence of symptoms such as

  • Nasal obstruction and recurrent headaches
  • Sinusitis and otitis media due to obstruction to ventilation of paranasal sinuses and middle ear
  • Recurrent epistaxis from the septal spur
  • Sleep apnea or hypopnea syndrome

Indications for septoplasty:

  • Cosmetic correction of external nasal deformities, as a part of septorhinoplasty
  • Preliminary step in hypophysectomy (trans-septal trans-sphenoidal approach) or vidian neurectomy (trans-septal approach)
  • Approach to middle meatus or frontal recess in endoscopic sinus surgery when deviated septum obstructs the view and access to these areas
  • Access to endoscopic dacryocystorhinostomy operation in some cases.

Related Pearl: Nasal Septum

Septum proper is an osseocartilaginous framework made up of:

  • Septal or quadrilateral cartilage
  • Perpendicular plate of ethmoid
  • Vomer
  • Others – crest of nasal bones, nasal spine of frontal bone, rostrum of sphenoid, crest of palatine bones and the crest maxilla, and the anterior nasal spine of maxilla

questions.text: A 9-year-old child is brought to the dermatology clinic with complaints of reddish-pink nodules on her back. The mother is worried about it being a tumour. A sample is sent for histopathological examination and the findings are shown below. Which variant of melanocytic nevus does this child have?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette with histopathological findings showing large fusiform plump cells with blue-pink cytoplasm is highly suggestive of the Spitz nevus (spindle and epithelioid cell nevus) variant of melanocytic nevus.

Melanocytic nevi (moles) are common benign neoplasms caused by acquired activating mutations in components of the Ras signalling pathway.

Based on the location, it may be junctional nevi, intradermal nevi or compound nevi.

Melanocytic nevi are thought to progress through a series of morphologic changes over time. Superficial nevus cells are larger, tend to produce melanin, and grow in nests. Deeper nevus cells are smaller, produce little or no pigment, and appear as cords and single cells. At the deepest extent of the lesions, these cells often acquire fusiform contours and grow in fascicles resembling neural tissue (neurotization).

Melanocytic nevi with neurotization indicate normal maturation change and help in differentiating benign nevi from melanomas (which lacks such features)

This morphological change in nevus cells occurs due to progressive loss of tyrosinase activity and acquisition of cholinesterase activity in deeper “nervelike” nevus cells.

questions.text: The results of a meta-analysis of various studies on the relationship between rabies infection and mortality rates are plotted as shown in the image below. What is this graphical representation known as?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a funnel plot, which is a means to assess the extent to which a systematic review is influenced by publication and other biases.

In general, there will be more variability in the results of smaller studies than larger studies, so, this plot should look like an inverted funnel. The larger study results cluster around the overall mean effect more closely than the results of the smaller studies. A funnel plot displays the effect size plotted against the sample size.

If the distribution of results of smaller studies is asymmetrical, it suggests that some smaller studies that showed unfavorable results may be missing from the analysis because of various biases. An asymmetrical funnel plot shows the apparent presence of publication bias. 

Other options :

Option B: Forest plots are commonly used to present the results of meta-analyses. It allows the results to be seen at a glance, with ready identification of outliers.

The following image shows a generic forest plot showing the odds ratios of various studies, their confidence intervals, and the summary measure arrived at through meta-analysis.

Option C: Scattergram is a graphical representation of the bivariate distribution relationship between two correlated variables. Correlation expresses the strength and direction of the relationship between two variables. This is expressed in terms of a correlation coefficient, signified by r.

Values of r vary from -1 (perfect negative correlation) to +1 (perfect positive correlation). Coefficients between ±0.5 and 1 are regarded as strong whereas those between ±0.5 and 0 are regarded as weak. The strength of the relationship is indicated by the size of the coefficient and its direction is indicated by the sign. 

The image below shows a scattergram.

Option D- An ogive is a cumulative frequency polygon that forms a typical S-shaped curve.

The following image shows an example of an ogive.

Related Pearl: Funnel Plots

  • A funnel plot is basically a scatter plot of individual studies which are used in systematic reviews and meta-analysis. It plots their precisions and results.
  • In a funnel plot, each dot represents an individual study.
  • The y-axis is usually the standard error or another estimate of precision and the x-axis is the outcome, usually the odds ratio.
  • Higher powered studies are placed towards the top and the lower powered ones towards the bottom such that the plot resembles an inverted funnel or a pyramid.
  • This shape is expected as different studies have different standard errors and other estimates.
  • A symmetrical funnel plot is shown in Fig. A. in the image below.
  • These funnel plots are used in meta-analysis to check for bias like publication bias or other reporting bias.
  • In the case of bias being present, an asymmetrical funnel plot results, as shown in Fig. B. of the image below.

Related Pearl: Graphical Representation of Data

1. Histogram

  • A histogram, by definition, is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains rectangles and shows the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.
  • The X or horizontal axis is called the abscissa which usually has the group scores or class intervals of the variables/data and the Y or vertical axis is called the ordinate which usually shows the frequencies at which these variables appear.
  • The following image shows a histogram.

2. Bar Chart

  • It is also called a bar graph.
  • It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data as they are not quantitative and usually qualitative.
  • The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups.
  • Bar graphs can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.

3. Pie Charts

  • Pie charts are also used for nominal or ordinal data.
  • The categorical data are represented as segments of a circle.

4. Frequency polygons

  • Frequency polygons are used for mainly ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

5. Ogive

  • A frequency polygon which is drawn to represent cumulative frequency distributions form a typical S-shaped curve which is called an ogive. It referred to as a cumulative frequency diagram.

6. Line chart

  • It is also called a line diagram or line graph.
  • Its best use is to show the trend of events or change over passage of time.

questions.text: A patient admitted to the medical intensive care unit is found to have non-anion-gap metabolic acidosis. Further investigations reveal a serum potassium level of 3.2 mmol/L, low urinary ammonium ions, and a positive urine anion gap. The pH of the urine is found to be 5.7. No other substances were found to be abnormally excreted in the urine. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient has type 1 renal tubular acidosis. The points that favor the diagnosis are hypokalemia, non-anion-gap metabolic acidosis, positive urine anion gap, low urine ammonium ions, and pH of the urine of more than 5.5.

Type 1 renal tubular acidosis (RTA) occurs due to impaired acid excretion in the distal tubule. Patients will have hypokalemia, a non-anion-gap metabolic acidosis, positive urine anion gap, low urine [NH4+]), and high urine pH (pH > 5.5). Most patients also have hypocitraturia and hypercalciuria, so nephrolithiasis, nephrocalcinosis, and bone disease are common.

Type 2 renal tubular acidosis occurs due to impaired reabsorption of bicarbonate ions in the proximal tubule. In addition to hypokalemic metabolic acidosis, patients also have glycosuria, generalized aminoaciduria, and phosphaturia (Fanconi syndrome). Since the acidification in the distal tubule is functioning normally, the pH of the urine is less than 5.5

Type 3 renal tubular acidosis has mixed features of both type 1 and type 2 RTA.

Type 4 renal tubular acidosis is common in patients with diabetes mellitus, tubulointerstitial disease, or chronic kidney disease. It occurs as a result of decreased aldosterone. The patients will have hyperkalemic metabolic acidosis along with hypertension.

questions.text: Which of the following vitamins play a role in Kreb's cycle?

choices.text: Vitamins B1, B2, B3 and B5
Vitamins B1, B3, B6 and B12
Vitamins B2, B3, B5 and B6
Vitamins B3, B6, B12 and B5

questions.solution:
Vitamins B1, B2, B3, and B5 of the vitamin B complex play a role in Kreb's cycle.

The following vitamins serve as cofactors for various enzymes of the tricarboxylic acid(TCA) cycle –

  • Vitamin B1: Thiamine
    • Active form - thiamine diphosphate
    • Cofactor for decarboxylation step of alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase complex.
  • Vitamin B2: Riboflavin
    • Active form - FAD (flavin adenine dinucleotide)
    • Cofactor for succinate dehydrogenase
  • Vitamin B3: Niacin
    • Active form - NAD+ (nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide)
    • Cofactor for isocitrate dehydrogenase, α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, and malate dehydrogenase complex
  • Vitamin B5: Pantothenic acid
    • Active form - as a part of coenzyme A
    • Cofactor for esterified to the carboxylic acid residues, i.e. acetyl-CoA and succinyl-CoA.

Related Pearl: Steps involved in TCA cycle

Step 1

Acetyl CoA + Oxaloacetate → Citrate

     (2C  + 4C  =   6C)

Enzyme: Citrate Synthase

Irreversible, Exothermic reaction
Step 2

Citrate → Cis –aconitate  → Isocitrate 

( 6C    →          6C →             6C)

Enzyme:   Aconitase

Cofactor:   Fe2+

The Reaction occurs in 2 steps:         

1st step:  Dehydration      

2nd step:  Rehydration

Inhibited by: Fluoroacetate (Non- Competitive)
Step 3

Isocitrate →[Oxalosuccinate]→α- Keto glutarate

        (6C) →         [6C]         →         (5C)

Enzyme:  Isocitrate Dehydrogenase

Cofactor:   Mn2+ or Mg2+

Reaction:  Oxidative  Decarboxylation

Intermediate:   Oxalosuccinate [ Unstable]

Release:    1 NADH and CO2
Step 4

α- Keto glutarate → Succcinyl Co A 

       (5C             →         4C)

Enzyme: α- Ketoglutarate Dehydrogenase(Multienzyme complex)

Reaction:  Oxidative Decarboxylation

Inhibited by: Arsenite  (Non – Competitive)

Physiologically unidirectional step.

Release: 1 NADH and CO2
Step 5

Succinyl- CoA  → Succinate

      ( 4C          →         4C )

Enzyme:  Succinate Thiokinase

Cofactor: Mg2+

Release:  1 ATP / GTP

Substrate level phosphorylation
Step 6

Succinate  →   Fumarate

( 4C          →         4C )

Enzyme:  Succinate Dehydrogenase (Part of 2nd complex ETC)

Cofactor:  FAD and Fe-S protein 

The only enzyme of TCA cycle attached to the inner mitochondrial membrane.

Inhibited by: Malonate ( competitive)

Release: FADH2
Step 7

Fumarate  →   Malate

( 4C         →     4C )

Enzyme:  Fumarate Hydratase

Reaction: Hydration
Step 8

Malate  →  Oxaloacetate  

( 4C     →        4C )

Enzyme:  Malate Dehydrogenase

Release:  1 NADH

Oxaloacetate is regenerated.

questions.text: An ENT resident administers a submucosal injection of Teflon paste to one of his patients. Which of the following nasal conditions is he treating?
questions.solution:
Injection of submucosal Teflon paste is a treatment approach for atrophic rhinitis.

The nasal chambers are very wide in atrophic rhinitis, so the air currents dry up the secretions, leading to crusting. Thus, the narrowing of the nasal airway helps relieve the symptoms.

Young’s operation - Both the nostrils are closed completely just within the nasal vestibule by raising flaps. The nostrils are re-opened after at least 6 months. With this procedure, the mucosa may revert to normal, and crusting may reduce.

Modified Young’s operation - This procedure aims at partially closing the nostrils. The result is the same as Young’s operation.

Other options:

Option A - Vasomotor rhinitis: Treated with vidian neurectomy, i.e. sectioning of parasympathetic secretomotor fibres to the nose

Option C - Rhinitis medicamentosa is also known as rebound congestion. It occurs due to overuse of topical nasal decongestants which leads to inflammation. It is treated by discontinuing the decongestant. This may lead to an initial worsening of symptoms which can be relieved using intranasal corticosteroids.

Option D - Rhinoscleroma is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by the gram-negative bacillus Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis. It usually affects young adults in the third to fourth decade of life and risk factors include malnutrition, poor hygiene, and overcrowding. Medical management is the mainstay treatment for rhinoscleroma. Streptomycin (1 g/day) and tetracycline (2 g/day) are given for a minimum of 4-6 weeks and continued till 2 consecutive biopsies are negative. Surgery is reserved to establish airway or correct deformity.

questions.text:
Match the following influenza viruses with their corresponding pandemics.
Influenza strain and period Pandemic
1. (H1N1) virus, 1918-1919 A. Hong Kong flu
2. (H2N2) virus, 1957-1958 B. Swine flu
3. (H3N2) virus, 1968 C. Asian flu
4. (H1N1) virus, 2009-2010 D. Spanish flu
questions.solution:
Option C is correct.

Influenza strain and period Pandemic
1. Influenza A(H1N1) virus, 1918-1919 D. Spanish flu
2. Influenza A(H2N2) virus, 1957-1958 C. Asian flu
3. Influenza A(H3N2) virus, 1968 A. Hong Kong flu
4. Influenza A(H1N1) virus, 2009-2010 B. Swine flu

Endemics :

The constant recurrence of a disease or infectious agent within a particular specified geographical region or population group is known as an endemic disease. An endemic disease might burst into a pandemic, given the right conditions. 

Epidemics :

The occurrence of an illness or a health-related event in a community or region in excess of normal expectancy is known as an epidemic. The community or region and the period in which the cases occur must be specified precisely.

Pandemics :

A pandemic is an epidemic occurring over a very wide area, crossing international boundaries, and usually affecting a large number of people. Examples: Influenza pandemics and cholera pandemics.

questions.text: A 6-month-old child has a history of recurrent skin and respiratory tract infections. Investigations are carried out and a disorder of phagocytosis is suspected. Which of the following will not be a differential diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
DiGeorge syndrome is not a disorder of phagocytosis.

It is due to a developmental defect involving the endodermal derivatives of the 3rd and 4th pharyngeal pouches. Cell-mediated immunity is defective due to decreased T-cells. Affected individuals also have depressed graft rejection, hypocalcemia, and cardiac defects. 

Disorders of phagocytosis:

  • Leukocyte adhesion deficiency
  • Chediak–Higashi syndrome
  • Chronic granulomatous disease
  • Tuftsin deficiency
  • Cyclic neutropenia

Other options: 

Option B: Leukocyte adhesion deficiency leads to defective neutrophil migration to sites of infection, peripheral neutrophilia, and recurrent infections without pus.

Option C: Chediak–Higashi syndrome is an autosomal-recessive disorder due to defects in lysosomal transport protein (LYST), leading to defective microtubule polymerization and defective phagolysosome formation. There is neutropenia and recurrent infections. 

Option D: Chronic granulomatous disease is due to a defect in NADPH oxidase resulting in the absence of respiratory burst. It presents with recurrent infections with catalase-positive microbes.

Related Pearl: Primary immunodeficiency disorders

Affected component of the immune system

Disorder

  • Common variable immunodeficiency
  • Selective immunoglobulin deficiency, such as IgA deficiency
  • Transient hypogammaglobulinemia of infancy
  • X-linked agammaglobulinemia

Cellular immunity: Problems with T cells 
  • Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis
  • DiGeorge syndrome
  • X-linked lymphoproliferative syndrome

Combined humoral and cellular immunity: Problems with B and T cells
  • Ataxia-telangiectasia
  • Hyperimmunoglobulinemia M syndrome
  • Severe combined immunodeficiency
  • Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome

  • Chronic granulomatous disease
  • Chédiak-Higashi syndrome (rare)
  • Tuftsin deficiency
  • Cyclic neutropenia
  • Leukocyte adhesion defects

Deficiency of complement proteins
  • Complement component 1 (C1) inhibitor deficiency (hereditary angioedema)
  • Terminal complement deficiency (C5-C9): Recurrent Neisseria infections

 

Related Pearl: Clinical features of DiGeorge syndrome- Mnemonic

DiGeorge syndrome is a cellular immunodeficiency disorder caused by the deletion of a small segment of chromosome 22 (22q11) leading to a developmental defect involving the endodermal derivatives of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches. (Thymus and parathyroid glands)

The clinical features can be remembered with the mnemonic – CATCH

  • C – Cardiac defects
  • A – Abnormal facies
  • T – Thymic aplasia
  • C – Cleft palate
  • H – Hypocalcemia

questions.text: Atezolizumab is not used in the treatment of which of the following malignancies?
questions.solution:
Atezolizumab is not used in the treatment of osteosarcoma.

Atezolizumab is a human IgG1 monoclonal antibody that inhibits the interaction of PD-L1 with PD-1 and B7-H1 and is active against the following:

  • Treatment-resistant metastatic non-small cell lung cancers
  • Locally advanced or metastatic urothelial cancer
  • Breast cancer
  • Colorectal cancers
  • Melanoma
  • Head and neck squamous cell carcinoma

Immune checkpoint inhibitors inhibit proteins that help the cancer cells to keep immune responses in check. When these proteins are blocked, the brake on the immune system is released and T cells are able to kill cancer cells more efficiently.

Other anti-PD-L1 antibodies are

  • Avelumab
  • Durvalumab

Durvalumab, Avelumab, and Atezolizumab are antagonists of PD-L1 which is a protein-ligand that is present on antigen-presenting cells, T cells, B cells, and some cancer cells.

Durvalumab is approved for use in metastatic urothelial cancer while Avelumab is for both metastatic urothelial cancer and Merkel cell cancer. 

The FDA approved Durvalumab in combination with etoposide and either carboplatin or cisplatin as first-line treatment of patients with extensive-stage small-cell lung cancer.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with a worsening headache for 8 months. A left sub frontal mass is resected. Microscopy is as seen below and tumor cells express progesterone receptors.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Microscopy shows a tumor with meningothelial whorls, syncytial cells with indistinct cell membranes and psammoma bodies. Most likely diagnosis is a meningioma.

Meningioma: They are predominantly benign tumors of adults, usually attached to the dura, that arise from the meningothelial cells of the arachnoid.

  • Meningiomas may be found along any of the external surfaces of the brain as well as within the ventricular system, where they arise from the stromal arachnoid cells of the choroid plexus.
  • Prior radiation therapy to the head and neck, typically is a risk factor.
  • The most common cytogenetic abnormality is loss of chromosome 22, especially the long arm (22q).
  • Meningiomas are a common lesion in the setting of NF2 (multiple sites, especially in association with acoustic neuromas or glial tumors.
  • The surface of the mass is usually encapsulated.
  • They may also grow en plaque, in which the tumor spreads in a sheetlike fashion along the surface of the dura. This form is commonly associated with hyperostotic reactive changes in the adjacent bone.
  • The lesions may contain numerous calcified psammoma bodies.

Histological subtypes:

  • WHO Grade I – Menigothelial, fibroblastic, transitional, psammomatous, secretory, microcystic
  • WHO Grade II- Clear cell, chordoid, atypical
  • Grade III – Papillary, rhabdoid, anaplastic
  • Atypical meningiomas (WHO grade II/IV) - a higher rate of recurrence and more aggressive local growth
  • Anaplastic (malignant) meningioma (WHO grade III/IV) - highly aggressive tumor with the appearance of a high-grade sarcoma
  • Immunoreactive for epithelial membrane antigen
  • Keratin is restricted to lesions with the secretory pattern, and these tumors are also positive for carcinoembryonic antigen
  • Moderate (3: 2) female predominance, usually solitary, but when present at multiple sites, the possibility of neurofibromatosis type 2 should be considered.
  • Meningiomas often express progesterone receptors and may grow more rapidly during pregnancy.

questions.text: You join a dedicated COVID health center where pediatric cases are prioritized and monitored on the basis of the patient's body temperature. A compilation of the temperature readings (in Celsius) of all the patients arranged in a meaningful order represents data in which of the following scales of measurement?
questions.solution:
The temperature readings (in celsius) of the patients represent interval scale data.

Similar to ordinal data, interval scale data can be placed in a meaningful order, but in addition, the items have meaningful intervals between them, which are usually measured quantities. In the given scenario, the temperatures of the patients can be arranged from high to low and the difference between the temperatures of each patient is quantifiable in measured quantities. This scale of measurement does not have an absolute zero; hence, the ratios of the scores are not meaningful.

All data can be measured in one of four scales—nominal, ordinal, interval, or ratio scale (mnemonic: NOIR).

Related Pearl: Scales of data measurement

Data can be quantitative (numerical values) or qualitative (types, labels).

Quantitative data can be discrete variables or continuous variables.

 

Description

Example

Discrete data

Can take certain values and none in between

Number of cancer patients in a hospital. 

Continuous data

Can take any value usually in between limits or a range. 

Most biomedical data is continuous.

Height, weight, blood pressure, etc.

 

Data always forms one of four scales of measurement – nominal, ordinal, interval, or ratio scales (mnemonic: NOIR):

 

Nominal Scale Data

Ordinal Scale Data

Interval Scale Data

Ratio Scale Data

Example

Male/female; red/green; sub-urban/rural

Students ranked 1st/2nd/3rd in their class. 

A customer feedback survey using terms like very good, good, poor and very poor or the Likert Scale.

Severity of a disease as mild, moderate, severe

 

 Measurements on the celsius scale. Pulse rate; 

Notes

Have no quantitative value.

They have no order or ratio. 

Arranged in a meaningful order.

No size interval is defined

Arranged in a meaningful order with a well defined size interval.

Example: Temperature in Celsius. If temperature in A is 40 deg Celsius and that in B is 20 deg Celsius, then A is 20 deg Celsius hotter than B (taking difference)

Does not have an absolute zero.

For example, Celsius scale has no such thing as “no temperature”. So the value cannot be zero.

Arranged in a meaningful order with a well defined size interval.

Eg: A pulse rate has well defined intervals and is meaningful in comparison. A 100/min pulse is exactly twice of 50 beats/min.

 

Has an absolute zero.

Eg: There can be a value of zero for pulse.

questions.text: Which of the following is the property of endothelin-I?
questions.solution:
Endothelin-1 is a potent vasoconstrictor.

They are produced by endothelial cells. They are secreted locally and act in a paracrine fashion.

Actions of Endothelin-1 (ET-1)

  • Platelet activation.
  • Inotropic effect.
  • Closure of ductus arteriosus.
  • Have a role in the pathogenesis of hypertension, myocardial infarction, and congestive heart failure.
  • In the brain, regulate the transport of substances across the blood-brain barrier (BBB).
  • In the kidneys, they are involved in tubuloglomerular feedback→ ↓ GFR.
  • In the lungs, it causes bronchoconstriction (mediated via ET-B receptors).
  • In GIT, they are involved in the migration of myenteric plexus to the distal colon (failure leads to Hirschsprung’s/megacolon).
  • Deletion of both alleles of ET-1 gene→craniofacial abnormalities and respiratory failure at birth.

questions.text: An exclusively breastfed newborn was brought with vomiting and diarrhea that developed since birth. On examination, the baby is jaundiced and has hepatomegaly. Blood glucose level was low and erythrocyte galactose-1-phosphate level was elevated. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of an exclusively breastfed infant with vomiting, diarrhea, jaundice, hypotonia, and hepatomegaly with elevated erythrocyte galactose-1-phosphate level is suggestive of classical galactosemia.

Classical galactosemia is an autosomal recessive disorder. The enzyme deficient here is galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase (GALT). Normally, newborns receive up to 40% of their calorie intake as lactose (glucose + galactose). Without GALT, the infant cannot metabolize galactose 1-phosphate, which accumulates and causes injury to the kidney, liver, and brain.

Clinical features include vomiting, hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, jaundice, congenital cataracts, aminoaciduria, and failure to thrive. There is an increased incidence of Escherichia coli neonatal sepsis. Long-term complications include speech delays, learning impairment, motor dysfunction, and hypogonadotropic hypogonadism (in females).

The presence of galactose in urine (positive Benedict's test), elevated blood galactose level, and elevated erythrocyte galactose-1-phosphate level help in confirming the diagnosis.

Treatment is a galactose-free diet. Supportive therapy and the prevention of complications are important.

Other options:

Option A: Fructosuria is due to the deficiency of fructokinase. There are no symptoms except for the benign excretion of fructose in urine.

Option B: von Gierke's disease is due to glucose-6-phosphatase or translocase deficiency. It is a glycogen storage disorder (Type I).  They may develop hypoglycemia and lactic acidosis in the neonatal period, but hepatomegaly usually develops at 3–4 months. They may have doll-like facies, short stature, and a protuberant abdomen. Hyperuricemia, the elevation of triglycerides, low-density lipoproteins, and phospholipids are seen.

Option D: Hereditary fructose intolerance is due to a deficiency of fructose 1, 6-bisphosphate aldolase (aldolase B). Patients are healthy and symptom-free until fructose or sucrose is ingested. Clinical manifestations may include jaundice, hepatomegaly, vomiting, lethargy, irritability, and convulsions. It will not be seen in newborns who are exclusively on breast milk.

questions.text: You are assisting a case of superficial parotidectomy as a junior resident. Your consultant asks you to identify the buccal branch of the facial nerve to trace back to the facial nerve trunk. Which of the following anatomical landmarks is used for the identification of the buccal branch of the facial nerve?
questions.solution:
The buccal branch of the facial nerve lies in relation to the parotid duct and is used as an anatomical landmark for the retrograde identification of the facial nerve trunk.

There are two methods for localization of the facial nerve trunk: 

1. Anterograde method: In this method, the facial nerve trunk is identified based on the anatomical landmarks after it exits from the stylomastoid foramen. They are then traced distally to arrive at the facial nerve trunk. The anatomical landmarks include:

  • Tragal pointer/Conley's pointer: It is the inferior portion of the cartilaginous canal. The facial nerve trunk lies 1 cm deep and inferior to its tip.
  • Posterior belly of digastric: The facial nerve lies superior to the upper border of the muscle. (Option D)
  • Squamotympanic fissure: It is a fissure in the temporal bone, which runs from TMJ to the tympanic cavity. The facial nerve runs through this fissure.
  • Styloid process: The facial nerve lies superficial to it. (Option B)
  • Mastoid process: Upon drilling it, the nerve is identified proximally.

2. Retrograde method: In this method, the main branches of the facial nerve trunk are identified and are then traced proximally until the main tunk is identified. Some of the main branches that are commonly used for tracing the facial nerve trunk include:

  • Buccal branch: It lies in relation to the parotid duct.
  • Marginal mandibular branch: It lies in relation to the facial vessels. (Option A)
  • Temporal branch

questions.text: A 22-year-old pregnant woman at 13 weeks of gestation informs you about accidental exposure to radiation from a chest X-ray at 7 weeks of gestation. What should be the next step advised to her?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical case, the patient should be advised to continue the pregnancy.

The radiation dose to the fetus during the declared term of pregnancy should be less than 1 mSv. In chest X-ray PA view, the absorbed dose of radiation by the fetus is less than 0.1 mSv. Hence, pregnancy can be continued.

An X-ray has a very limited role in obstetric imaging. There are very few indications where an X-ray will be useful: 

  • Fetal: congenital malformation of the fetus and neonates, skeletal malformations, birth injuries like fractures or dislocations.
  • Maternal:  Patients having cardiopulmonary disease may require an X-ray chest during pregnancy and that should be done beyond 12 weeks. 

Radiation can cause fetal morbidity (FGR, genetic mutations, neurologic abnormalities, mental retardation, childhood leukemia) and mortality. The risks are high with radiation after the first 2 weeks postconception and within the first trimester (period of organogenesis).

Radiation during pregnancy can damage the early phase of the embryo but the risk can be minimized by using the ‘10-day rule’. This rule states that no woman should be exposed to an X-ray for a nonurgent indication outside 10 days from her last period during the reproductive period unless the pregnancy is excluded.

questions.text: A 34-year-old farmer presents with complaints of shortness of breath and productive cough with orange mucus plugs for the past 2-3 weeks. His symptoms began after exposure to plant waste. He has a history of bronchial asthma and examination revealed rhonchi. Chest X-ray of the patient is shown in the image below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the chest X-ray showing the finger-in-glove appearance are suggestive of allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA).

Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis is a hypersensitivity reaction involving the major airways. It is most commonly seen in patients with longstanding asthma. It can also be associated with cystic fibrosis. The condition is diagnosed in younger patients usually before 40 years of age. The patient typically presents with atopic symptoms. Sometimes expectorant cough with orange mucus plugs may be seen.

Radiographic findings in ABPA include:

  • Lobar collapse
  • Non-segmental areas of opacities commonly involving the upper lobe
  • Branching thick tubular opacities due to distended bronchi filled with fungus and mucus - Finger-in-glove appearance 
  • Pulmonary cavitation is rarely seen

Other features of aspergillus infection:

Aspergilloma: Aspergillomas are mass-like fungus balls that are typically composed of Aspergillus fumigatus and are a non-invasive form of pulmonary aspergillosis. Aspergillomas occur in patients with normal immunity but structurally abnormal lungs, with pre-existing cavities. The most common underlying condition is pulmonary tuberculosis. Radiographic findings of aspergilloma include:

  • Air crescent sign - The fungal ball can be seen on both plain film and CT as an intracavitary mass surrounded by a crescent of air.
  • The mass usually moves within the cavity when the patient moves and this sign is called the Monod sign.

Angioinvasive aspergillosis: It is seen in immunocompromised individuals, especially in patients with neutropenia. Halo sign is the typical CT finding in these patients.

  • The halo sign in chest imaging is a feature seen on HRCT where ground glass opacity surrounds a pulmonary nodule or mass and represents hemorrhage.

Other options:

Option A- Bronchiectasis is characterized by local and irreversible dilatation of bronchi. Radiographic findings are:

  • Tramline appearance is seen in chest X-rays.
  • Ring or curvilinear opacities on end-on appearance.
  • CT shows bronchial dilatation and lack of tapering of bronchial lumen. It is the cardinal sign.
  • Signet ring sign - Internal diameter of the bronchi is greater than the adjacent pulmonary artery.

Option B- Blastomycosis is a chronic infection, characterized by the formation of suppurative and granulomatous lesions, especially in the lungs and skin. The pulmonary disease resembles TB or histoplasmosis. There can be focal or diffuse consolidation, miliary lesions, or abscess formation.

 

Option C- Pulmonary tuberculosis chest radiograph typically shows upper lobe infiltrates with cavities. In immunocompromised individuals like in HIV patients, there can be lower zone infiltrates without cavity formation. In disseminated TB miliary reticulonodular patterns may be seen.

questions.text: Identify the given instrument shown below.
questions.solution:
The given instrument is a cortical screw.

Identification points for the screws are:

  • Cortical screw: Threaded whole length, smaller thread, low pitch, compression produced by over drilling proximal cortex
  • Cancellous screw: Larger thread, high pitch, compression by partial threading with a blunt tip
  • Malleolar screw: Modified cancellous screw with a sharp-pointed tip

Most orthopedic implants are made of titanium-based alloys because they are highly resistant to corrosion.

questions.text: A professional boxer has suffered multiple concussions in his boxing career. Which of the following pathological findings of the brain is most likely present in this person?
questions.solution:
Parenchymal injury of the brain as a result of multiple concussions can result in pathological plaque jaune lesions.

Plaque jaune lesions are depressed, retracted, yellowish-brown patches involving the crests of gyri. They occur as a result of traumatic injury to the brain. These lesions are commonly located at the sites of contrecoup injuries. They commonly involve the inferior frontal cortices and temporal & occipital poles. These lesions can become epileptic foci. 

Other options:

Option B: Microglial nodules are aggregations of microglial cells around areas of necrosis of grey and white matter. They are seen in viral encephalitis.

Option C: Red neurons are associated with acute ischaemic/hypoxic neuronal injury. They are characterized by a shrunken cell body, pyknosis of the nucleus, and the disappearance of the nucleolus with intense eosinophilia of the cytoplasm.

Option D: Shadow plaques are lesions found in multiple sclerosis where the border between normal and affected white matter isn't sharply circumscribed.

questions.text:
Match the following antenatal USG findings and the associated conditions:
USG finding Associated condition
1) Banana sign a) Intrauterine death
2) Spalding sign b) Spina bifida
3) Frog-eye sign c) Normal gestation
4) Double decidual sac sign d) Anencephaly
questions.solution:
The correct option is 1-b,2-a,3-d,4-c

Banana sign - Spina bifida

Spalding sign - Intrauterine death

Frog-eye sign - Anencephaly

Double decidual sac sign - Normal gestation

Banana sign - Anterior curvature of cerebellum along with effacement of cisterna magna produces this appearance. Seen in spina bifida associated with Arnold-Chiari malformation.

Frog eye or Mickey Mouse appearance: It is seen in Anencephaly, which is the absence of cranial bones with exposed rudimentary brain tissue. This finding is when seen in the coronal plane due to absent cranial bone/brain and bulging orbits.

Spalding sign - It is a sign of intrauterine death. It is the irregular overlapping of the skull bones on one another. It is due to the liquefaction of brain matter and softening of ligamentous structures supporting the skull. Usually seen 7 days after death.

Double decidual sac sign: Normal Ultrasonographic appearance of an intrauterine gestational sac. Seen as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: A 40-year-old diabetic patient was prescribed sildenafil for his erectile dysfunction. Following this, he develops a blurring of vision and complains that things seem to appear with a bluish-green hue. Inhibition of which of the following enzymes is likely to have caused his visual side effects?
questions.solution:
Visual disturbance seen with sildenafil is due to PDE-6 inhibition.

Sildenafil is used for the treatment of erectile dysfunction principally due to its inhibitory actions on PDE-5 (Phosphodiesterase 5) in the vascular tissues of the corpus cavernosa. However, it also exerts minor inhibitory action against PDE-6, which is present exclusively in rod and cone photoreceptors and results in blurring and blue-green tinting of vision.

Tadalafil and avanafil have better PDE-5/PDE-6 selectivity, compared to sildenafil and vardenafil and hence have lesser visual side effects.

questions.text: A 57-year-old male patient presented with sudden-onset bilateral lower extremity weakness, back pain, saddle anesthesia, urinary retention, and loss of bowel function. Cranial nerve functions and upper-limb neurological functions are normal. Motor strength in the lower limbs is grade 4 on both sides. Sensation was diminished to light touch in the T12-S3 dermatome bilaterally. There is no loss of pain or temperature sensation. Ankle reflex is lost, but knee reflex is intact. Bilateral Babinski's reflex and diminished rectal tone were present. Which of the following is the most likely cause for this patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical presentation and history are suggestive of conus medullaris syndrome secondary to a compressive tumor (spinal metastasis from lung cancer).

The conus medullaris is the tapered caudal termination of the spinal cord, comprising the sacral and single coccygeal segments.
The conus medullaris syndrome consists of
  • Symmetrical loss of sensation in the perianal region (bilateral saddle anesthesia) (S3-S5)
  • Prominent bladder and bowel dysfunction (early onset urinary retention and incontinence with lax anal tone)
  • Impotence
  • Absent bulbocavernosus (S2-S4) and anal (S4-S5) reflexes 
  • Largely preserved muscle strength
  • Loss of ankle reflex (S1)
  • Knee reflex usually preserved (L3-L4)  

Conus medullaris syndrome presents more acutely than cauda equina syndrome. 

Other options:

Option A- Central cord syndrome results due to damage to the gray matter nerve cells and crossing the spinothalamic tract around the central canal. Involvement of the spinothalamic tract results in loss of pain and temperature sensation which is not seen in this patient. It presents as arm and leg weakness, and dissociated sensory loss i.e. pain and temperature are lost whereas light touch, joint position, and vibration sense are intact. Important causes are spinal trauma, syringomyelia, and intrinsic cord tumors.

Option B- Compression of the lumbosacral nerve roots below the level of termination of the spinal cord that is L1-L2 results in cauda-equina syndrome. Common causes of cauda equina syndrome include ruptured lumbosacral intervertebral disc, epidural hematoma, vertebral fracture, and compressive tumor. Low back pain, asymmetrical loss of sensation, asymmetrical weakness, variable areflexia, saddle anesthesia (loss of sensation in the buttocks and perineal region) are common presenting symptoms. Relative sparing of bowel and bladder functions with late-onset retention symptoms is seen.

Option D: Brown-Sequard syndrome is a hemi-transection of the spinal cord. It presents with ipsilateral weakness (corticospinal tract), ipsilateral loss of position, and vibration sense (posterior column), and contralateral loss of pain and temperature one or two levels below the lesion.

Note: Mass lesions in the lower spinal canal often produce a mixed clinical picture with elements of both cauda equina and conus medullaris syndromes.

questions.text: A  patient comes with complaints of fever, cough with foul-smelling sputum, and night sweats. She reported having undergone a tooth extraction a few days ago. On examination, clubbing is seen and cavernous breath sounds are heard over the right lung.  Her chest X-ray is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diganosis is lung abscess. 

The clinical points in the question pointing to this diagnosis are: 

  • History of fever, cough with foul-smelling discharge and night sweats
  • History of tooth extraction pointing towards the possibility of aspiration
  • Clubbing and cavernous breath sounds are heard over the right lung
  • Chest X-ray image showing a thick-walled cavity with air-fluid level

Lung abscess represents necrosis and cavitation of the lung following microbial infection. They are broadly divided into two categories:

  • Primary lung abscess usually occurs in the abscence of any underlying systemic or pulmonary condition. They usually occur in the posterior upper lobes and superior lower lobes of the lungs. The right lung is more commonly involved because of less angulated right mainstem bronchus. They are polymicrobial in nature including anaerobes and microaerophilic streptococci. Aspiration is a major risk factor (hence alcoholic patients are at higher risk).
  • Secondary lung abscess usually occurs in the presence of an underlying lung or systemic condition. The location of the abscess varies with the underlying condition. Generally they occur due to a broad bacterial spectrum including Pseudomonas aeruginosa and other gram-negative rods.

Clinical features include fever, night sweats, productive cough with foul-smelling sputum, and chest pain. 

Physical examination usually reveals poor dentition/gingival disease, digital clubbing, and absence of a gag reflex. Amphoric and/or cavernous breath sounds can be heard during auscultation.

Chest X-ray features of lung abscess:

  • A lung cavity with an air-fluid level
  • Thick and irregular cavity wall and a surrounding pulmonary-infiltrate

Computed tomography (CT) is more sensitive than chest radiography and is used to detect small cavities.

Clindamycin, or amoxicillin-clavulanate, or moxifloxacin can be administered for primary lung abscesses. Antibiotics for secondary lung abscesses are prescribed according to the pathogen identified. The treatment is usually prolonged until the resolution of the abscess is achieved. 

The two radiograph images given below show thick-walled cavities with air-fluid levels on lateral and PA views respectively.

questions.text: A lady brings her son to you, complaining that the child walks in his sleep every night and always seems confused after waking up. He has no recollection of these events. What is the peak age group in which this disorder occurs?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points towards a diagnosis of somnambulism (sleep walking), and the peak prevalence is between 4-8 years of age.

Somnambulism is a disorder of sleep arousal in which an individual arises from bed and carries out simple to complex motor activities without full consciousness. It occurs in the NREM phase of sleep. 

It is more commonly seen in children, with peak prevalence being between ages 4 to 8 years. It usually resolves after adolescence. It is rarely seen in adults, and has a familial pattern. It may occur secondary to other sleep disorders like sleep apnea. Sleep deprivation, interruption of slow-wave sleep, alcohol consumption, and stress can exacerbate the condition.

During an episode of sleepwalking, the individual may sit up, attempt to walk, or perform semi purposeful actions. They have a blank expression and are unresponsive to communication. Waking them up is possible only with great difficulty.

During the episode, patients can interact with the environment successfully (e.g., avoiding tripping over objects), but can also harm themselves (e.g., walking into the road). Legally, somnambulism is considered a form of automation, and hence doctrine of diminished responsibility applies. Hence, the person is not criminally responsible for his acts carried out during a fit.

Forms of somnambulism include:

  • Sleep-related eating - the individual may ingest food during the episode.
  • Sleep-related sexual behavior (sexsomnia) - the individual may engage in sexual activities during the episode

Management:

  • Reassurance
  • Maintaining patient safety during episodes
  • Avoiding sleep deprivation and alcohol consumption before going to bed
  • Antidepressants, relaxation techniques and hypnosis may also be helpful.

questions.text: You treat a patient suffering from Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma with IV cyclophosphamide. The drug is present in a vial in powdered form. choices.text: The glass vial is to be discarded in puncture proof blue box

Discard the plastic saline bottle in non-chlorinated yellow plastic bag

questions.solution:
Cyclophosphamide is a cytotoxic drug. All cytotoxic drugs and items contaminated by it (including glass vials, ampoules, saline bottles) should be collected in yellow-colored non-chlorinated plastic bags labeled as cytotoxic hazard.

Option B: Mask and gowns (biochemical waste) which are reusable should be discarded in yellow-colored non-chlorinated plastic bags.

questions.text: A Brazilian tourist who has traveled to India on vacation presents with lesions on his chest and back. The lesions are shown below. On examination, no oral or mucosal lesions are found. Acantholytic cells are seen on the Tzanck smear. A histopathological sample is sent for further examination. Which type of blister is present in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the lesions seen in a Brazilian patient and acantholysis on Tzanck smear, without oral or mucosal lesions is highly suggestive of pemphigus foliaceus. It is characterized by a subcorneal blister.

Pemphigus foliaceus is a benign form of pemphigus, an inflammatory blistering disorder, that is endemic in Brazil and occurs sporadically in other geographic regions. This is a form of a subcorneal blister, where the stratum corneum forms the roof of the bulla. It is caused by autoantibodies that result in the dissolution of intercellular attachments within the epidermis. There is no involvement of the mucosal epithelium in pemphigus foliaceus but is rarely affected.

Lesions are most common on the scalp, face, chest, and back. Bullae are superficial and mainly present as areas of erythema and crusting. These represent superficial erosions at sites of blister rupture.

Other options:

Suprabasal blisters: A portion of the epidermis, including the stratum corneum, forms the roof. They are seen in conditions such as pemphigus vulgaris.

Subepidermal blisters: The entire epidermis separates from the dermis. They are seen in conditions such as bullous pemphigoid.

Junctional blisters: These are blisters at the basal lamina. This type of blister is seen in conditions such as junctional epidermolysis bullosa, bullous pemphigoid, and toxic epidermal necrolysis.

questions.text: A young non-obese patient presented with increased fatigue for several months. Two of his relatives have a history of early-onset diabetes. Investigations revealed high blood glucose and low serum insulin levels. Urine ketones and islet autoantibodies were negative.  There was an improvement after 2 weeks of glimepiride. Which of the following is incorrect regarding this condition?

choices.text: It responds to all oral hypoglycemic agents
It is associated with cystic kidney disease

questions.solution:
This patient is likely to have maturity-onset diabetes of the young (MODY). It responds only to sulphonylureas (glimepiride, glipizide), not all oral hypoglycemic agents.

The clinical vignette describes a young non-obese patient with a positive family history of diabetes. Features of reduced insulin level with no antibodies, negative urinary ketones, and a good response to a sulphonylurea drug (glimepiride) rule out the possibility of Type 1 diabetes mellitus.

MODY is a monogenic disorder inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion. It is generally inherited at the age of 25 years or younger. Patients are generally not obese. The pathophysiology of this condition involves impaired glucose-induced secretion of insulin. 

There are six types of MODY. However, type 3 is the most common. Types 1, 3 and 5 occur due to mutations in the hepatic nuclear factor. Type 2 occurs due to a mutation in the glucokinase gene and type 4 occurs due to mutations in pancreatic and duodenal homeobox 1. MODY type 5 is associated with renal cysts.

Patients usually respond to therapy with sulfonylureas but eventually require insulin as a result of beta-cell failure.

questions.text: A senior resident asks you to incise and drain the abscess in a 20-year-old student during your surgery postings. Which of the following blades you would use for this procedure?
questions.solution:
The blade marked as '2' in the image, represents the 11 size-blade which is often used to incise and drain the abscess.

Uses:

  • Commonly used to incise skin, subcutaneous tissue, deep fascia to open the abscess cavity in a single stroke, during  I & D of an abscess.

questions.text: A 38-year old lady in her 6th week of gestation is concerned about Down's syndrome and enquires about noninvasive prenatal testing. When is the earliest that the test can be undertaken?
questions.solution:
Non-Invasive Prenatal Testing (NIPT) can be done any time after 9-10 weeks, after which it is not dependent on the gestational age.

NIPT is used for the screening of Trisomy 13, 18, 21, and Turner's syndrome. It is not a diagnostic test. It is a novel genetic test that uses cell-free circulating fetal DNA in the maternal serum for screening of chromosomal anomalies.

DNA from the fetus is found circulating in the maternal blood in two forms, either inside the intact fetal cells or as cell-free DNA from the breakdown of placental fetal cells.

In NIPT, the cell-free chromosome fragments are measured. A fetus with aneuploidy will have a significantly larger number of abnormal DNA fragments than a normal fetus.

NIPT can be performed after 9-10 weeks of gestation. It is recommended after the routine first-trimester ultrasound assessment. The American College of Obstetrics and Gynaecology advises the use of NIPT for pregnancies with a high risk of fetal autosomal trisomy. The following categories are included:

  • Women >35 years at delivery
  • A positive first- or second-trimester analyte-based screening test
  • Sonogram with a minor aneuploidy marker
  • Prior pregnancy with autosomal trisomy
  • The patient or partner are known carriers of a balanced robertso­nian translocation involving chromosome 21 or 13.

Its disadvantage is that it is very costly and it can be used for screening of chromosomes 13, 18, 21, and Turner's syndrome only. Other atypical chromosomal abnormalities can be missed on NIPT.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient suffered a head injury due to a road traffic accident. He couldn't talk and made some sounds. He opens his eyes to painful stimuli and localizes it. What is the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score for this patient?
questions.solution:
For the given scenario, the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score is 9.

To arrive at this the following clinical points have to be considered:

  • The patient is able to open his eyes to painful stimuli - Eye response = 2

  • The patient is able to localize a painful stimulus - Motor response = 5

questions.text: A 38-year-old male patient presents to the OPD for evaluation of low backache. The patient gives a history that he also feels pain in the back of the leg and at the ankles. On examination there is decreased sensation in the ankle region and ankle jerk reflex is diminished. The test shown in the image is positive. Which of the following is not an absolute indication for surgical management in this patient?

choices.text: Marked progressive weakness of the muscles

questions.solution:
The clinical features and a positive straight leg raising test as shown in the image are suggestive of an intervertebral disc prolapse involving L5-S1 nerve root. Recurrent episodes of severe sciatica is only a relative indication for surgical management.

Indications for surgical management: 

Absolute indications:

  • Failed conservative management.
  • Marked progressive weakness of muscles.
  • Progressive neurological deficit.
  • Cauda equina paralysis.

Relative Indications:

  • Recurrent episodes of incapacitating sciatica
  • Pain unrelieved by complete rest from activity.

Intervertebral disc prolapse

Features of IVDP pain:

  • Pain is increased by flexion episodes, sneezing, coughing, straining, and sitting. 
  • Pain is decreased by rest and in the semi-Fowler position. Semi-Fowler position is lying in a bed supine with the head of the bed raised at approximately 30 to 45 degrees.
  • Leg pain equal to or more than the back pain in IVDP cases is evidence of involvement of the nerve root due to the herniated disc.

Important tests for diagnosis:

1. Straight Leg Raising Test (SLRT) or Lasegue sign

This is done to assess nerve root irritation in the lumbosacral area.  The patient is made to lie on the back with the head extended, with hips and legs in the neutral position. The affected leg is then passively and slowly raised by the ankle with the knee fully extended. The examiner stops further leg elevation when pain is elicited. Normally it should be possible to raise the limb to 80–90 degrees. The SLRT test is positive if the patient develops pain when the leg is between 30 and 60/70 degrees from horizontal. The pain should be radicular type and radiating to the back of the thigh or to the calf.

 

2. Bragard test (or Sciatic stretch test or Flip test)

Perform SLRT. At the point where the patient experiences discomfort, the leg is lowered a little. The stretching and pain become less. At this angle, the ankle is passively dorsiflexed. If the pain at the back of the thigh or in the calf is felt again, the test is positive. This is also called reinforcement positive or Bragard’s sign positive

 

3. Crossed SLRT (or well-leg raising test or Fajersztajn sign)

When SLRT is performed on the unaffected side, the patient may feel pain on the affected side. This is termed a contralateral positive SLRT or crossed SLRT positive. It is a very specific sign of root compression. It becomes positive usually when there is severe compression due to a centrally located prolapse.

4. Bowstring sign (or popliteal compression test)

The ‘bowstring sign’ is even more specific for disc prolapse than SLRT. Perform SLRT until the patient experiences sciatic pain. Without reducing the amount of lift, bend the knee so as to relax the sciatic nerve (Buckling sign). Buttock pain is immediately relieved. The examiner then presses the popliteal fossa to stretch the lateral popliteal nerve behind the lateral tibial condyle. This will tighten the nerve like a bowstring and re-induce the pain.

 

5. Femoral stretch (reverse Lasegue test or Mackiewicz sign)

The patient lies prone. The examiner flexes the knee to the thigh and the hip is passively extended. The test is positive if the patient experiences anterior thigh pain. This test is usually positive for L2-L3 and L3-L4 (high lumbar) protrusions

 

Treatment:

Conservative:

  • Continuous bed rest and traction for 2 weeks will reduce the herniation in over 90% of cases.
  • Back exercises and posture correction are also a part of conservative management
  • Epidural steroids

Surgical: Surgical procedures include laminectomy, hemilaminectomy, fenestration surgery, and microscopic & endoscopic lumbar discectomy.

questions.text:
Identify the correct sequence of doffing the PPE kit.
  1. Remove outer gloves and perform hand hygiene.
  2. Remove shoe covers only by touching the other surface and perform hand hygiene.
  3. Remove eyepiece by holding the straps and perform hand hygiene.
  4. Remove gown slowly by holding the gown at the waist and pulling, without touching the outer surface.
  5. Remove inner gloves and perform hand hygiene.
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of doffing (removing) the PPE kit is 2, 1, 3, 4, 5.

Preparation for doffing the PPE:

  • To be performed only in the designated area
  • Check for any leak or soiling
  • The doffing room should have two chairs, dirty and clean
  • All the PPE must be discarded in the red bin
  • Hand hygiene must be performed after every step

Steps of doffing the PPE:

  • Engage the observer and ask him to check the PPE - observer should check for any leak, tear, or contamination of PPE. If contaminated, then it should be disinfected with alcohol-based wipes.
  • Disinfect the gloves
  • Remove and discard shoe covers
  • Disinfect and remove the outer pair of gloves
  • Disinfect inner gloves
  • Remove face shield/eye goggle - loosen the screw and remove the face shield by holding it from the back handle. Discard it.
  • Remove hood and cover all (gown)
    • Holding the suit at the arms, slide it off the shoulder slightly, then pull the suit from the side of the waist
    • Roll the arms out one by one
  • Disinfect and remove inner gloves
  • Perform hand hygiene and wear a new pair of gloves
  • Remove and discard N-95 mask
  • Disinfect gloves
  • Sit on the clean chair and disinfect shoes using alcohol wipes
  • Disinfect and remove gloves
  • Perform hand hygiene
  • Wipe the shoes on the sodium hypochlorite soaked doormat at the exit
  • Exit the doffing area and take a shower

questions.text: A man comes to the dermatology OPD with the following lesion. Further probing reveals a history of tuberculosis in his wife. Which of the following statements is false about this skin lesion?

choices.text: It occurs in previously sensitised patients
It is the most common cutaneous manifestation of TB in India

questions.solution:
This clinical scenario with a history of exposure to tuberculosis is suggestive of lupus vulgaris, which often presents as atrophic warty plaques. It is a paucibacillary lesion.

It occurs in previously sensitized hosts with good immunity. On histology, granulomas with scanty or absent caseation are seen.

It is the most common cutaneous tuberculosis in India. In India, it commonly occurs over the buttocks or the trunk, whereas, in Europe, it is common over the head and neck.

The lesions occur in the form of plaques with serpiginous edges or mutilating ulcers. They heal with central scarring.
