questions.text: Which of the following images represent Pomeroy's procedure of sterilization?
questions.solution:
Pomeroy's procedure is represented by image 1. In this method the fallopian tube is identified on each side, brought out through the incision, and the middle portion is formed into a loop which is tied at the base with catgut and excised. It is surgically reversible.

Methods of Female sterilization:

Laparotomy/Minilaparotomy:

Madlener's procedure (Image 2):. A loop of the fallopian tube is crushed and then ligated with a nonabsorbable suture.

Irving's procedure (Image 3): The mid-portion of the tube is ligated and the intervening portion excised. The proximal end is buried in the myometrium and the distal end is buried in the broad ligament. It is a reliable method but irreversible and may require a laparotomy incision.

Kroener's technique (Image 4): It refers to fimbriectomy done by ligating the distal ampulla of the tube with two permanent sutures followed by division and removal of the infundibulum. It is irreversible.

Uchida's method: The tubal serosa is stripped off the muscular layer in the midsegment of the tube, which is then excised. The proximal end is ligated and buried in the broad ligament. The minimal excision of the tube preserves the potential for tuboplasty.

Aldridge method: A hole is made in the anterior leaf of the broad ligament and the fimbrial end is buried into this.

  • Laparoscopic techniques: 
    • Each fallopian tube is picked up near the isthmic end (2–3 cm away) and clipped or banded with silastic bands, Filshie clips, Hulka band, or falope silastic rings. It is a reversible technique.
  • Hysteroscopic sterilization with the Essure permanent device: It is made of a flexible stainless steel inner coil and a nickel-titanium outer coil (nitinol). Polyethylene terephthalate (PET) in the inner coil causes a benign local fibrous tissue growth that occludes the fallopian tube. It takes 3 months to occlude the tube, confirmed with hysterosalpingography. During this period of 3 months, other methods of contraception should be used. It is an irreversible technique.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presented with a history of diffuse thyroid swelling for the past 2 months. Investigations show increased T3 and T4 levels and the presence of thyroid peroxidase antibodies. She undergoes fine needle aspiration cytology which is shown in the image below. Which of the following findings are seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Hashitoxicosis, a transient phase of thyrotoxicosis that usually occurs in the first two months of Hashimoto thyroiditis, and Hürthle cells are seen in fine-needle aspiration in this condition.

Hashimoto thyroiditis is an autoimmune disease characterized by the gradual destruction of the thyroid gland leading to thyroid failure. It is more commonly seen in females between 45 to 65 years of age. In the majority of cases, it is caused by the presence of circulating autoantibodies against thyroglobulin and thyroid peroxidase.

Morphologically, there is a diffuse and symmetrical enlargement of the thyroid gland, with an intact capsule. Microscopic features include:

  • Extensive lymphocytic infiltrate containing small lymphocytes, plasma cells, and well-developed germinal centers
  • Hürthle cells, are epithelial cells that line atrophied thyroid follicles and contain eosinophilic granular cytoplasm

The image below shows a histopathological picture of Hashimoto's thyroiditis:

In most cases, there is a gradual development of hypothyroidism. However, in some patients, transient thyrotoxicosis may occur due to the release of thyroid hormones from disrupted thyroid follicles known as hashitoxicosis. Free T4 and T3 levels are elevated and TSH and radioactive iodine uptake are decreased in this phase. As hypothyroidism occurs, T4 and T3 levels fall, and TSH increases. Patients are also more susceptible to developing other autoimmune diseases like type 1 diabetes and systemic lupus erythematosus.  

Other options:

Options B and C: Orphan Annie Eye nuclei (nuclei with finely dispersed chromatin and a ground-glass appearance) and pseudo-inclusions (nuclear membrane grooves) are characteristic of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid, which is the most common form of thyroid cancer. Other histological hallmarks include branching papillae covered by a single to multiple layers of cuboidal epithelial cell and psammoma bodies (concentrically calcified structures within the papillae). This type of cancer has an excellent prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate in 95% of cases.

Option D. Multinucleate giant cells are found in granulomatous thyroiditis. Granulomatous thyroiditis, also known as De Quervain thyroiditis, occurs due to viral infection, most often upper respiratory tract infection. The virus destroys thyroid follicles, inciting cytotoxic T lymphocyte reaction against the thyroid antigens. Thyroid pain is the most common symptom. In some cases, there may be transient thyrotoxicosis lasting for 2-6 weeks. Normal function returns after recovery.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient who is a known hypertensive comes to the medicine OPD for a regular check-up. He complains of always being anxious. On examination, his BMI is 29 and his BP is 180/100 mmHg. His blood workup shows Hb - 18 g%, and hematocrit - 60%. What condition does the patient most likely have?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette showing increased haemoglobin and hematocrit values in an obese, hypertensive and anxious person is highly suggestive of Stress polycythemia or Gaisböck syndrome.

Polycythemia denotes an abnormally high red cell count, usually with a corresponding increase in the haemoglobin level. It may be relative when there is hemoconcentration due to decreased plasma volume, or absolute when there is an increase in the total red cell mass.

Relative polycythemia:

Relative polycythemia results from dehydration, such as occurs with deprivation of water, prolonged vomiting or diarrhoea, or excessive use of diuretics. It is also associated with an obscure condition of unknown aetiology called stress polycythemia, or Gaisböck syndrome. Affected individuals are usually hypertensive, obese, and anxious (“stressed”). In this case there is normal RBC mass but a relative decrease in plasma volume.

Absolute polycythemia:

Absolute polycythemia is primary when it results from an intrinsic abnormality of hematopoietic precursors and secondary when the red cell progenitors are responding to increased levels of erythropoietin.

  • Primary: The most common cause of primary polycythemia is polycythemia vera, a myeloproliferative disorder associated with mutations that lead to erythropoietin-independent growth of red cell progenitors. Much less commonly, primary polycythemia results from familial mutations in the erythropoietin receptor that induce erythropoietin-independent receptor activation.
  • Secondary polycythemia: It may be caused by compensatory or pathologic increases in erythropoietin secretion. Causes of the latter include erythropoietin-secreting tumours and rare, but illustrative inherited defects that lead to the stabilization of HIF-1α, a hypoxia-induced factor that stimulates the transcription of the erythropoietin gene.

questions.text: You are a microbiologist examining a water sample brought to you by the municipal corporation. They suspect fecal contamination of the source of drinking water. The sole presence of which of the following organisms indicates that the contamination was not recent?
questions.solution:
The presence of Clostridium perfringens alone, in the absence of the coliform group, in a water sample suggests that the contamination is not recent.

Clostridium perfringens occur in faeces in much smaller numbers than E. coli. The spores of this organism are capable of surviving in water for a longer time than organisms of the coliform group and resist chlorination at the doses normally used to disinfect.

Detection of Clostridium perfringens can be done using varying quantities of the water samples, incubated in a litmus milk medium (anaerobically) at 37°C for five days. The presence of 'stormy clot' formation indicates the presence of Clostridium perfringens.

Presumptive coliform count

  • The basis of the presumptive coliform test is the inoculation of the water to be tested into tubes containing a suitable liquid medium, which are then incubated and examined after the appropriate time.
  • The test is called presumptive because the reaction observed in the tube may occasionally be due to the presence of some other organism or combination of organisms, and the presumption that the reaction is due to coliform organisms has to be confirmed.
  • The proportion of false-positive reactions obtained depends both on the bacterial flora of the water under examination and on the medium used.
  • Lactose broth, or MacConkey's broth, with bromocresol purple 25 as an indicator and a standardized concentration of bile salts incubated between 35°C–37°C for 48 hours, seems to be the most suitable media for presumptive tests.

Following this, the Eijkman test is done to confirm the presence of E. coli. They can grow at 44°C (faecal thermotolerant bacilli), ferment lactose and cause indole and gas production.

Differential coliform count/ Eijkman test:

Methodology: Following the presumptive test, subcultures are made from all the bottles showing acid and gas to fresh tubes of single-strength Mac Conkey medium pre-warmed to 37 degrees Celsius. These tubes are incubated at 44 degrees Celcius and examined after 24 hours.

Interpretation: 

  1. Tubes exhibiting gas in Durham's tubes are deemed to contain E.Coli.
  2. From the number of positive tubes obtained, the number of E.coli bacteria present in the water sample tested can be estimated by referring to Mc cardy's probability tables.
  3. The presence of E.coli can be further confirmed by testing for indole production and citrate utilisation.

Classification of the quality of drinking water based on bacteriological tests :

  Presumptive coliform count/100ml E.coli count/100ml
Class I - Excellent 0 0
Class II - Satisfactory 1-3 0
Class III - Suspicious 4-10 0
Class IV - Unsatisfactory >10 0.1 or more

Other options:

Option A: Recent faecal contamination of water is suggested by the presence of enterococcus (faecal streptococci).

Option C: If Escherichia coli is detected, it is definitive proof of faecal contamination. However, it is non-specific for suggesting the duration of the contamination.

Option D: Bacteroides species are present in faeces but do not play a significant role in testing and sampling for faecal pollution of water.

questions.text:
A patient presents with complaints of easy fatiguability, weakness, and joint pain. On further questioning, he says that he was diagnosed with gastroesophageal reflux disease 1 year back and is on treatment for the same since then. His blood work results are given below. The presenting features of this patient are caused by the adverse effect of which of the following drugs?
  • Hemoglobin - 10.5 gm/dL
  • Total leukocyte count- 7.6 x 103 /microL
  • Platelets - 350000 /microL
  • RBC - 3.23 x 106 /microL
  • Peripheral smear: Macrocytic anemia with hypersegmented neutrophils.
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of an adverse effect of chronic treatment with omeprazole. It is associated with decreased vitamin B12 absorption, thus leading to megaloblastic anemia in this patient.

Other side effects of using proton-pump inhibitors (PPI) for long-term care include the following: 

  • Increased susceptibility to infections like hospital-acquired pneumonia and Clostridium difficile infection (pseudomembranous enterocolitis). 
  • Increased risk of bone fracture due to reduced calcium absorption.
  • It is also associated with the risk of spontaneous bacterial peritonitis in patients with ascites. 

Omeprazole serves as both substrate and inhibitor for CYP2C19. Thus, omeprazole may inhibit the activation of clopidogrel and decrease its antiplatelet action.

Other options:

Option A: Misoprostol produces diarrhea, with or without cramps. It can also cause clinical exacerbations of inflammatory bowel disease.

Option B: The most common side effect of sucralfate is constipation. It should be avoided in patients with renal failure who are at risk of aluminum overload.

Option D: H2 receptor antagonists like cimetidine produces side effects like diarrhea, headache, drowsiness, fatigue, muscular pain, constipation, and gynecomastia.

questions.text: A young patient was found to have triglyceride levels of 600 mg/ dL. His LDL levels are slightly lower than normal and HDL levels are reduced. His mother too has elevated triglycerides with reduced levels of LDL and HDL cholesterol. The patient appears healthy, has a normal BMI, and has no history of coronary heart disease in his family. Which of the following drugs will be beneficial for this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the patient has elevated levels of triglycerides with low levels of LDL and HDL cholesterol. This pattern is also seen in his mother. Therefore, it is most likely to be familial hypertriglyceridemia. Since the patient does not have risk factors for coronary heart disease, fenofibrate will be beneficial in reducing triglyceride levels.

Familial hypertriglyceridemia occurs due to a defect in the lipolysis of the triglyceride-rich lipoproteins (TRLs). As a result of this, the levels of fasting triglyceride levels are elevated. Plasma LDL levels are reduced due to the defective conversion of triglyceride-rich lipoproteins to LDL. Identification of hypertriglyceridemia in first-degree relatives helps in the diagnosis.

Hypertriglyceridemia can also be secondary due to intake of simple carbohydrates, obesity, insulin resistance, alcohol use, and estrogen treatment.

Initial management involves exercise and dietary management (restriction of fatty food, avoidance of alcohol, estrogen-containing medications, etc)

If the levels of the triglycerides are >500 mg/dL despite lifestyle changes, then fibrates and fish oil can be used to reduce the levels and decrease the risk of pancreatitis. If the patient has risk factors for coronary heart disease, then statin therapy will be beneficial.

questions.text: A 46-year-old male patient came to the emergency department with fever and severe constrictive chest pain that worsened with deep inspiration and on lying down. He had a myocardial infarction 2 weeks back. A pericardial friction sound was audible at the lower left sternal border. The electrocardiogram is given below.  Which of the following is not true regarding this condition?

choices.text: It is due to an infection in the pericardium
Aspirin is given as first line treatment
Colchicine can be used in treatment

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a post-myocardial infarction (MI) patient presenting with pleuritic chest pain, fever, malaise, pericardial rub on auscultation, and the ECG given above showing diffuse ST-segment elevation with upward concavity are suggestive of Dressler syndrome.

Dressler syndrome/post-myocardial infarction syndrome is an autoimmune condition (option B) with inflammation of the pericardium. It presents as pleuritic chest pain, fever, malaise, and sometimes a pleuritic rub and effusion. The ECG findings include PR segment depression or ST-segment elevation. It commonly occurs 1–8 weeks after MI (option A). However, it can recur over months.

Treatment:

  • First-line therapy consists of aspirin 650 mg (option C) every 4 hours with NSAIDs like Ibuprofen or Indomethacin
  • Colchicine (option D) enhances the response to NSAIDs and prevents recurrence
  • Glucocorticosteroids and NSAIDs are best avoided in patients with Dressler syndrome within 4 weeks of STEMI as they may impair infarct healing, cause ventricular rupture, and increase coronary vascular resistance

Complications of myocardial infarction:

  • Myocardial rupture
  • Contractile dysfunction
  • Arrhythmia: Ventricular fibrillation is the most common arrhythmia within one hour of MI
  • Supraventricular tachycardia
  • Heart block
  • Pericarditis: occur even 48 hours after MI
  • Dressler syndrome or post-MI syndrome: 2-3 weeks after a transmural MI
  • Ventricular aneurysm
  • Progressive late heart failure (chronic IHD)
  • Infarct expansion associated with mural thrombus
  • Papillary muscle dysfunction

Myocardial rupture: Various forms of cardiac rupture typically occur when there is transmural necrosis of a ventricle. 

Rupture of the left ventricular free wall
  • Most common
  • 3-7 days after MI
  • Hemopericardium and cardiac tamponade
Rupture of the ventricular septum
  • Less common
  • Acute ventricular septal defect (VSD) and left-to-right shunting
Papillary muscle rupture
  • Least common
  • Severe mitral regurgitation

questions.text: What is the maximum period of voluntary self-admission under the Mental Healthcare Act 2017?
questions.solution:
The maximum period of voluntary self-admission is 30 days.

When a person has a mental illness that requires admission, and if he/she is able to make his or her own decision and voluntarily requested admission, then it is called voluntary self-admission.

According to the Mental Healthcare Act, the maximum duration for which such admission can last is 30 days. 

If the admission requires more than 30 days, or if it requires readmission within 7 days after discharge, then such patients should be examined by two psychiatrists and can be admitted for a maximum period of 90 days.

Note: The aforementioned question is as per the 2020 recall. This concept has been updated, and the admissions are classified as independent and supported. Please refer to the MCQ MG6497 for recent information.

questions.text: A patient presents with fever associated with rigor and chills for 1 week, with abdominal distension and loss of appetite. On examination, there is marked hepato-splenomegaly. There is a poor response to antibiotics and antimalarials. The Widal test is negative but rk39 is positive. A sample from which of the following sites is the most sensitive to demonstrate the presence of the causative organism?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical vignette of a patient with fever, rigor, chills, abdominal distension, and marked hepatosplenomegaly, alongside a positive rk39 test, the presentation is highly suggestive of visceral leishmaniasis (kala-azar). The most sensitive diagnostic method for detecting the causative organism is splenic aspirate, which has a positive detection rate of up to 98%.

Splenic aspiration is highly effective because it directly samples the site of infection. However, it is not routinely performed due to significant risks, such as haemorrhage, particularly in patients with advanced disease where the spleen is markedly enlarged and soft.

Kala-azar is a slowly progressing indigenous disease caused by a protozoan parasite of the genus Leishmania. Leishmaniasis is a parasitic disorder transmitted by the bite of an infected female Phlebotomus sandfly in developing countries. The disease is transmitted by sand flies, which inoculate the flagellated promastigotes into the skin of the host. It lowers immunity and causes persistent fever, anaemia, and hepatosplenomegaly, and if left untreated, death may occur due to opportunistic infection.

In human beings, the disease presents in four different forms with a broad range of clinical manifestations:

  • Visceral leishmaniasis, or kala-azar,
  • Cutaneous leishmaniasis,
  • Mucocutaneous leishmaniasis, and
  • Diffuse cutaneous leishmaniasis.

The life cycle of Leishmania involves two forms, the promastigote which develops and lives extracellularly in the sandfly vector and the amastigote form (as shown below) multiplies intracellularly in the reticuloendothelial cells of the host.

Diagnosis of visceral leishmaniasis includes the rK39 rapid diagnostic test and Kala-azar dipstick test, as recommended by the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP) in India. Parasitological confirmation is achieved by demonstrating LD bodies in a buffy coat smear. The aldehyde test of Napier is used for surveillance, while serological tests like rapid dipstick, direct agglutination test, ELISA, and indirect fluorescent antibody test aid in diagnosis. The Leishmanin (Montenegro) test is useful for identifying endemicity and immune response, though it is typically positive 4-6 weeks after cutaneous leishmaniasis onset.

A confirmatory diagnosis is achieved through parasite demonstration in bone marrow, spleen, lymph node aspiration, or in culture medium. The microscopic demonstration of amastigotes in bone marrow, generally obtained by aspirating the sternal marrow (as shown below). Other samples may include peripheral blood, splenic aspirate, and enlarged lymph nodes.

Treatment for visceral leishmaniasis typically includes medications such as sodium stibogluconate, miltefosine, and amphotericin B. In India, liposomal amphotericin is the first-line treatment, administered as a single intravenous dose of 10 mg/kg. This regimen is preferred due to its efficacy and safety profile, providing a robust option for managing this serious and life-threatening parasitic disease.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman came to the hospital with complaints of tremors, palpitations, and heat intolerance for the past 3 weeks. She also reported a loss of 3 kgs of weight loss during this period. She is not on any medications or nutritional supplements and has not undergone any imaging or surgical procedures in the past year. On examination, her pulse rate is 110 beats/min. The thyroid gland is slightly enlarged and extremely tender. TSH level is 0.05 mIU/L, free T4 level is 2.8 ng/dL, and radioiodine uptake was less than 1% at 24 hours. ESR is elevated while the leukocyte count is normal. What is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Begin treatment with NSAID or glucocorticoid

questions.solution:
The symptoms and lab results are suggestive of thyrotoxicosis due to subacute (painfull) thyroiditis for which the best next step is aimed at symptomatic relief with NSAIDs. 

Subacute (painful) Thyroiditis:

  • The thyroid hormone levels are increased from the release of the preformed hormone and not from excessive production, and therefore antithyroid medications are not effective.
  • The low iodine uptake and the tenderness of the thyroid confirm the diagnosis of subacute (painful) thyroiditis.
  • Treatment is aimed at symptomatic relief. NSAIDs are often effective for mild-to-moderate disease, but glucocorticoids may be necessary for more severe or refractory pain.

Other options:

Option b: Thyroglobulin is used in the setting of low-iodine-uptake thyrotoxicosis to distinguish between the endogenous and exogenous source of thyroid hormone. As the patient has the enlarged and tender thyroid, there is no reason to suspect the external use of levothyroxine in this case.

Option c: In view of the low iodine uptake and the absence of recent iodine load, this patient’s condition is not suggestive with Graves disease and hence TSI testing is not needed.

Option d: Ultrasonography with color Doppler flow would be useful if the uptake were low in the setting of recent iodine load in order to distinguish thyroiditis from Graves disease, but it is not necessary for the diagnosis in this situation.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male patient presented with nausea, vomiting, fatigue, and polyuria. On examination, he has an altered mental state. His past medical history is significant for lung cancer, which is now in remission.  The abnormalities in his blood reports are elevated serum calcium levels and low serum parathyroid hormone levels. What is the most likely type of underlying lung cancer in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario depicts the symptoms of hypercalcemia secondary to humoral hypercalcemia of malignancy (HHM)—a paraneoplastic syndrome associated with underlying squamous cell carcinoma of the lung.

Hypercalcemia results from the ectopic production of parathyroid hormone (PTH) or PTH-related peptides.
Clinical manifestation of hypercalcemia:
  • Renal - polyuria, polydipsia, nephrolithiasis
  • Central nervous system - lethargy, altered mental status, stupor, coma
  • Gastrointestinal - Nausea, vomiting, anorexia, abdominal pain, constipation, peptic ulcer disease, pancreatitis
  • Cardiac - bradycardia, AV block, short QT interval
  • Skeletal - bone pain, pathological fractures

Treatment:

  1. Volume expansion by intravenous normal saline (200-500 mL/h)
  2. Forced diuresis using loop diuretics after sufficient rehydration
  3. Intravenous bisphosphonates (zoledronic acid, pamidronate)
  4. Others - Denosumab, gallium nitrate, steroids

Paraneoplastic syndromes may be the presenting finding or the first sign of recurrence of malignancy.

  • SIADH
Small cell lung cancer (SCLC)
  • Syndrome of inappropriate secretion of antidiuretic hormone (SIADH) 
  • Cushing's syndrome
  • Eaton-Lambert syndrome
  • Retinal blindness

  • Hypertrophic primary osteoarthropathy

Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung is associated with the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH). Although SIADH presents with fatigue, nausea, and confusion, it also presents with hyponatremia, which is detected on laboratory investigations (not seen in this patient).

questions.text: An ophthalmology resident while presenting the seminar on staphyloma presents the following image showing different types of staphyloma. The type of staphyloma occurring at point A, at the limbus, is known as :
questions.solution:
The type of staphyloma occurring at point A is known as intercalary staphyloma. It is located at the limbus and is lined by the root of the iris and the anterior-most part of the ciliary body.

The patient usually has defective vision due to marked corneal astigmatism. The treatment consists of localised staphylectomy under heavy doses of oral steroids.

In the above image:

A: Intercalary staphyloma
B: Ciliary staphyloma
C: Equatorial staphyloma
D: Posterior staphyloma

Staphyloma:

It is an abnormal protrusion of the uveal tissue through a weak and thin portion of the cornea or sclera.

  • It is lined internally by uveal tissue and externally by weak cornea or sclera.
  • Types of Staphyloma:
    • Anterior staphyloma: It is characterized by ectasia of the pseudo-cornea, which occurs after the total sloughing of the cornea. It is lined internally by the iris and externally by the newly formed epithelium.
    • Intercalary staphyloma: This is located at the limbus and is lined by the root of the iris and the anterior-most part of the ciliary body
    • Ciliary staphyloma: It is characterized by ectasia of weak sclera lined by the ciliary body. This affects the ciliary zone, which includes the region up to 8 mm behind the limbus.
    • Equatorial staphyloma: This occurs at the equatorial region up to 14 mm behind the limbus of the eye.
    • Posterior staphyloma: This affects the posterior pole of the eye.
  • Note :
    • The most common cause of anterior staphyloma is a sloughing corneal ulcer.
    • The most common cause of posterior staphyloma is degenerative high axial myopia.

questions.text: Identify the false statement about the protective reflex that occurs in response to excessive lung inflation.

choices.text: Occurs when the tidal volume reaches 1500 ml
Mediated by slowly adapting receptor via myelinated vagal fibres
Switches off the inspiratory ramp signal in the dorsal group of neurons

questions.solution:
The Hering-Breuer reflex (protective reflex that occurs in response to excessive lung inflation) increases the rate of respiration.

Hering-Breuer reflex: When the lungs are overinflated, pulmonary stretch recep­tors activate a feedback response that switches off the inspiratory ramp signal of the dorsal respiratory group of neurons (DRG), stopping further inspiration. This reflex increases the respiratory rate by cutting down inspiration time.

The receptors involved are slowly adapting pulmonary stretch receptors and the impulses travel in the vagus nerve via large myelinated fibers. 

The Hering­ Breuer reflex is not activated until the tidal volume is more than three times normal (>≈1.5 liters per breath). Therefore, this reflex appears to be mainly a protective mechanism for preventing excess lung inflation. 

It signifies that the reflex plays a protective role preventing the overinflation of the lung rather than regulating the normal ventilation. 

Advantages of Hering-Breuer inflation reflex: It cuts down the inspiration time, and therefore,

  • It prevents overinflation of the lungs.
  • Lungs operate at lower lung volumes, thereby preventing wastage of energy.

 Hering-Breuer reflex can be divided into:

  • Hering-Breuer inflation reflex- An increase in the duration of expiration in response to steady lung inflation
  • Hering-Breuer deflation reflex- A decrease in the duration of expiration in response to marked deflation of the lung.

questions.text: A woman presents to the OPD with complaints of amenorrhoea for the past year. She has a history of postpartum hemorrhage and lactational failure. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of Sheehan's syndrome. 

Sheehan's syndrome (SS) is postpartum hypopituitarism secondary to the necrosis of the pituitary gland. It usually results from severe hypotension or shock caused by massive hemorrhage during or after delivery. Patients with SS have varying degrees of anterior pituitary hormone deficiency. The hyperplastic enlargement of the pituitary, which occurs normally during pregnancy, increases the risk of infarction. 

Affected women may have persistent hypotension, tachycardia, hypoglycemia, and lactation failure. The most prominent symptoms are lactation failure (due to a deficiency of prolactin) and postpartum amenorrhea (due to a deficiency of gonadotropins). Because deficiencies of some or all pituitary-responsive hormones may develop after the initial insult, Sheehan syndrome can be heterogeneous and may not be identified for years.

It can present acutely as pituitary apoplexy, an endocrine emergency, characterized by a sudden onset of headache, nausea, visual deficits, and in severe cases, severe hypoglycemia, hypotension and shock, CNS hemorrhage, and death.

Also, it can present late with the following features:

  • Loss of pubic and axillary hair
  • Hypothyroidism due to decreased TSH secretion 
  • Adrenal insufficiency due to low ACTH

Treatment is by hormone replacement - first glucocorticoids, later - thyroid hormone, sex steroids, vasopressin and growth hormones are given. If there is evidence of progressive visual loss, cranial nerve involvement or loss of consciousness, immediate surgical decompression must be carried out. Fertility can be achieved in these women with hMG and hCG. Clomiphene is ineffective. 

Option B: Rotor syndrome is a type of hereditary hyperbilirubinemia with autosomal recessive inheritance. Affected individuals have mild jaundice and hyperbilirubinemia. 

Option C: Prolactinoma or pituitary adenoids is the condition of hyperprolactinemia diagnosed by a prolactin level >200 μg/L. It usually presents with infertility, amenorrhea, and galactorrhea.

Option D: Acromegaly is characterized by the signs and symptoms pertaining to excessive growth hormone secretion.

questions.text: A female patient presents with sudden onset palpitations, sweating, breathlessness, and a feeling like she is being choked. Physical examination and routine investigations were within normal limits. Which of the following is false about this condition?

choices.text: Occurs only in the presence of a trigger

questions.solution:
This clinical vignette describes a classic panic attack, which can occur even in the absence of an identifiable trigger.

A panic attack is a sudden surge of intense fear or discomfort that may last from minutes to hours. Recurrent panic attacks can point to a panic disorder.

Panic attacks can also be seen in other disorders such as specific phobias, social phobias, and post-traumatic stress disorder. Unexpected panic attacks occur at any time and are not associated with any identifiable situational trigger. Attacks in patients with social and specific pho­bias are usually expected in response to a specific stimulus.

Some panic attacks are neither unexpected nor expected attacks and are known as situationally predisposed panic attacks. They may or may not occur on exposure to a specific trigger, or may occur immediately after exposure or after a considerable period of time.

Four or more of the following should be present to label it a panic attack:

  • Palpitations, pounding heart, or tachycardia
  • Perspiration
  • Trembling 
  • Breathlessness or a sensation of smothering
  • Feelings of choking
  • Chest pain or discomfort
  • Nausea or abdominal distress
  • Dizziness, unsteadiness, light-headedness, or fainting 
  • Chills or heat sensations
  • Paresthesias
  • Derealization (feelings of unreality) or depersonalization (feeling detached from oneself)
  • Fear of losing control 
  • Fear of death

Alprazolam and paroxetine can be used for the medical management of panic disorders. Cognitive and behavior therapies can also prove effective.

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, arthralgia, and pain behind the eyes for 3 days. On examination, she has the following rash. Lab reports show thrombocytopenia and leucopenia. Which of the following antibodies are demonstrated for the purpose of early diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the symptoms and the rash suggests dengue fever. It presents as sudden-onset fever, retroorbital pain, myalgia, arthralgia, and a rash. The rash in dengue appears as 'white islands in a red sea' due to erythema with petechiae. Demonstration of circulating IgM antibody provides early diagnosis as it appears within two to five days of onset of illness and persists for one to three months.

Dengue is an acute febrile disease caused by the mosquito-borne dengue viruses (DENVs), consisting of four serotypes (DENV 1 to 4), that are members of the Flaviviridae family, genus flavivirus. 

Dengue virus is transmitted from person to person by Aedes aegypti or "tiger" mosquitoes. 

The four DENV infections can be asymptomatic or manifest. The diseases range in severity from undifferentiated acute febrile illness, classical dengue fever (DF), to the life-threatening conditions Dengue Hemorrhagic Fever (DHF)/Dengue Shock Syndrome (DSS). 

After an incubation period of 3–15 days, classical dengue fever begins with an abrupt onset of high fever. The condition is self-limiting though debilitating with headache, retro-orbital pain, myalgia, arthralgia, petechiae rash, and leucopenia. A macular-papular recovery rash appears 3–5 days after the onset of fever, and it usually starts on the trunk before spreading peripherally. During the febrile phase, dehydration can lead to neurological disturbances and febrile seizures in young children.  

Dengue fever is sometimes referred to as ‘break bone fever’ due to associated severe muscle and joint pain or ‘seven-day fever’ since the symptoms usually persist for 7 days.

Dengue Hemorrhagic Fever or DHF is associated with hemorrhagic manifestations, plasma leakage resulting from an increased vascular permeability, and thrombocytopenia. Plasma leakage is characterized by hemoconcentration (hematocrit increase of 20%), development of ascites, or pleural effusion.

Dengue Shock Syndrome is distinguished from Dengue Hemorrhagic Fever by the presence of cardiovascular compromise, which occurs when plasma leakage into the interstitial spaces results in shock. DSS is a fatal condition. Common clinical warning signs for DSS include a rapidly rising hematocrit, intense abdominal pain, persistent vomiting, and narrowed or absent blood pressure.

Suspected cases of dengue are confirmed by the presence of NS1 antigen or IgM antibodies. IgG antibodies can be done in paired serum samples.

The treatment of dengue is supportive management, with hydration, cold sponging, and paracetamol for fever. Aspirin/ NSAIDS like Ibuprofen should be avoided as they can cause gastritis, vomiting, acidosis, platelet dysfunction and severe bleeding. Fluid and electrolyte replacement and platelet infusion should be done for severe cases.

In the given scenario, a child weighing between 20-30kgs will be transitioned to Abacavir (ABC) + lamivudine (3TC) + dolutegravir (DTG)

DTG is approved for use among children older than six years and weighing more than 15 kg and is widely available for children weighing at least 20 kg who can take 50mg filmcoated adult tablets.

questions.text:
A surgeon is performing an intestinal resection procedure in a patient with Crohn's disease. During the surgery, he accidentally damages one of the branches of the artery marked "?" in the image given below. Which of the following are the areas supplied by the vessel marked in the image?

1) Jejunum

2) Descending colon

3) Vermiform appendix

4) Caecum

5) Rectum
questions.solution:
The vessel marked "?" in the image is the superior mesenteric artery and it is identified by its origin from the abdominal aorta and the left renal vein can be seen passing behind the vessel. It is the artery of the midgut and supplies the duodenum (distal), small intestine (jejunum, ileum), appendix, cecum, ascending colon, proximal 2/3rd of the transverse colon.

The superior mesenteric artery (SMA) is a branch of the abdominal aorta and originates at the level of the lower border of the L1 vertebra in the transpyloric plane. It descends anterior to the uncinate process of the pancreas and the third part of the duodenum and posterior to the body of the pancreas and the splenic vein. The left renal vein separates it from the aorta posteriorly.

The branches of SMA include:

  • Jejunal branches
  • Ileal branches
  • Middle colic artery
  • Right colic artery
  • Ileocolic artery
  • Inferior pancreaticoduodenal artery

questions.text: A child born to a 38-year-old mother was found to have a round face, flat occiput, protruding tongue, and a 'Simian crease' on the palm. Karyotyping revealed trisomy of chromosome 21. Which of the following anomalies will you most likely see in this child?
questions.solution:
Annular pancreas is more prevalent in children with Down syndrome as given in the scenario above. It is most often seen in association with congenital duodenal stenosis or atresia.

It occurs because of the failure of a complete rotation of the ventral pancreatic bud during development, so a ring of pancreatic tissue surrounds the second or third part of the duodenum. Duodenal obstruction typically causes vomiting in the neonate.

Treatment is duodenoduodenostomy.

Pancreas divisum: When the dorsal and ventral ducts fail to fuse during embryogenesis, it leads to pancreas divisum. As most pancreatic exocrine secretions exit through the dorsal duct, pancreas divisum can lead to partial obstruction caused by a small minor papilla, leading to chronic backpressure in the duct. This relative outflow obstruction can lead to relapsing acute or chronic pancreatitis. The incidence of pancreas divisum in the general population is about 10%.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman presented with an episode of sudden left-sided weakness and speech difficulty which resolved spontaneously within 24 hours. She has a history of recurrent miscarriages. ECG shows a sinus rhythm. Echocardiography revealed small vegetations on both sides of the mitral valve. What is the most probable diagnosis?

ECG - electrocardiogram
questions.solution:
The given presentation of neurological deficit resolving within 24 hours indicates a transient ischemic attack (TIA). The history of recurrent miscarriage points toward antiphospholipid syndrome (APS). These factors, along with the pattern of vegetations on the mitral valve, are strongly suggestive of Libman sack’s endocarditis.

Libman sack’s endocarditis is a type of non-bacterial thrombotic endocarditis (NBTE). It is associated with autoimmune conditions such as systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and antiphospholipid antibody syndrome. The deposition of immune complexes leads to the formation of small (1 to 4 mm), sterile vegetations on heart valves. 

Vegetations can occur anywhere on the valve surface, on the chordae, or even on the atrial or ventricular endocardium. Histologically, there is intense valvulitis and fibrinoid necrosis of the valve substance. Patients may present with symptoms of stroke or TIA's due to emboli from the vegetation.

Other options:

Option A: Infective endocarditis is a microbial infection of the heart valves or the mural endocardium. The classic hallmarks of infective endocarditis are vegetations on heart valves. They are large, irregular masses on the valve cusps that can extend onto the chordae. Vegetations in infective endocarditis are friable, bulky, destructive lesions composed of fibrin, inflammatory cells, and microbes. 

Option C: Marantic endocarditis or Non-bacterial thrombotic endocarditis is characterized by the deposition of small (1 to 5 mm), sterile, non-destructive thrombi along the line of closure of the leaflets of the cardiac valves. A hypercoagulable state is a predisposing factor for marantic endocarditis.

Option D: Rheumatic heart disease is the inflammation of the endocardium and the left-sided valves that typically results in fibrinoid necrosis within the cusps or tendinous cords. Vegetations in RHD are small (1-2 mm) along the lines of closures of the valve leaflets. Irregular subendocardial thickenings are termed MacCallum plaques.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about congenital rubella, except

choices.text: It is diagnosed when the infant has IgM antibodies at birth
It is diagnosed when IgG antibodies persist for more than 6 months
Most common congenital defects are deafness, cardiac malformations and cataract
Infection after 16 weeks of gestation results in major congenital defects

questions.solution:
Infection beyond first trimester doesn’t result in major congenital defects. Birth defects are uncommon if maternal infection occurs after 20 weeks.
Presence of IgM antibodies in infant suggests denovo neonatal infection, rather than passively transferred antibodies.Congenital Rubella Syndrome consists of triad of Cataract, Deafness and cardiac malformations.

questions.text: During your surgery internship, you observe the following incision was made by the senior resident while performing an abdominal surgery. What is the name of the incision  being performed here?
questions.solution:
The above image shows Chevron (rooftop) incision.

Chevron (rooftop) incision is a bilateral anterior subcostal incision joined in the midline. It can be used to access the organs of the upper abdomen and diaphragm.

A Mercedes-Benz modification of this incision includes a midline incision superiorly, providing further access to the upper abdomen or the lower mediastinum.

Other options:

Option A: Kocher’s incision is a right subcostal incision, which is commonly used in open cholecystectomy surgeries.

Option B: Mayo Robson’s incision is a right upper paramedian incision extended like a hockey stick to the midline. It is indicated in cholecystectomy

Option D: Rutherford-Morrison’s incision is an oblique muscle-cutting incision, with its lower end over McBurney’s point and extending obliquely upwards and laterally, as necessary.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with blurring of vision and the presence of a dark spot with distorted vision in his right eye for the past week. He has been taking steroid tablets for asthma. His best corrected visual acuity measured 6/24 in his right eye and 6/6 in his left eye. Posterior segment examination is shown in the image. What is the first-line management for this case?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with visual abnormalities, history of steroid intake, and the fundal image depicting focal fundal detachment are suggestive of central serous retinopathy. Discontinuation of steroid use is the first line of management in this case.

Central serous chorioretinopathy (CSR) is an idiopathic disorder characterized by a localized serous detachment of the sensory retina at the macula.

Recent studies implicate abnormal choroidal circulation as the cause of CSR. 

Risk factors:

  • Age: young adults (20–50 years)
  • Sex: male > female
  • Steroid intake 
  • Emotional stress
  • Pregnancy
  • Cushing's syndrome
  • Hypertension
  • Sleep apnea syndrome

Clinical features:

  • Mostly unilateral
  • Retinal detachment - Sudden painless loss of vision
  • Relative positive scotoma
  • Micropsia
  • Metamorphopsia

Investigations:

  • Ophthalmoscopy - circular ring reflex present and foveal reflex absent
  • FFA - enlarging inkblot pattern or smoke stack pattern
  • OCT - optically empty neurosensory elevation at macular region.

Spontaneous resolution is seen in most cases and hence observation is enough. Steroids are contraindicated. The disease is usually self-limiting but may recur.

Other treatment options for recurrent and chronic cases: Laser photocoagulation, photodynamic therapy, and intravitreal anti-VEGF.

The image below depicts fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA), showing an enlarging ink-blot pattern/ enlarging dot sign - A small hyperfluorescent spot that gradually enlarges in size - seen in Central Serous Retinopathy (CSR).

The image below depicts fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA), showing smokestack appearance - A small hyperfluorescent spot that ascends vertically like a smokestack that looks like an umbrella or a mushroom - seen in central serous retinopathy (CSR).

 The image below depicts optical coherence tomography (OCT) showing fluid accumulation in the subretinal space, with shallow retinal detachment - seen in CSR.

questions.text: A 1-year-old baby is brought to the emergency room with bluish discoloration of the skin and rapid breathing. His mother reveals a history of congenital heart disease in the baby and adds that this episode was provoked by an incessant cry. Which of the following is least likely to be used for managing this child?
questions.solution:
The least likely drug to be used for managing this child is intravenous nitroglycerin. The given scenario is suggestive of a paroxysmal hypercyanotic attack/ cyanotic spell. The administration of intravenous nitroglycerin is of no use and can worsen the condition, as it decreases peripheral resistance.

Paroxysmal hypercyanotic spells may also be referred to as tet spells/ blue spells/ hypoxic spells. Though commonly associated with Tetralogy of Fallot, they can be associated with other forms of pulmonary stenosis with ventricular septal defect as well. Precipitating factors include crying, defecation, feeding, wakening from sleep, dehydration, fever, tachycardia, tachypnea, and events provoking agitation.

They are characterized by:

  • Period of uncontrolled crying/ panic/ irritability
  • Rapid and deep breathing
  • Increased cyanosis
  • Limpness and lethargy
  • Reduced murmur intensity (signifying substantial blood flow reduction across the right ventricular outflow tract)

Management options for this child include the following:

  • Calm the child and minimize the stimuli
  • Place in the knee-chest position
  • Administer oxygen
  • Subcutaneous morphine (not in excess of 0.2mg/kg)
  • IV sodium bicarbonate - for correction of the ongoing metabolic acidosis
  • IV phenylephrine - as it increases the systemic vascular resistance
  • IV propranolol - as it reduces the pulmonary infundibular spasms in TOF
  • If the spell is resistant to all the above-said measures, then intubation and sedation of the child are required to break the spell

questions.text: A young man deliberately ingested a poisonous liquid in an attempt to commit suicide. The bottle from which he ingested the liquid is shown below. Emergency management was done as soon as he was taken to the hospital. When examining the urobag a few hours later, what color will you expect the urine to be?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of carbolic acid/phenol poisoning.  A few hours later, the urine in the urobag will be expected to have a smoky green or olive green color. This urine color change occurs due to the oxidation of the metabolic products of phenol—hydroquinone and pyrocatechol.

Carbolic acid or phenol is an organic acid that is used as a disinfectant and solvent. It has a characteristic phenolic odor. Poisoning by carbolic acid is called carbolism.

On exposure to the skin, carbolic acid coagulates the proteins and causes the formation of an eschar that will come off as slough later. It can damage the nerves and cause tingling and numbness.

On ingestion, a burning sensation may be felt, along with nausea and vomiting. Vomiting puts the patient at risk of aspiration pneumonia. The acid can also cause pulmonary and laryngeal edema, leading to difficulty breathing, and ultimately respiratory failure. Systemic features include headache, dizziness, syncope, and even coma.

Diagnosis of carbolic acid poisoning can be made by adding a few drops of 10% ferric chloride to the patient's urine sample. If the sample turns violet or blue, it indicates the presence of phenolic compounds. The urine sample would also reduce Benedict's and Fehling's solutions.

Treatment involves removing contaminated clothing and washing the skin. If the patient has ingested the poison, cautious gastric lavage with 20% alcohol, glycerol, or vegetable oil should be carried out. MgSO4 or liquid paraffin should be left in the stomach to remove surface phenol and prevent deep penetration. Parenteral saline can also be administered to correct the circulatory depression, dilute the carbolic acid content of the blood, and promote its excretion. Hemodialysis can be carried out if there is renal failure.

Post mortem, the viscera should be preserved in a saturated salt solution. The skin has a reddish appearance with necrosis or ulceration. The body has a characteristic phenolic odor. The esophagus may look reddish and like parchment. The internal surface of the stomach may show prominent rugae with a leathery appearance, due to the opaque, coagulated, grey, or brown mucosa.

Other options-

Option (B): Pale yellow is the color of normal urine, so this is not the correct answer.

Option (C & D): Orange-red color of urine can be seen in patients on rifampicin therapy.

questions.text:
A patient diagnosed with renal cell carcinoma has been planned for radical nephrectomy by the surgical team. The tumor is 4 cms in size, situated at the lower pole of the kidney with negative regional lymph nodes determined through CT. Which of the following will be removed in this patient?
  1. Kidney
  2. Adrenal gland
  3. Perirenal fat
  4. Regional lymph nodes
questions.solution:
While performing radical nephrectomy in the above patient only kidney and perirenal fat will be removed, as the tumor size is less than 5cm and situated at the lower pole of the kidney with negative regional lymph nodes.

Radical Nephrectomy :

Classically radical nephrectomy consists of removal of the kidney, perirenal fat, adrenal gland, and regional lymph nodes. In patients with a tumor <5 cm in size, located at the inferior pole, the adrenal gland can be spared. Regional lymph node dissection is done for patients with clinically positive nodes detected by CT or during the surgery. As in this scenario the tumour size is <5cm and regional lymph nodes detection was negative, both the adrenal glands and lymph nodes are spared. 

Partial nephrectomy :

  • For tumors less than or equal to 4 cm in size and limited to the kidney (T1a), partial nephrectomy is performed.
  • Partial nephrectomy is also increasingly being performed in tumors >4cm in size but less than or equal to 7 cms, and limited to the kidney (T1b). If partial nephrectomy is not feasible in T1b tumors, then a radical nephrectomy is done.
  • Other indications for partial nephrectomy are bilateral renal cell carcinoma and carcinoma affecting a solitary functioning kidney.

Radical nephrectomy is performed in patients with large tumors and for patients in whom a partial nephrectomy is not technically feasible.

questions.text: A chronic kidney disease patient requires a renal transplant. His twin sister is found to be an HLA match and she donates her kidney. What type of graft is described here?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario mentions a graft received from a twin sister. Since the sex of both the twins are different, they are non-identical twins. A graft from two genetically non-identical members of the same species is known as an allograft. This was formerly known as homograft.

An isograft, on the other hand, is defined as an organ or tissue that is taken from an individual (donor) and is placed on another individual (recipient) who has the same genetic constitution as of the donor. An example of this would be a graft between identical twins.

Other options :

Autograft is an organ or tissue taken from an individual and grafted on him/herself.

A xenograft is a graft between members of two different species. This was formerly known as  heterograft.

Related Pearl: Types of transplants

Type  Definition

Organ implanted in the same anatomic location in the recipient as it was in the donor. Diseased organ is removed. Eg: heart, lung, liver, intestine
Heterotopic

Organ implanted in a different anatomic location. Diseased organ is left in place. Eg: Kidney, pancreas
Auxiliary transplantation Partial tissue from the donor is used which acts as temporary support for the recipient's injured organ, which remains in place. Eg: left lobe of liver
Autotransplant  Transfer of cells/tissues/organs within the same person.

questions.text:
Match the following scenarios to the type of delusion.
  1. Delusion of persecution 
  2. Delusion of infidelity
  3. Delusion of dysmorphophobia
  4. Delusion of grandeur

 

a. A man believes his wife is cheating on him despite having proof that she is not.

b. A lady believes that the president is desperately in love with her.

c. A man believes he has been specially chosen by the gods to heal the world.

d. A lady having a body mass index of 14 believes that she looks obese.

e. A man believes that foreign armed forces are plotting to kill him.
questions.solution:
The correct matching of types of delusions is 1-e, 2-a, 3-d, and 4-c. 

A delusion is a false fixed belief that does not change even with evidence to prove otherwise. Delusions are termed bizarre, if they are not derived from ordinary life experiences and are clearly implausible. Non-bizarre delusions are those which are possible, but not real and there is no convincing evidence to prove them. An example is a belief that an individual is under police surveillance but there is a lack of convincing evidence. 

Common delusions include:

Delusion of grandeur is characterized by a sense of increased self-importance, exceptional abilities, wealth, or fame. 

The delusion of infidelity is a jealous type of delusion. The central theme of the individual's delusion is that his or her spouse or lover is unfaithful. Othello syndrome describes morbid jealousy that can arise due to multiple concerns. It is more commonly seen in men with no previous psychiatric history.

In delusions of dysmorphophobia, the individual is convinced of misshapenness, personal ugliness, or exaggerated size of their body parts. It is a somatic type of delusion. 

Patients with delusions of persecution are convinced that they are being pe It r­secuted or harmed by an individual, organization, or other groups. These are the most common types of delusions.

Erotomanic delusion, also known as psychose passionelle involves a belief that a person usually of higher stature is in love with the patient.

A diagnosis of delusional disorder is made when non-bizzare delusions are present for at least a month that cannot be attributed to other psychiatric conditions.

Related Pearl: Types of delusions

THE TYPES OF DELUSIONS

Delusion of control

False belief that a person’s will, thoughts, or feelings are being controlled by external forces.

Delusion of grandeur or Megalomania 

Exaggerated conception of one’s importance, power, or identity.

Delusion of infidelity or morbid jealousy or Othello syndrome

False belief that one’s lover is unfaithful. Sometimes called pathological jealousy.

Delusion of love or erotomania

False belief that another person is in love with them. In De Clerambault syndrome, the woman believes that a man, frequently older and of higher status, is in love with her.

Delusion of misidentification 

Capgras syndrome: Belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an exact double i.e. an impostor.

Fregoli syndrome: Person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Nihilistic delusion 

False belief that oneself, others or the world, is non-existent or about to end. When nihilistic delusion is accompanied by ideas concerning bodily function failure e.g. putrefaction of intestine etc, it is called Cotard syndrome.

Delusion of infestation 

False belief that one is infested with small but visible organisms. As a monosymptomatic delusional disorder, this is called Ekbom syndrome. 

Delusion of persecution

The most common delusion. False belief of being harassed or persecuted.

Delusion of poverty

The person strongly believes they are financially incapacitated.

Delusion of reference

False belief that the behavior of others has a particular and unusual significance, usually of a negative nature. The person may falsely feel that others are talking about them (e.g. the people on television are talking to or about the person).  

Delusion of self-accusation

False feeling of remorse and guilt. Seen in depression with psychotic features.

Related Pearl: Disorders of thought and perception

DISORDERS OF THOUGHT

DISORDER OF STREAM OF THOUGHT

(A) Disorder of tempo

(i) Flight of Ideas

Continuous flow of rapid speech that jumps from topic to topic

  • "I like mangoes, the weather is nice, India is great"

(ii) Retardation of thinking

Slow speed of speech and a prolonged latent period before a response

  • "I went to the market (pause)......... the shop was closed"

(iii) Circumstantialities

Inclusion of irrelevant details and going on in a roundabout manner, but their thought ultimately reaches the answer

  • Doctor: "How did you get that bruise?"

  • Patient: "I woke up and had a cup of coffee, read the newspaper and went for a walk. It was a wonderful day in the park. I returned home and watched the TV. I took a nap in the afternoon after lunch. I slipped and fell in the bathroom. The fall gave me this bruise."

(iv) Clang associations

Jumping from one word to another irrelevant rhyming word

  • I am Sam...I like jam...I travel in a tram"

(B) Disorder of continuity

(i) Perseveration

Repetition of out of context words, phrases, or ideas beyond the point of relevance.

  • Q1. What's your name?: "Rahul"

  • Q2. Where are you from?: "Rahul"

  • Q3. How old are you?: "Rahul"

(ii) Thought blocking

A sudden disruption of thought or a break in the flow of ideas

  • "I went to the market (extreme silence)...................."

DISORDER OF FORM OF THOUGHT

(i) Tangentiality

In response to a question, the patient gives a reply that is appropriate to the general topic but does not answer the question exactly. The speech moves away from the actual answer.

  • Doctor: "Have you had any trouble sleeping lately?"
  • Patient: "I usually sleep in my bed, but now I'm sleeping on the sofa"

(ii) Derailment

A breakdown in both the logical connection between ideas and the overall sense of goal-directedness. The words make sentences, but the sentences do not make sense.

  • "Some people just don't understand why I had breakfast in America during the first world war"

(iii) Neologisms

Bringing in new words that do not exist.

  • The world is not 'gooder' for people like me"

(iv) Desultory thoughts

Speech is grammatically correct, however, sudden unrelated ideas force their way in from time to time.

  • My actual problem is that the people never understand me and my stomach feels like an empty bucket"

(v) Word salad

Using a mixture of unintelligible meaningless words and sentences

  • Tree bus rain food home car tiger"

DISORDER OF POSSESSION OF THOUGHT
A. Thought alienation

(i) Thought insertion

Thoughts are being inserted into the patient's mind and they recognize them as being foreign and coming from without any stimulus

  • "I have repeated thoughts of killing my neighbors and I believe aliens are putting these ideas into my head at night"

(ii) Thought withdrawal

Delusion that someone or something is removing from one's mind and the patient has no power over this.

  • "Lately, I am losing all my memories and I believe that the 'government agents' are stealing them when I go to sleep"

(iii) Thought broadcasting

Belief that one's thoughts are quietly escaping from one's mind and that other people might be able to access them and hear or see them.

  • "I believe my exact thoughts appear on the TV and the internet and I think I can broadcast them globally" 

(iv) Thought echo

Patient hears the 'echo' of his own thoughts in the form of a voice after he has made the thought.

  • "I thought of making a sandwich in the morning and surprisingly a voice, from nowhere, told me to make a sandwich out loud" 

 B. Obsessions and Compulsions

1. Obsessions

Recurrent and persistent thoughts, impulses. or images that cause distress to oneself.

  • Fear of dirt or contamination
  • Fear of becoming ill
  • Constant thoughts of a certain number
  • Need for symmetry or exactness
  • Worry about whether something has been done "right"
  • Forbidden sexual or religious thoughts

2. Compulsions

Repetitive behaviors or actions that the person feels driven to perform in response to an obsession

  • Washing hands
  • Blinking eyes
  • Counting items, such as currency
  • Checking to see if doors are locked
  • Arranging items in a certain way
  • Requiring constant approval from people around them

 
 DISORDER OF CONTENT OF THOUGHT

(i) Phobias

Persistent fear of an object or situation, typically disproportional to the actual danger posed, in which the sufferer goes to great lengths in avoiding it

  • Arachnophobia - fear of spider
  • Barophobia - fear of gravity
  • Cynophobia - fear of dogs
  • Hemophobia - fear of blood
  • Nosocomephobia - fear of hospitals

(ii) Religious preoccupations

Thoughts involving religious themes or subject matter.

  • "I get instructions from God on how to make my country great"

(iii) Ideas of hopelessness

Thoughts of complete despair where the patient strongly believes that the circumstances will never get better for him.

  • "I am never going to pass my final exams, no matter how hard I study"

(iv) Antisocial urges

Thoughts of indulging in some behaviors or actions that harm or lack consideration for the well being of others.

  • "I have these urges to go rob a bank or blackmail my neighbors for their money"

(v) Delusions

False beliefs that are strongly held and unchangeable in the face of refuting evidence and that are not consistent with the person's educational, social and cultural background.

The three main criteria for a belief to be considered a delusion are:

  • Certainty (held with complete confidence)
  • Incorrigibility (not changeable by proof to the contrary)
  • Impossibility or falsity of content (implausible, bizarre or patently untrue)
 DISORDERS OF PERCEPTIONS

  • Illusion: Misinterpretation of real external stimuli.

  • Hallucination: False sensory perception, externally.

  • Pseudohallucination: False sensory perception from within and having an insight.

  • Depersonalization: Feeling as if one is disconnected from reality, feeling detached from one's own thoughts and one's own physical body.

    "I sometimes drift into a dream-like state where I lose contact with my own self"

  • Derealization: Alteration in the perception or experience of the external world so that it seems unreal.

    "The world and everything around is nothing but just a dream"

Related Pearl: Psychotic disorders

Differential diagnosis of DSM-5 psychotic disorders

Psychotic disorder

 Criteria for diagnosis
Brief psychotic disorder

Sudden onset and a full return to function

Duration: > 1 day and < 1 month
Schizophreniform disorder

Same symptoms as schizophrenia and functional decline not required

Duration: > 1 month & < 6 months
Schizophrenia

Requires functional decline

At least 6 months (includes at least 1 month of active symptoms, can include prodromal and residual periods)
Schizoaffective disorder

With concurrent mood episode. Active-phase symptoms of schizophrenia with at least a 2 weeks of lifetime history of delusions or hallucinations in absence of prominent mood symptoms
Delusional disorder

One or more delusions for > 1 month

No other psychotic symptoms and normal functioning apart from the direct impact of delusions
Shared psychotic disorder (folie a deux)

Development of delusions in a person who is in a close relationship (ex: spouse, child) with someone who has a delusional disorder (the inducer)

questions.text: A 30-year-old lady presents with complaints of infertility and secondary amenorrhea after 25 years of age. She also had galactorrhoea. Her urine pregnancy test was negative and her prolactin level was 45 ng/mL. The gynecologist prescribes a drug that reduces prolactin levels. What is the mechanism of action of the drug prescribed to her?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario depicts hyperprolactinemia. D2 receptor agonists are used as the drug of choice to reduce prolactin levels in hyperprolactinemia.

Cabergoline is a long-acting D2 agonist. Its t1/2 is >60 hours. It undergoes significant first-pass metabolism in the liver.

Cabergoline is the preferred drug for the treatment of hyperprolactinemia because of its greater efficacy and lower side effects. Therapy is initiated at a dose of 0.25 mg twice a week or 0.5 mg once a week. The dose can be increased to 1.5-2 mg two or three times a week as tolerated; the dose should be increased only once every 4 weeks. Doses of 2 mg per week or less should normalize prolactin levels in about 80% of patients. Cabergoline induces remission in a significant number of patients with prolactinomas. At higher doses, it is used in some patients with acromegaly, alone or in conjunction with (somatostatin) SST analogs. 

Adverse effects:

  • Hypotension
  • Nausea

Bromocriptine is shorter-acting when compared with cabergoline.

questions.text: An elderly man, who is on chronic morphine therapy for pain relief, visits your clinic with complaints of not passing stools for the last 4 days. Which of the following drugs is best suited to treat his condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture points towards opioid-induced constipation. Methylnaltrexone, an opioid antagonist with predominant peripheral action is best suited for treating opioid-induced constipation.

Methylnaltrexone is a peripheral µ receptor antagonist. It was introduced in the treatment of opioid-induced constipation refractory to other measures.

It is a quaternary ammonium compound and hence cannot cross the blood-brain barrier. It can reverse the effects mediated by peripheral opioid receptors and spares CNS effects like analgesia.

The peripherally acting opioid antagonists include:

  • Methylnaltrexone
  • Naloxegol
  • Naldemedine
  • Alvimopan

questions.text: A patient complains of neck stiffness and severe headache. The CT image shown below is suggestive of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The clinical manifestations of neck stiffness and severe headache with CT revealing blood in the basal cistern points out to the diagnosis of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH).

Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) is the bleeding into the subarachnoid space, which is the area between the arachnoid membrane and the pia mater surrounding the brain. The diagnosis is suspected when a hyperattenuating material is seen filling the subarachnoid space. Most commonly this is apparent around the circle of Willis, on account of the majority of berry aneurysms occurring in this region (65%), or in the Sylvian fissure (30%).

The modified Fisher scale is a method for grading SAH as seen on non-contrast CT (NCCT). The Hunt and Hess scale describes the severity of SAH and is used as a predictor of survival.

Xanthochromia on CSF is indicative of SAH in case of a negative CT scan. 

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man presents with painless generalized lymphadenopathy and weakness. The biopsy findings of H&E staining and immunohistochemistry for BCL2 are given in the images below. The results of immunophenotyping of the cells are as follows: CD19+, CD20+, CD10+, and CD5-. What is the translocation seen in this disease?

H&E: Hematoxyline and eosin
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of follicular lymphoma. The majority of follicular lymphomas have the characteristic t(14;18) translocation.

Follicular lymphoma presents in middle age with no sex predilection. The most common presenting symptom is painless generalized lymphadenopathy. A lymph node biopsy is adequate for the diagnosis of follicular lymphoma. Immunophenotyping of the cells showing CD19, CD20, CD10, BCL2 positive, and CD5 negative is suggestive that the cells originate from the germinal center.

This chromosomal rearrangement results in the overexpression of BCL2 protein, which is an inhibitor of apoptosis that contributes to cell survival.

On histopathology, the lymph nodes exhibit a nodular or nodular and diffuse growth pattern. Two cell types are predominantly present in varying proportions: 

  • Centrocytes (small cleaved cells) - small cells with a cleaved nucleus and scant cytoplasm
  • Centroblasts - large cells with open nuclear chromatin, several nucleoli, and modest amounts of cytoplasm

In most cases, there is a majority of centrocytes.

Other options:

Option B: t(9;22) results in Philadelphia chromosome, which causes chronic myeloid leukemia.

Option C: t(8;14) is seen in Burkitt lymphoma.

Option D: t(11,14) is seen in mantle cell lymphoma.

questions.text: After the successful delivery of a baby, a grade 3b perineal tear is noticed. Which are the structures injured in this case?

choices.text: Perineum, perineal muscles, and >50% of external anal sphincter
Perineum, perineal muscles, and <50% of external anal sphincter
Perineum, perineal muscles, external and internal anal sphincter
Perineum, perineal muscles, anal sphincter complex and anorectal mucosa

questions.solution:
The perineum, perineal muscles, and >50% of the external anal sphincter are injured in Grade 3b perineal tears.

The lacerations of the perineum have been divided into four degrees:

  • First-degree: Injury to the skin of the perineum and/ or the vaginal mucosa.
  • Second-degree: Injury to the perineum and perineal muscles without the involvement of the anal sphincter.
  • Third-degree: Injury to the perineum and the anal sphincter complex. It is further classified as:
    • Grade 3a: Less than 50% of external anal sphincter (EAS) thickness torn.
    • Grade 3b: More than 50% of EAS thickness torn.
    • Grade 3c: Both EAS and internal anal sphincter (IAS) are torn.
  • Fourth-degree: Injury to the perineum, the anal sphincter complex (EAS and IAS), and the anorectal mucosa.

Obstetric anal sphincter injuries (OASIS) refer to both third- and fourth-degree perineal tears.

A central tear of the perineum - When the head penetrates first through the posterior vaginal wall, then through the perineal body and appears through the skin of the perineum. It usually occurs in patients with a contracted outlet.

questions.text: A 67-year-old male patient is found on rectal examination to have a hard, irregular nodule within his prostate. A biopsy of this lesion reveals the presence of crowded small glands lined by a single layer of cells with enlarged, prominent nucleoli. Immunohistochemistry shows the absence of the outer basal cell layer. From what portion of the prostate did this lesion most likely originate?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, palpation of hard, irregular nodules within the prostate with immunohistochemistry revealing the absence of an outer basal layer is suggestive of carcinoma prostate and most prostatic carcinomas arise from the peripheral zone.

Carcinoma of the prostate is the most common form of cancer affecting men. It arises in the peripheral zone of the gland, classically in a posterior location. 

The growth and survival of prostate cancer cells depend on androgens, which bind to the androgen receptor (AR) and induce the expression of pro-growth and pro-survival genes. Germline mutations of the tumor suppressor BRCA2 increase the risk of prostate cancer. Other acquired mutations include TPRSS2-ETS fusion genes. Prostatic Intraepithelial Neoplasia(PIN) has been described as the precursor lesion of carcinoma prostate.

On palpation, it is gritty, and firm in consistency. Histologically, most lesions are adenocarcinomas that shows small crowded glands lined by a single layer of neoplastic cells with mild to moderate degree of pleomorphism. The outer basal cell layer is absent. Immunohistochemically, basal cell markers are absent and α-methyl acyl-coenzyme A-racemase (AMACR) positive.

Grading of prostate cancer by the modified Gleason system correlates with pathologic stage and prognosis.

Grade Group 1 (≤6)

 Only individual discrete well-formed glands

Grade Group 2 (3 + 4)

Predominantly well-formed glands with a lesser component of poorly formed, fused, or cribriform glands

Grade Group 3 (4 + 3)

 Predominantly poorly formed/fused/cribriform glands with a lesser component of well-formed glands

Grade Group 4 (4+4/3+5/5+3)

Only poorly formed/fused/cribriform glands or predominantly mix of well-formed glands and lack of glands

Grade Group 5 (4+5/5+4/5+5)

 Lack of gland formation (or with necrosis) with or without poorly formed/fused/cribriform glands
