questions.text: Which of the following is the preferred treatment method in severe twin to twin transfusion syndrome?
questions.solution:
Laser photoablation of the placental vascular anastomoses is the preferred treatment for severe TTTS - Quintero stages 2 to 4.

Among the other options, septostomy is seldom done. Amnioreduction is a treatment modality that involves needle drainage of excessive amniotic fluid. Selective feticide is done only if the growth disturbances develop before 20 weeks.

Of all, selective fetoscopic laser photocoagulation (SFLP) is the preferred treatment modality as it is associated with better survival rates and reduced likelihood of recurrence.

Quintero staging:  

  • Stage I—Amniotic fluid discordant + Urine visible in donor bladder
  • Stage II—Stage I +Urine not visible in donor bladder
  • Stage III— Stage II + abnormal Doppler studies of the umbilical artery, ductus venosus, or umbilical vein.
  • Stage IV—frank ascites or hydrops in either twin.
  • Stage V—demise of either fetus.

questions.text:
A 55-year- old man is found to have hepatomegaly on physical examination. He also complains of a dark tan despite avoiding sun exposure and recently diagnosed diabetes mellitus. His liver microscopy is given on the slide below. Arrange the following organs affected in this condition in decreasing order of severity.
  1. Joints
  2. Pancreas
  3. Adrenal gland
  4. Pituitary gland
  5. Thyroid gland
questions.solution:
The patient suffers from hemochromatosis. Liver microscopy shows a Prussian blue-stained section showing extensive hemosiderin deposition stained blue with normal parenchymal architecture. Hemochromatosis is characterized principally by the deposition of hemosiderin in the following organs in decreasing order of severity: liver, pancreas, myocardium, pituitary gland, adrenal gland, thyroid, and parathyroid glands, joints, and skin

Hemochromatosis is an inherited or acquired metabolic disorder caused by excessive iron absorption. Iron overload leads to the accumulation of iron in parenchymal organs such as the liver and pancreas followed by heart, joints, and endocrine organs. Symptoms usually first appear in the fourth to fifth decades of life.

It is caused by mutations in the genes:

  • HJV
  • TFR2
  • HFE - The most common HFE mutations are C282Y, which causes inactivation of the protein and H63D

The manifestations of classic hemochromatosis include hepatomegaly, abdominal pain, abnormal skin pigmentation mainly in sun-exposed areas, defective glucose homeostasis or diabetes mellitus, cardiac dysfunction (arrhythmias, cardiomyopathy), and atypical arthritis. The testes may be small and atrophic resulting in reduced gonadotropin and testosterone levels.

In the liver, iron is initially seen as hemosiderin granules in the cytoplasm of periportal hepatocytes that stain with Prussian blue. As the iron load increases, there is progressive pigmentation of the rest of the lobule, bile duct epithelium, and Kupffer cells.

The characteristic triad of hemochromatosis includes:

  1. Micronodular cirrhosis
  2. Diabetes mellitus in 75% to 80% of patients
  3. Abnormal skin pigmentation in 75% to 80% of patients

In the early stages of accumulation, the liver is slightly enlarged, dense, and chocolate brown. Fibrous septa slowly develop, leading to a small, shrunken liver with a micronodular pattern of cirrhosis. The liver parenchyma is often dark brown to black in later stages due to overwhelming iron accumulation.

Skin pigmentation is mainly due to increased epidermal melanin production and partially due to hemosiderin deposition in the dermis. The combination of these pigments imparts a characteristic slate-gray color to the skin. 

The total body iron pool ranges from 2 to 6 gm in normal adults. In hemochromatosis, total iron accumulation may exceed 50 gm, more than one-third of which accumulates in the liver.

Related Pearl: Classification of Iron Overload

 Primary / Hereditary Hemochromatosis

HFE gene-related

  • Type 1: C282Y mutations of genes encoding HFE 

Non-HFE gene-related

  • Type 2: Juvenile hemochromatosis
    • 2a - HJV mutation (hemojuvelin)
    • 2b - HAMP mutation (Hepcidin)
  • Type 3: Transferrin receptor 2 (TfR2) related 
  • Type 4: Ferroportin-related HH 

Secondary / Acquired Hemochromatosis

Transfusion iron overload

  • Thalassemia major
  • Sideroblastic anemia
  • Chronic hemolytic anemias

Chronic liver disease

  • Alcoholic liver disease
  • Non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH)
  • Porphyria cutanea tarda

Miscellaneous

  • Congenital atransferrinemia
  • African iron overload (Bantu siderosis)

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about the procedure shown in the image?

choices.text: The patient is positioned with the diseased side up
It is contraindicated if the patient is having empyema
Lobectomy can be done via this proecdure
It allows direct visualization of the pleural cavity

questions.solution:
The procedure that is shown is VATS - Video-Assisted Thoracoscopic Surgery and it can be used in the debridement of empyema.

  • Many thoracic procedures can be done through VATS like pneumonectomy, lobectomy, empyema drainage, pleural biopsy, pleurodesis.
  • The patient is usually positioned with the disease side uppermost, having had a double lumen endotracheo-bronchial tube placed by the anesthetist to allow for single-lung ventilation.
  • Lung biopsy and the treatment of recurrent pneumothorax are the most frequent indications.
  • It is useful in malignant and other undiagnosed cases of pleural effusion as it allows direct visualization of the pleural cavity for complete drainage, talc pleurodesis, and multiple pleural biopsies.
  • The principal advantage is that a large incision is avoided resulting in less postoperative pain and a more rapid recovery.

Debridement of the empyema through the VATS approach is indicated when the infected fluid becomes fibrinopurulent and loculated. At the end of the procedure, chest drains are placed for dependent drainage. The following precautions must be noted before placing the drains

  • The drain should exit the skin anterior to the midaxillary line. If this is not done then the patient will have to lie on the tube which will cause pain and obstruction of the tube.
  • The course of the drain should be oblique to the skin, chest wall, and pleura, or else it will lead to kinking of the tube.

questions.text: A 60-year-old chronic alcoholic presents to you with distention of the abdomen, behavioural changes, yellowish discoloration of the skin, and decreased urine output. His laboratory investigations show elevated liver enzymes and creatinine. If kidneys appear normal on ultrasonography, what is the definitive treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features point to a diagnosis of hepatorenal syndrome and the definitve treatment of the same is liver transplantation. 
 
Hepatorenal syndrome (HRS) is a form of functional renal failure without any renal pathology that occurs in some patients with advanced cirrhosis or acute liver failure. The pathophysiological hallmark is severe renal vasoconstriction.
 
There are two types of HRS:
  • Type 1 HRS: There is progressive impairment in renal function and a marked decline in creatinine clearance within 1–2 weeks of presentation.
  • Type 2 HRS: There is a drop in glomerular filtration rate with elevated creatinine levels. It has a better prognosis than type 1 HRS.

Ultrasound of the kidney shows normal study and hyaline casts may be observed, indicating prerenal failure.

Management:

  • Stop diuretics
  • Albumin infusion at 1g/kg/day
  • Medical management:
    • Vasopressin analogs- terlipressin
    • Somatostatin analogs- octreotide
    • Alpha-adrenergic agonists- midodrine, noradrenaline
  • Definitive treatment: Liver transplantation

questions.text:
A pregnant woman comes for her antenatal check-up. She is in her third trimester now. She is a daily wage worker and reveals that she will continue working during the pregnancy. How much protein would you advise her to consume on a daily basis (RDA)?

RDA: Recommended dietary allowance
questions.solution:
The recommended dietary allowance of protein for a pregnant woman in the third trimester who is a heavy worker is 68 g/day.

According to the national institute of nutrition, the recommended RDA of protein is 46 g per day, regardless of the type of occupation and activity of the woman.

During pregnancy, the RDA of protein is increased in the second and third trimesters:

  • In the second trimester, it increases by 9.5 g. Therefore, the total protein requirement is 46+9.5 = 55.5 g/day per day.
  • In the third trimester, it increases by 22 g. Therefore, the total protein requirement is 46+22 = 68 g of protein per day.

questions.text: Which of the following opioids follow the marked graphical representation (A) in the given image?
questions.solution:
The graph is of the ceiling effect of opioids i.e. with some opioids when the ceiling is reached further increment in dose does not increase the effect. Morphine does not show the ceiling effect. 

The ceiling effect is particularly seen with respiratory depression i.e. higher doses do not produce further respiratory depression. Respiratory depression increases proportionally with dose.

The following opioids show a ceiling effect:

  • Buprenorphine
  • Butorphanol
  • Nalbuphine
  • Pentazocine

questions.text: A woman presents with a history of recurrent abortions. A hysterosalpingogram is done and shown below. The intercornual angle mentioned in the report is 70 degrees, and the cleft depth is reported to be <1cm.  Ultrasound reveals an intercornual distance of less than 4 cm. What is the treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a history of recurrent abortion with the given hysterosalpingogram and intercornual angle of 70 degrees, a cleft depth of less than 1cm, and intercornual distance of less than 4 cm suggests a diagnosis of a septate uterus, for which transcervical hysteroscopic resection of the septum is the appropriate method of treatment.

The procedure involves the resection of the septum under hysteroscopic guidance. Hence, it doesn't scar the uterus and avoids the necessity of cesarean sections for future pregnancies, improving the outcomes.

Intercornual distance <4 cm >4 cm
Fundal contour Convex, flat or minimally indented Fundal cleft >1 cm from the intercornual line
Intervening myometrium Thin (fibrous) Thick

Other options:

Jones' metroplasty, Strassmann's metroplasty, and Tompkins's metroplasty are surgeries that involve a transabdominal approach, which causes uterine scarring and is hence not preferred. Strassmann's metroplasty is a unification procedure for the bicornuate uterus.

questions.text: The culture used for antibiotic sensitivity testing in the given image is  ______
questions.solution:
Lawn culture is used for antibiotic sensitivity testing.

The lawn or carpet culture provides a uniform surface for the growth of the bacterium. It is prepared by flooding the surface of the plate with liquid culture. Lawn culture is used for:

  • Antibiotic sensitivity testing (disc method)
  • Bacteriophage typing
  • When a large amount of growth is required for the preparation of bacterial antigens and vaccines

Other methods used in bacterial culture: 

  • Streak culture: It is routinely used for the isolation of bacteria in pure culture from clinical specimens.
  • Lawn culture/carpet culture: It is used for bacteriophage typing and antibiotic sensitivity testing.
  • Stroke culture: It is employed for providing pure growth of bacterium for slide agglutination and other diagnostic tests.
  • Stab culture: It is used for the demonstration of gelatin liquefaction and oxygen requirements of the bacterium, for maintenance of stock cultures. 
  • Pour plate culture: It gives an estimate of viable bacterial count in a suspension.
  • Liquid culture: These are preferred for inocula containing antibiotics and other inhibitory substances.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presented with progressive, painless loss of vision in the right eye. There was no history of associated photopsia. On examination, a shifting fluid sign is present. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the presence of shifting fluid is suggestive of exudative retinal detachment (ED). 

Exudative RD is characterized by the accumulation of fluid beneath the retina in the absence of a retinal break or traction. Fluid leaks outside the vessels and accumulates under the retina. RD does not occur as long as the retinal pigment epithelium is pumping the leaking fluid into the choroidal circulation. 

Causes:

  • Inflammatory conditions like choroiditis, posterior scleritis
  • Choroidal tumors like melanoma
  • Toxemia of pregnancy
  • Central serous retinopathy
  • Coats disease

Patients may present with painless progressive visual field defects without photopsia. Floaters may be present if there is an associated vitritis.

Clinical signs include

  • Convex configuration of the retinal detachment, with a smooth surface
  • A detached retina is very mobile
  • Shifting fluid sign - Subretinal fluid causes detachment of the retinal portion under which it accumulates. In the upright position, the fluid collects under the inferior retina. But in the supine position, the inferior retina flattens and the fluid shifts posteriorly, which leads to detachment of the superior retina.
  • The cause of the RD may be apparent. 
  • Leopard spots - Scattered areas of clumped subretinal pigment may be seen after the detachment has flattened.

Retinal detachment (RD) is the result of the accumulation of fluid between the retina and the retinal pigment epithelium. It is classified into the following:

  • Rhegmatogenous RD - due to a tear or break in the retina
  • Secondary RD - due to some other preceding event
    • Exudative RD
    • Tractional RD

The image shows the shifting fluid sign and late-phase fluorescein angiogram showing hyperfluorescent spots with a leopard spot pattern in the posterior fundus and staining of the arteries and an avascular area in the nasal region, respectively.

Other options:

Option A: Breaks in the Descemet membrane may occur due to

  • Corneal enlargement in infantile glaucoma. Haab striae are horizontal concentric lines representing the breaks in Descemet’s membrane, seen in patients with congenital glaucoma.
  • Deformations such as keratoconus
  • Birth trauma

The image below shows Haab's striae. 

Option B -  Rhegmatogenous RD: In this condition, fluid accumulates after a break (tear) occurs in the retina. The most dangerous type of retinal break is a horseshoe tear. The most dangerous location of the retinal break is the superior temporal retina. Risk factors for the development of rhegmatogenous RD are:

  • High myopia
  • Blunt trauma
  • Previous cataract surgery (aphakia and pseudophakia)
  • Lattice degeneration of the retina

Clinical features of rhegmatogenous RD:

  • Symptoms
    • Photopsia: Flashes of light due to vitreoretinal traction at the site of the break. Photopsia is symptom-specific for rhegmatogenous detachment. 
    • Floaters: Due to associated vitreous haemorrhage
    • Visual field defect: A black curtain/veil in front of the eye
  • Signs
    • Shaffer's sign: Pigments in the anterior vitreous (tobacco dusting) are a feature of fresh retinal detachment.
    • The detached retina is convex in its configuration.
    • The surface is corrugated with undulations.

Option C - Tractional RD: It occurs when the vitreous has an abnormally strong attachment to the retina. With vitreous liquefaction and subsequent contraction, the retina is pulled away from the retinal pigment epithelium without a retinal break.

  • Causes
    • Proliferative diabetic retinopathy
    • Retinopathy of prematurity
    • Eales' disease
  • Signs
    • The detached retina is concave in its configuration.
    • No breaks are seen.

The image below shows the tractional segments and bands with a concave retina.

Knotting techniques :

questions.text: A 48-year-old premenopausal woman complained of heavy menstrual bleeding and bleeding between her cycles. The patient was in good health, with no other complaints. No significant past history. She was referred for a pelvic ultrasound which revealed a 12 x 11mm mass within the endometrial cavity surrounded by free fluid. Doppler US established internal vascularity via a single feeder vessel. Which among the following is not a risk factor for this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical case described along with visualization of a feeding vessel on ultrasonography is characteristic of an endometrial polyp, and oral contraceptive pills are not a risk factor.

Risk factors for development of endometrial polyps include:

  • Increasing age
  • Obesity
  • Tamoxifen use 
  • Some studies suggest an association with hormone replacement therapy

Oral contraceptive pills appear to be protective. For women taking tamoxifen, the levonorgestrel-releasing intrauterine system (LNG-IUS) was investigated and shown to lower endometrial polyp formation rates.

Estrogen and progesterone have been implicated in the growth of endometrial polyps, and higher receptor levels are seen compared with the normal endometrium.

Benign endometrial polyps commonly occur at all ages, with their greatest prevalence after age 50. They are a common cause of postmenopausal bleeding. Women with polyps may present with heavy cyclic or intermenstrual bleeding, or without complaints as an incidental finding on imaging.

On transvaginal sonography, endometrial polyps may appear as a nonspecific area of endometrial thickening or a round or elongated hyperechoic focal mass within the endometrial cavity. Some polyps may contain cystic spaces corresponding to dilated endometrial glands.  On color or power Doppler, endometrial polyps typically have only one arterial feeding vessel.

Treatment is by hysteroscopic polypectomy for symptomatic women or women with risk factors for malignant transformation. For asymptomatic women without risk factors, conservative management with regular monitoring can be done.

questions.text: The drug of choice in anaphylactic shock is?

choices.text: Adenosine 6 mg followed by 12 mg IV

questions.solution:
Adrenaline 0.5 mg 1/1000 by intramuscular route (IM) is the drug of choice for treatment of anaphylactic shock. Hence it is the answer here.

In case the patient develops life threatening condition, adrenaline 0.25 mg IV is given.

Note : This is a controversial question. The following inference from journal may help to clarify the concept.

  • As vasodilatation is the main pathological change early in anaphylaxis, this enables the subcutaneous or intramuscular absorption of adrenaline to be rapid and effective.
  • Thus, when the disease is treated early and is progressing slowly, or venous access is difficult or the patient is unmonitored, intramuscular adrenaline has advantages in terms of safety and is usually effective.
  • Later, when intravascular volume is depleted and shock occurs with a life threatening situation, or there is severe dyspnoea or airway compromise, the intravenous route is necessary to achieve optimal absorption.

questions.text: A patient who underwent parotidectomy developed sweating that occurs when he smells or tastes food. It was suspected to be due to aberrant regeneration of parasympathetic fibres to the parotid gland. Which of the following foramina do these fibres pass through?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of sweating occurring while smelling or tasting food, secondary to aberrant regeneration of parasympathetic fibres, suggests Frey's syndrome. These fibres to the parotid gland pass through the foramen ovale and jugular foramen, marked as 2 and 4 in the image, respectively.

Parasympathetic nerves are secretomotor to the parotid gland. The preganglionic parasympathetic fibres begin in the inferior salivatory nucleus. These fibres travel via the glossopharyngeal nerve and reach the tympanic plexus via the tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve through the jugular foramen. Then, these fibres travel via the lesser petrosal nerve and come out of the foramen ovale to relay in the otic ganglion. The postganglionic parasympathetic fibres emerging from the otic ganglion pass via the auriculotemporal nerve to reach the parotid gland.

The image given below shows the parasympathetic pathway of the parotid gland.

Frey's syndrome occurs due to aberrant regeneration of the parasympathetic nerve fibres of the auriculotemporal nerve. This results in abnormal innervation of sweat glands on the face. Patients usually present with sweating, warmth, and redness of the face when they smell or taste food. 

The sympathetic supply to the parotid gland is derived from the plexus around the middle meningeal artery.

Sensory supply to the parotid gland is from the auriculotemporal nerve, and the parotid capsule is from the sensory fibres of the greater auricular nerve.

Foraminas marked in the image are:

  2. Foramen ovale
  3. Foramen spinosum

questions.text:
Match the following images with the corresponding Streptococcal skin/soft tissue infection.

A - Cellulitis

B - Erysipelas

C - Impetigo

D - Myositis
questions.solution:
The images are matched as follows :

Column A (From the thumbnail image) Column B 
1 D - Myositis
2 C - Impetigo
3

B - Erysipelas
4  A - Cellulitis

The portal of entry of streptococci is responsible for the presenting clinical features that may range from local suppuration to a diffuse rapidly spreading infection.

Myositis : 

Invasive Streptococcus pyogenes infections result in streptococcal toxic shock syndrome characterized by shock, bacteremia, respiratory failure, and multiorgan failure. These fulminant symptoms include necrotizing fasciitis, myositis, and soft tissue infections at other sites. Such 

Impetigo : 

Localised infection of superficial layers of skin is called impetigo. It presents with superficial vesicles that may later get eroded and crusted. It can be of a bullous and a non-bullous type and most commonly occurs in children.

Erysipelas :

Erysipelas is caused by the entry of S. pyogenes, β-Hemolytic Group A Streptococci into the skin. It presents with raised, erythematous sharply demarcated rapidly spreading skin lesions, along with systemic symptoms. Leg and face are the most common sites.

Cellulitis :

It is usually an acute rapidly spreading infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissues presenting with diffuse erythema, warmth and swelling. It is most commonly caused by group A streptococcus. It occurs following mild trauma, burns, wounds, or surgical incisions. In cellulitis, the lesion is not raised, and the line between the involved and uninvolved tissue is indistinct. This helps in differentiating it from erysipelas.

Related Pearl: Skin and soft tissue lesions caused by Streptococcus

Streptococcus causes a variety of skin and soft tissue infections. These include:

questions.text:
A female baby presented with bilious vomiting and abdominal distension on the 5th day of life. The mother informs that the child has not passed meconium yet. Barium enema of the patient shows the following. A rectal biopsy is taken to confirm the diagnosis. Which of the following statements are true regarding this condition?
  1. The disease is more common in females
  2. The rectum is always affected
  3. Disease limited to the rectosigmoid is termed short-segment disease
  4. The aganglionic region may have a grossly normal or dilated appearance
  5. Chagas disease shares the same pathophysiology as this disease
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the barium enema image showing a dilated right colon is suggestive of Hirschsprung's disease. Among the given statements, 2,3 and 5 are true.

Hirschsprung disease is also known as congenital aganglionic megacolon. The premature arrest of normal migration of neural crest cells from the cecum to the rectum produces aganglionosis of the distal intestinal segment. This causes functional obstruction of the affected bowel and proximal dilation. Diagnosis requires documenting the absence of ganglion cells within the affected segment.

Heterozygous loss-of-function mutations in the receptor tyrosine kinase RET account for the majority of familial and sporadic Hirschsprung disease cases. There is an association between Downs syndrome and Hirschsprung disease as well. The disease is more common in males, but, when present in females, the affected aganglionic segment tends to be longer.

Diagnosis : 

Histologic confirmation that ganglion cells are absent within the affected segment through hematoxylin and eosin-stained sections or immunohistochemical stains for acetylcholinesterase.

Based on the segments affected, they are classified into -

  • Short-segment Hirschsprung disease - Disease limited to the rectosigmoid segment
  • Long-segment Hirschsprung disease - Disease having proximal extension beyond the rectosigmoid segment

The rectum is always affected, but the length of the additional involved segments varies widely. In most cases, the abnormality extends to the sigmoid colon, but in severe cases, the entire colon may be involved.

The aganglionic region may have a grossly normal or contracted appearance. The normally innervated proximal colon undergoes progressive dilation and may become massively distended (congenital megacolon) as a result of the distal obstruction.

Causes of acquired megacolon :

  • Chagas disease (same pathophysiology as Hirschsprung)
  • Obstruction by a neoplasm or inflammatory stricture
  • A complication of ulcerative colitis
  • Visceral myopathy
  • Association with psychosomatic disorders

questions.text: An elderly diabetic man presents with a history of difficulty breathing, cough, and fever. He says he had had shortness of breath for the last week, which has worsened in the last 2 days. He has received his routine flu shot 1 month back. He gives a history of international travel 10 days back. His SpO2 is recorded to be 89%. High-resolution CT scan shows the presence of bilateral, multilobar ground-glass opacification. Which of the following statements is true regarding the structure of the virus?

choices.text: Protein is of host cell origin

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette showing breathlessness, fever, and cough with a low oxygen saturation and ground-glass opacities on HRCT is indicative of COVID-19 disease caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus belonging to the coronavirus family which is an enveloped, single-stranded RNA virus, susceptible to bile salts.

Coronaviruses are enveloped helically symmetrical viruses. It also causes severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS-CoV). The virus has been named SARS-CoV-2 (severe acute respiratory syndrome- coronavirus-2) and the disease it causes has been named coronavirus disease 2019 (abbreviated COVID-19).

Being enveloped contributes to their lipid solvent susceptibility. This is the reason alcohol-based hand sanitizers and soaps are used. The lipid membrane dissolution and protein denaturation by ethanol leads to membrane disruption and inhibition of metabolism.

Properties of enveloped virus:

  • Envelope confers chemical, antigenic, and biological properties on the virus.
  • It is made of lipid (phospholipid) and protein (glycoprotein).
  • Lipid is largely of host cell origin, whereas glycoprotein is virus coded.
  • The lipid is acquired when the viral nucleocapsid buds through a cellular membrane during maturation. Budding occurs only at sites where virus-specific proteins have been inserted into the host cell membrane.
  • Protein subunits may be seen projecting on the surface of envelope called peplomer. E.g, Hemagglutinin and Neuraminidase of Influenza virus.

The following are the differences between enveloped and non-enveloped viruses.

 Enveloped viruses Non-enveloped viruses
Ether sensitive Ether resistant
Heat labile Heat stable
Pleomorphic Non-pleomorphic
Susceptible to bile salts Resistant to bile salts

questions.text: What does Billing's method of contraception refer to?
questions.solution:
Billing’s method of contraception refers to the cervical mucus method. It is also called ovulation method.

The properties of the cervical mucus change during the menstrual cycle. The female partner can predict the fertile period by examining her cervical mucus.

Under the influence of estrogen, the mucus increases in quantity and becomes more slippery and elastic i.e. wet days. This continues till it reaches a peak. After this, under the influence of progesterone, it becomes thicker, scanty i.e. dry days.

Abstinence is advised during the wet days till 4 days after the peak day. The safe period includes the dry days after menses till the appearance of mucus and from the 4th day after the peak day.

questions.text: A 34-year-old  male patient presents to the emergency department with acute onset of severe abdominal pain. The patient gives a history of recurrent episodes of epigastric pain and burning sensation for the past few months. The supine abdominal radiograph of the patient is given below. What is the characteristic sign shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The above x-ray shows the presence of air in the bilateral subphrenic spaces and a linear density on the ventral surface of the liver (arrow), known as the falciform ligament sign. It is seen in the pneumoperitoneum. 

The acute presentation of abdominal pain with similar episodes in the past, along with the given abdomen x-ray suggests pneumoperitoneum. Bilateral subphrenic free air is seen and the arrow mark shown here is the falciform ligament. This peritoneal fold is an embryological remnant of the umbilical artery connecting the anterior abdominal wall to the anterosuperior surface of the liver. It is invisible under normal situations; however, when surrounded by intraperitoneal free air, it may become visible as a vertical band of soft tissue parallel to the right border of the spine.

Causes of pneumoperitoneum:

  • Bowel perforation
    1. Peptic ulcer
    2. Ischemic bowel
    3. Necrotizing enterocolitis
  • Small bowel perforation
    1. Trauma
    2. Penetrating injuries
  • Injury during surgery/laparoscopy

Radiological signs in pneumoperitoneum:

  • Bowel-related signs
    • Double-wall sign (also known as Rigler's sign): Both the outer and inner walls of the bowel are visible.
    • Telltale triangle sign (also known as triangle sign): A radiolucent triangle of gas between three loops of bowel or between two loops of bowel and the abdominal wall.
  • Peritoneal ligament–related signs
    • Football sign - the abdominal cavity is outlined by gas from a perforated viscus, seen in massive pneumoperitoneum.
    • Falciform ligament sign - Falciform or medial umbilical ligaments may be seen due to free gas on either side of the ligaments. 
    • Lateral umbilical ligament sign (also known as inverted "V" sign) - Free gas routines the lateral umbilical ligament.
    • Urachus sign
  • Right upper quadrant signs
    • Morison's pouch sign - a triangular area of gas in the right upper quadrant, usually bound by the 11th rib in the right upper quadrant in the area of Morrison's pouch
    • Cupola sign - Gas under the right and left hemidiaphragm joining in the midline, seen on chest x-ray.
    • Fissure for ligamentum teres sign
    • Hepatic edge sign
    • Lucent liver sign
    • Periportal free gas sign

Other options: 

Football sign - Supine radiograph where the peritoneal layer is enhanced over the entire abdominal cavity. This is seen in a large pneumoperitoneum. 

Cupola sign - Free air below central tendon of the diaphragm in the midline

Lateral umbilical ligament sign (or inverted 'V' sign) is seen in the pelvis representing free gas outlining the lateral umbilical ligaments.

questions.text: An unimmunized child developed a fever, cough, and conjunctival congestion. 4 days later he developed a rash behind his ears which soon became widespread as shown in the image below. On examination, bluish-white spots were seen on the inner aspect of the cheek. Which of the following statements is false regarding the complications associated with this condition?

choices.text: Myocarditis is the most common cause of death
Hemorrhagic form of the disease is often fatal
Low levels of retinol is associated with increased  mortality
Acute otitis media is the most common complication

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and the image showing a morbilliform rash are suggestive of measles. The incorrect statement about the complication related to this condition is that myocarditis is the most common cause of death. Pneumonia is the most common cause of death in measles. 

Pneumonia in measles can be giant cell pneumonia which is caused by the virus directly or can be due to superadded bacterial infection.

Measles infection is caused by a single-stranded, lipid-enveloped RNA Paramyxovirus. It has an incubation period of 8-12 days, after which the prodrome phase begins with mild fever, conjunctivitis, upper respiratory tract infection, and pathognomic Koplik spots. These spots are small, bluish-white ulcerations on the inner aspect of the cheek at the level of the premolars.

A maculopapular rash appears 4 days after fever, which begins at the face and spreads to the torso and extremities. Lymphadenopathy may be present. Patients can transmit infection 3 days before and 4-6 days after the onset of rash. The morbilliform rash is shown below. 

The most common complication of measles is acute otitis media. Sinusitis and mastoiditis are also seen. Black measles or hemorrhagic measles is a fatal complication characterized by hemorrhagic skin eruptions. It is rarely seen nowadays. Other complications include croup, tracheitis, bronchiolitis, diarrhea and vomiting, febrile seizures, and encephalitis. Myocarditis is a rare complication of measles.

Subacute Sclerosing Panencephalitis is a rare but fatal complication characterized by cognitive decline, spasticity of limbs, and seizures. It is insidious in onset and clinical manifestations usually begin 7-10 years after primary measles infection. It is caused due to persistent infection with a genetically altered variant of the measles virus within the central nervous system.

Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells are pathognomonic of measles. These are multinucleated giant cells formed by the fusion of infected cells. The image below shows a slide of a lymph node biopsy showing a Warthin–Finkeldey giant cell. 

Low serum retinol levels in children with measles are associated with higher morbidity and mortality and hence Vitamin A therapy is indicated for all patients with measles. The management is mainly supportive. There is no role for antivirals.

questions.text: A class is being conducted on the various structures present in the next. Neck dissection is performed, and the given image shows the lateral aspect of the neck. All of the following muscles are supplied by nerves arising from the structure 'A' and its branches, except _____.
questions.solution:
The structure marked as A in the above image is the inferior root of ansa cervicalis, and it supplies all the above-mentioned muscles, except the thyrohyoid.

The inferior root descends on the lateral side of the internal jugular vein, crosses it a little below the middle of the neck, and continues forwards to join the superior root anterior to the common carotid artery, forming the ansa cervicalis (ansa hypoglossi).

Ansa cervicalis: 

  • It is a loop of nerves that are a part of the cervical plexus. It is made up of two roots. The upper root has contributions from the first cervical spinal nerve, and the lower root has contributions from the second and third cervical spinal nerves.
  • It innervates sternohyoid, sternothyroid, and omohyoid muscles.

The thyrohyoid and geniohyoid are not supplied by ansa cervicalis. They are supplied by the first cervical spinal nerve, via the hypoglossal nerve.

questions.text: A  patient with elevated blood pressure even after the medical intervention is found to have a solitary adrenal adenoma on imaging studies. A tissue sample of the adenoma taken during laparoscopic adrenalectomy is sent to the laboratory for you to examine. The histopathological picture is as shown below. Which of the following is false about this condition?

choices.text: More common in men than women
The image is showing spironolactone bodies

questions.solution:
The given image shows the presence of eosinophilic, laminated cytoplasmic inclusions, known as spironolactone bodies which are found after treatment with spironolactone and the presence of a solitary adenoma is indicative of Conn syndrome. This is more common in females than males. 

Hyperaldosteronism is the increased secretion of aldosterone. It can be primary or secondary. Primary hyperaldosteronism is autonomous overproduction of aldosterone, with suppression of the renin-angiotensin system and decreased plasma renin activity. The two primary causes of primary hyperaldosteronism are adrenocortical adenoma and bilateral adrenal hyperplasia. 

When primary hyperaldosteronism is caused by a solitary aldosterone-secreting adenoma, the condition is referred to as Conn syndrome. This occurs most frequently in mid-adult life. Up to half of the cases have somatic mutations of KCNJ5 which encodes a potassium channel protein.

Pateints with primary hyperadlosteronism primarily present with hypertension and hypokalemia. The diagnosis of primary hyperaldosteronism is confirmed by elevated ratios of plasma aldosterone concentration to plasma renin activity.

Aldosterone-producing adenomas show the presence of eosinophilic, laminated cytoplasmic inclusions, known as spironolactone bodies. These spironolactone bodies are found after treatment with the antihypertensive drug spironolactone.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man was recently diagnosed with secondary syphilis and was started on treatment. He was admitted to the hospital with complaints of fever with chills, headache, and myalgia noticed 3 days after starting treatment. His pulse rate is 92/min and his blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg. What is the next line of management in this case?

choices.text: Decreasing the dose of the offending drug
Treatment with antipyretics for symptomatic relief

questions.solution:
The given clinical picture of fever with chills and headache after treatment with a drug for secondary syphilis is suggestive of Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction and is associated with the use of penicillin in syphilis disease.

Symptomatic management of pyrexia with antipyretics is the next line of management. Penicillin treatment need not be interrupted during the course of the treatment and thereafter. Steroids are usually not indicated.

Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction is a host immune reaction due to the release of spirochetal antigen by the dying T.pallidum on treatment with penicillin. This occurs in primary and in most cases of secondary syphilis after several hours of the first dose of penicillin.

It is characterized by fever, shivering, myalgia,headache and exacerbation of lesions. Physical findings of tachycardia, increased respiratory rate and vasodilation with mild hypotension can be observed. Additionally, increased neutrophil count may be present.

The treatment of syphilis is based on the CDC’s 2015 guidelines:

CSF abnormal: Treat as neurosyphilis

CSF Abnormal: Treat as Neurosyphilis

questions.text: When the pH of chyme entering the duodenum falls to 3.5, an inhibitory reflex on gastric emptying is initiated. Which of the following will not initiate the same reflex?
questions.solution:
The inhibitory reflex that is initiated in response to acidic chyme (pH 3.5) is the enterogastric reflex. This reflex may be initiated by the distension of the duodenum (not ileal distension).

Enterogastric inhibitory reflex refers to the slowing or stopping of gastric emptying in response to the following duodenal factors:

  • Distention of the duodenum -too much chyme in the duodenum (Option A)
  • The presence of any irritation of the duodenal mucosa
  • The acidity of the duodenal chyme
  • The osmolality of the chyme - either hypotonic or hypertonic fluids (Option B) initiates enterogastric inhibitory reflexes. Thus, the flow of non-isotonic fluids into the small intestine is regulated. This prevents rapid changes in electrolyte concentrations in the extracellular fluid during the absorption of the intestinal contents.
  • The presence of certain breakdown products in the chyme, especially those of proteins (Option C) and to a lesser extent, of fats. 

Emptying of the stomach is also controlled moderately by stomach factors like:

  • the degree of filling in the stomach
  • the excitatory effect of gastrin on stomach peristalsis

Hormones involved in feedback inhibition of gastric emptying:

  • Cholecystokinin (CCK)- most important. It is secreted from the jejunal mucosa in response to fatty substances in the chyme.
  • Secretin- Released from duodenal mucosa in response to gastric acid passing through the pylorus.
  • Glucose-dependent insulinotropic peptide or gastric inhibitory peptide (GIP) - released from small intestinal mucose in response to fat and carbohydrates in the chyme.

questions.text: The district you are in charge of has a spike in the number of pediatric COVID cases. You are assigned the responsibility of setting up a Dedicated COVID-19 Health Centre (DCHC). Which of the following is not an ideal centre for establishing a DCHC?
questions.solution:
Medical colleges are not converted to dedicated COVID-19 Health Centres (DCHCs). They have the infrastructure to meet the needs of higher care and are used to establish dedicated COVID-19 Hospitals (DCHs). 

COVID-19 hospitals are categorized into three types. As per the management algorithm for COVID-19 cases, infrastructure and other health system requirements vary by symptoms. They are as follows :

  • Severe cases - dedicated COVID-19 hospitals (DCHs),
  • Moderate symptoms, particularly those requiring oxygen support - dedicated COVID-19 health centres (DCHCs) and
  • Mild or asymptomatic cases - home isolated / COVID-19 care centres (CCCs)

DCHCs have hospital beds with facilities to cater for Oxygen delivery with/without High Dependency Units (HDU) and are not equipped to take on severe COVID-19 cases.

DCHs typically have all components of hospital care including Intensive Care Units (ICU) and are usually the preferred centres for severe COVID-19 patients.

Examples where DCHC/Level 2 Care can be established :

  • Primary Health Centres (PHC),
  • Community Health Centres (CHCs)
  • Small District Hospitals (DH)
  • Urban Health facilities

These locations will have to be upgraded and mentoring by a higher centre is required.

Examples where DCH/Level 3 Care can be established :

  • Medical colleges
  • Large district hospitals

These have the infrastructure to meet the needs of higher care, but often need re-purposing of prevailing structure to cater for the special needs of pediatric COVID cases.

questions.text: The electrostatic repulsion between fibrinogen molecules prevents them from getting aggregated in plasma. What is this caused by?

choices.text: Positive charge by histidine and lysine residues
Negative charge by histidine and lysine residues
Negative charge by aspartate and glutamate residues
Positive charge by aspartate and glutamate residues

questions.solution:
Negative charges contributed by aspartate and glutamate cause the electrostatic repulsion between fibrinogen molecules that prevents aggregation. 

Fibrinogen (factor I) is a soluble plasma glycoprotein. It has three polypeptide chains -Aα, Bβ, and γ, that are covalently linked by disulfide bonds. 

The Aα and Bβ chains have N-terminal A and B portions, which are called fibrinopeptide A (FPA) and fibrinopeptide B (FPB), respectively. They are highly negatively charged as they contain aspartate and glutamate residues. These negative charges cause electrostatic repulsion between fibrinogen molecules and prevent their aggregation. It also contributes to the solubility of fibrinogen in plasma.

Thrombin acts on fibrinogen, cleaving fibrinopeptide A and B from fibrinogen to form fibrin monomers. Further polymerization of these fibrin monomers to dimers and higher oligomers occurs spontaneously.

Fibrin oligomers get stabilized by factor XIIIa, which covalently cross-links adjacent fibrin monomers. This cross-linking leads to a stable fibrin clot.  Factor XIIIa is a transglutaminase that is formed when thrombin acts on Factor XIII. 

Note: The imidazole group in histidine has a pK value of 6.1 and hence is an effective buffer at the physiological pH of 7.4. The buffering capacity of plasma proteins and hemoglobin is mainly due to histidine residues.

questions.text: Which of the following feature in the fundus of myopic patients, is most likely to predispose them to the development of retinal detachment?
questions.solution:
The presence of lattice degeneration in the fundus of myopic patients predisposes them to the development of retinal detachment.

Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment is much more common in high myopia. The presence of the following findings at an increased frequency in myopes predisposes them to the development of retinal detachment.

  • Posterior vitreous detachment
  • Lattice degeneration
  • Asymptomatic atrophic holes
  • Myopic macular holes
  • Giant retinal tears

Other fundus features of pathological myopia:

  • Lacquer cracks - They are ruptures in the RPE-Bruch membrane-choriocapillaris complex and appear as fine irregular yellow line crisscrossing at the posterior pole. They can lead to choroidal neovascularization.
  • Coin haemorrhages - They develop from lacquer cracks
  • Fuchs spot - It is a raised, circular, pigmented lesion developed at the macula after a subretinal hemorrhage has been absorbed
  • Pale tessellated appearance of the fundus
  • Myopic crescent - in the temporal retina

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents with purple, pruritic plaques on the flexor aspect of the forearm which appeared 7 months back. New lesions have appeared on the other arm after abrasions at the same site. A skin biopsy done to confirm the diagnosis shows the following histology. What is the structure marked?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of lichen planus. The structure marked in the histopathological image of lichen planus is civatte bodies.

Civatte bodies/Colloid bodies are damaged basal keratinocytes that have undergone apoptosis, consist largely of keratin intermediate filaments, and are almost always covered with immunoglobulins. They are found particularly in the lower layers of the epidermis. They are usually seen in lichenoid dermatosis.

Lichen planus is the most typical lichenoid dermatosis. It is characterized by idiopathic inflammation of skin and mucosal tissues. It has mostly a chronic course with frequent relapses.

Lichen Planus manifests as pruritic, purple, polygonal, planar, papules, and plaques - which are the 6Ps of lichen planus. It also exhibits Wickham striae (thin white lacy lines on the lesion), Koebner phenomenon (new lesions at sites of skin trauma).

Histopathology of lichen planus typically shows interface dermatitis, saw toothing, Max Joseph’s space, Civatte or colloid bodies.

The following image shows the histology of Lichen planus with loss of rete ridges, loss of stratum basale, and interface dermatitis.

The following image shows lesions characteristic of lichen planus - Pruritic, purple, polygonal, planar, papules, and plaques:

Squamous cell carcinoma may arise from mucosal and paramucosal lichen planus.

Other options :

Option A: Schaumann bodies are seen in non-caseating granuloma of sarcoidosis. They are laminated concretions composed of calcium and protein

Option B: Asteroid bodies are seen in non-caseating granuloma of sarcoidosis. They are stellate inclusions within giant cells.

Option C: Donovan bodies are characteristic of in granuloma inguinale (also called donovanosis). They are due to macrophages encapsulating Klebsiella granulomatis coccobacilli.

questions.text: An Rh-negative G2P1 mother delivered her Rh-positive baby by cesarean section. Kleihaeur Betke test, as shown in the image, was done. Which of the following statements is true regarding the test?

choices.text: Fetal erythrocytes are the ghost cells
The reagent used is citric acid

questions.solution:
The reagent used for the Kleihauer-Betke test is citric acid.

Kleihauer-Betke test is the most commonly used quantitative test used to detect fetomaternal hemorrhage i.e., the approximate volume of fetal blood entering the maternal circulation. It is also known as the acid elution test.

The principle behind it is that fetal erythrocytes contain hemoglobin F, which is more resistant to acid elution than hemoglobin A.

After exposure to acid, only fetal hemoglobin remains, such that after staining, the fetal erythrocytes appear red and adult cells appear as “ghosts.” Fetal cells are counted and expressed as a percentage of adult cells.

Flow cytometry is the best test for the quantification of fetomaternal hemorrhage. It is more sensitive and accurate as compared to the Kleihauer-Betke test. 

Flow cytometry can analyze a larger number of cells and is not influenced by maternal levels of fetal hemoglobin and fetal levels of maternal hemoglobin. It utilizes monoclonal antibodies to HbF or to the D antigen followed by quantification by fluorescence.

questions.text: A middle-aged man is being evaluated for complaints of seizures and visual disturbances. His magnetic resonance image (MRI) of the brain is as shown. The transmission of the causative agent, in this case, is an example of?
questions.solution:
The MRI brain is showing multiple cysticerci within the brain suggesting neurocysticercosis caused by Taenia solium. The transmission of Taenia solium is an example of cyclo-zoonoses. 

Zoonoses are diseases and infections which are naturally transmitted from a vertebrate to man. They can be transmitted from either animals or other humans.

Cyclo-zoonoses is a type of zoonotic transmission that requires >1 vertebrate host species to complete the developmental cycle of the agent. They do not require any invertebrate hosts. Examples are the human taeniases, echinococcosis, and pentastomid infections.

Cysticercosis is a condition that occurs due to the infection by the larval stage of T. solium. Neurocysticercosis is the most serious and most common form of cysticercosis. 

Clinical features of neurocysticercosis include seizures, increased intracranial pressure, hydrocephalus, psychiatric disturbances, meningoencephalitis, transient paresis, and visual disturbances. 

Diagnosis:

  • Biopsy - the microscopy of the lesion shows invaginated scolex with suckers and hooks. It provides a definitive diagnosis
  • Imaging techniques -  
    • X-rays - may demonstrate calcified cysticerci in the subcutaneous tissues, muscles and skull
    • Computed tomography scan - best method to demonstrate dead calcified cysts
    • MRI - demonstrates non-calcified cysts, ventricular cysts, spinal cysticerci
  • Serology -  
    • Antibody detection - by ELISA in the serum or cerebrospinal fluid
    • Antigen detection - by ELISA. Their presence indicates recent infection
  • Ophthalmoscopy - to detect ocular cysticercosis

Treatment: Excision, praziquantel, albendazole.

  • Zoo-anthroponoses
  • Amphixenoses

questions.text: A patient with Hodgkin’s disease on chemotherapy with an alkylating agent develops behavioral disturbances and experiences sedation. He presented to the emergency room with a disulfiram-like reaction. What is the drug being described here?
questions.solution:
The most likely alkylating agent being described here is procarbazine. It is associated with behavioural disturbances and sedation. Concomitant CNS depressants should be avoided.

Procarbazine is a weak MAO inhibitor and can potentiate tyramine and catecholamines action. It also has disulfiram-like actions and alcohol should be avoided.

questions.text: In a group of 50 adult males, the mean height is 170 cm. The standard deviation is 2.5 cms. How many will have height between 170 to 172.5 cm, if the distribution is normal?
questions.solution:
17 men will have height between 170 to 172.5 cm.

According to the empirical rule of normal distribution, 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviations of the mean.

In this case,

S.D = 2.5 cm, mean = 170 cm

170 + 2.5 = 172.5 cm, 170 – 2.5 cm = 167.5 cm

Hence 68% men will have height between 167.5 cm and 172.5 cms. And 34% men will have height between 170 cm and 172.5 cms.

34/100 × 50 = 17 men will have height between 170 cms and 172.5 cms. 

Related Pearl: Normal Distribution

The normal distribution curve is the most common shape taken by continuous data distributions. It is also called bell curve (bell-shaped) or Gaussian distribution after mathematician Karl Friedrich Gauss.

The following is an image of three different normal distribution curves.

Salient features of the standard normal distribution:

  • Defined by two parameters: the mean and the standard deviation
  • Has mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1
  • Mean = median = mode
  • Symmetric and have bell-shaped curves with a single peak
  • Total area under the curve is 1
  • Frequency of values is more around the center and less around the tails
  • No skew in the curve
  • Data like blood pressure, heights, IQ scores, etc. form a normal distribution
  • The empirical rule of a normal distribution:
    • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean (mean ± 1 SD)
    • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 2 SD)
    • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 3 SD)

Related Pearl: Variance, Deviation Scores and Standard Deviation

  • Deviation Scores: 
    • The deviation score of an element in distribution is the difference between the mean of the distribution and the element itself, i.e., subtracting the distribution’s mean from the element.
    • Denoted by the letter x
    • For example, if 29 and 15 are elements in a distribution that has a mean of 22, the deviation score of 29 would be (29 – 22) = 7 and the deviation score of 15 would be (15 – 22) = - 7.
    • Sum of all the deviation scores of elements in distribution will be zero
  • Variance (also called mean square) 
    • The mean of the squares of all the deviation scores of the distribution
    • Used to measure how far data is spread out
    • If the variance is zero, it indicates that all the elements in the distribution are the same and that there is no variability.
    • Population variance (σ2) is calculated as:
      • Find the deviation score of each element in the distribution
      • Square each of the deviation scores.
      • Obtain the mean of all these squared deviation scores
  •  
    • Sample variance (s2): 
      • more commonly used in statistics than population variance
      • The denominator is n-1 (and not N as it is in population variance)
      • For small samples, it is better to use n-1 in the denominator.
      • For a very large sample, like a population, subtracting 1 from a huge number will not make much of a significant correction. Hence, we may choose to ignore subtracting 1.
  • Standard Deviation (SD)
    • It is the square root of variance.
    • The standard deviation of a population is denoted by σ and the standard deviation of a sample is denoted by just s.
    • The formula for the standard deviation of a sample (usually <30):
    • For a population (large sample), the denominator would be replaced by just N.
    • It is particularly useful for normal distributions but can be used in skewed distributions
    • It is used to calculate the proportion of the population within the given SD
    • A low SD means that the data are close to the mean but a high SD would mean that the data are more spread out.
    • The empirical rule of a normal distribution states that:
      • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean.
      • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean.
      • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean.

questions.text: Identify the following test.
questions.solution:
The Patch test is shown in the image which is used to confirm the diagnosis of Allergic contact dermatitis.

The patch test is used to detect delayed (type IV) hypersensitivity to antigens that come in contact with the skin, by applying the suspected antigen under occlusive patches to the skin. Patches are removed after 48 hours (or sooner if there is itching and burning). The patch site is evaluated 1 hour after removal, on day 2 and on day 4 to detect delayed reactions.

Site - Usually the upper back, or lateral aspect of the arm.

Indications for patch testing:

  • Allergic contact dermatitis
  • Eczematous disorders where contact allergy is suspected
  • Eczematous disorders not responding to treatment
  • Chronic hand and foot eczema
  • Varicose eczema

Patch test should be delayed for 4 weeks after sunbathing, and the patches should not be exposed to the sun or any other UV light. Corticosteroids and other immunosuppressive drugs may falsely reduce positive test responses in sensitized patients. They should be stopped before the patch test, if feasible. However, at doses below 15 mg prednisolone, the response is not likely to be affected. 

The image below shows the patch test.

 

Option A: Skin prick test involves an intradermal puncture through a drop of allergen placed on the skin.

Positive reaction - an urticarial weal, which is apparent after 15 min - 45 min. 

Below image shows skin prick testing.

 

 

Option C: Casoni's test is an immediate Type I hypersensitivity reaction to hydatid fluid to diagnose Echinococcus granulosus infection.

The antigen extracted from the hydatid fluid is sterilised and injected intradermally in one arm. An equal amount of saline is injected in the other arm as control.

Positive reaction - a wheal of about 5cm with multiple pseudopodia-like projection appears within 30mins and disappears in an hour. A secondary reaction of edema and induration appears after 8 hours.

The image given below shows an intradermal injection as done in casoni's test.

 

Option D: Radioallergosorbent test (RAST) is a blood test used for estimation of specific IgE.

questions.text: You were asked to conduct an autopsy of a 32-year-old man who succumbed to death due to poisoning. His organs can be preserved in rectified spirit in poisoning due to any of the following agents except?
questions.solution:
The organs can be preserved in rectified spirit, except in cases of suspected poisoning by kerosene.

Rectified spirit can be used to preserve tissue and organs in most cases of suspected poisoning. In suspected poisoning with the following, preservation with rectified spirit should be avoided:

  • Alcohol
  • Kerosene
  • Chloroform, ether
  • Chloral hydrate
  • Formic acid, Formaldehyde
  • Acetic acid
  • Phenol
  • Phosphorus, and
  • Paraldehyde

Other preservatives used in toxicology postmortem include:

  • Saturated NaCl solution: Avoided in poisoning from corrosive acids, alkalis, corrosive sublimate, and aconite.
  • 10 mg/ml of sodium or potassium fluoride and potassium oxalate (anti-coagulant) to preserve blood.
  • Fluoride should be added to urine, CSF, and vitreous humor if alcohol estimation is required and if analysis for cocaine, cyanide, and CO is being done.

A preservative is not necessary if :

  • The viscera can be analyzed in 24 hours
  • If the sample can be stored in a refrigerator or icebox
  • Bone, hair, nails specimens
  • Lung for inhaled poisons

The viscera should not be preserved in formaldehyde because extraction of non-volatile poisons becomes difficult.

In cases of chronic poisoning with heavy metals such as lead, arsenic, mercury, antimony, copper, etc., the shaft of a long bone, strands of scalp hair, fingernails or toenails, and a wedge of the quadriceps muscle should also be taken for sampling.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old woman receiving treatment for infertility presented with abdominal pain and distension. On examination, her pulse was 130/min, blood pressure 130/80 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation was 97 %. Per abdominal examination revealed ascites, and no mass was palpable. Ultrasonography of the pelvis is shown below. Which of the following measures are ineffective in the prevention of this condition?

1. Withholding of FSH dose prior to hCG

2. Increasing the FSH dose

3. Substitution of FSH with hCG

4. Withholding the hCG trigger

5. Withholding pretreatment with combined oral contraceptives

FSH- Follicle-stimulating hormone, hCG-Human chorionic gonadotropin
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the USG findings are suggestive of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS). The given sonogram reveals enlarged ovaries with numerous follicular cysts. Increasing FSH dose and withholding pretreatment with combined oral contraceptives have no role in preventing OHSS.

Strategies to avoid OHSS induction include :

  • Decreasing follicular stimulation - Decreasing the FSH (Follicle-stimulating hormone) dose
  • Coasting- Withholding FSH administration for one or more days prior to the hCG (Human chorionic gonadotropin) trigger injection 
  • Prophylactic treatment with volume expanders during and after oocyte retrieval
  • Substitution of hCG for FSH during the final days of ovarian stimulation.
  • Low-dose hCG administration- this supports the maturation of larger ovarian follicles but causes atresia of small antral follicles, reducing the risk of OHSS.
  • Withholding the hCG trigger - results in cycle cancellation. IVF should then be considered in this case.
  • GnRH antagonist protocol: This would allow a single dose of GnRH agonist in place of hCG. The resulting endogenous LH surge then brings about the maturation of the follicle and oocyte
  • Pretreatment with combined oral contraceptives is done to prevent cyst formation, improve the chances of ovulation induction, and reduce hyperstimulation.

Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS) is characterized by mul­tiple ovarian follicular cysts accompanied by increased capillary permeability. It happens most often as a complication of ovulation­ induction therapy for infertility. It occurs due to the stimulation of vascular endo­thelial growth factor (VEGF) expression in granulosa-lutein cells by hCG.

They often present with shortness of breath, abdominal pain, and gastrointestinal disturbances like nausea, vomiting, and oliguria.

Abdominal pain occurs due to ovarian enlargement and accumulation of peritoneal fluid. Increased vascular permeability and loss of fluid, protein, and electrolytes into the peritoneal cavity cause ascites and result in hemoconcentration. Hemoconcentration causes hyperviscosity and leads to hypercoagulability.  

Hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, leukocytosis, pleural effusion, and pericardial effusion can be associated with OHSS. 

Some of the risk factors for OHSS:

  • Polycystic ovarian syndrome
  • Young age
  • High estradiol during ovulation induction
  • Pregnancy

OHSS is primarily managed with general supportive care. Paracentesis is performed to ameliorate abdominal discomfort and relieve respiratory discomfort.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman is practicing intermittent fasting in order to lose weight. She fasts every day for 13 hours. During this period of fasting, which of the following is least likely?
questions.solution:
In this woman, practicing intermittent fasting for 12 hours, significant ketogenesis is least likely. Significant amount of ketone body synthesis occurs during prolonged starvation(>3 days).

A decrease in insulin: glucagon ratio is seen in the fasting state, in which there is the activation of gluconeogenesis, increased glycogenolysis, thus leading to decreased glycogen storage and inhibition of glycolysis.

Metabolic process

Fasting state

Fed state

Insulin: Glucagon

Decreased

Increased

Gluconeogenesis

Increased

Decreased

Glycogenolysis

Increased

Decreased

Ketogenesis

Increased

Decreased

Glycogen storage

Decreased

Increased

The fasting state begins two to four hours after the absorptive/well-fed state. In early fasting i.e; 4-18 hours after the well-fed state, the blood glucose level is maintained by hepatic glycogenolysis. The glycogen stores are sufficient for around 18 hours after a meal, following which they start to deplete. So the source of blood glucose in a person fasting for 13 hours will be liver glycogenolysis. Gluconeogenesis begins 4–6 hours after the last meal but becomes fully active only after stores of liver glycogen are depleted (after 18 hours). They can serve as a source of glucose for up to 2 days.

In prolonged starvation (>3 days), acetyl CoA is converted to ketone bodies in the liver which will act as the main fuel source for skeletal and heart muscle and can meet up to 20% of the brain’s energy needs.

After several weeks of starvation, ketone body synthesis will not take place due to depleted triacylglycerol stores. Proteins remain the only source of fuel. Protein degradation increases, and death results from a loss of heart, liver, or kidney function.

questions.text: A patient was administered a Hib PRP (polyribosyl ribitol phosphate) vaccine. The production of which of the following immunoglobulins is not induced by this vaccine?
questions.solution:
The Hib polyribosyl ribitol phosphate (PRP) vaccine does not induce IgE. IgG, IgA, and IgM are induced by the capsular PRP antigen of Hib. Although the production of IgE immunoglobulins may be induced, they do not play a significant role in the immune response generated by the vaccine.

IgG, IgA, and IgM immunoglobulins are bactericidal, opsonic, and protective and hence, this antigen is employed for immunization.

This capsular antigen is unique as it helps in capsular typing. This is of medical importance as up to 95% of H. influenzae isolates from acute invasive infections such as meningitis belong to type b. 

H.influenza strains that lack a capsule are known as non-typeable strains. Non-typable H. influenza usually causes childhood otitis media, sinusitis, chronic bronchitis, puerperal sepsis, and exacerbations of COPD. Typeable H. influenza causes meningitis.

H. influenza is typed into 6 serotypes (a to f) based on the capsular polysaccharide. H. influenza b accounts for most of the invasive infections.

questions.text: 400 mg of a drug was administered to a patient, of which 40 mg is excreted in 60 minutes. Assuming the drug follows first-order kinetics, how much of the drug would remain after 2 hours?
questions.solution:
After 2 hours, 324mg of the drug will remain.

In first-order kinetics, a constant fraction of the drug is excreted in a given time. 

In the given question, 40 mg out of 400 mg is excreted in 60 minutes ---> 40/400 = 0.1 fraction is eliminated every 60 minutes.

After 60 minutes; 400 mg - 40 mg = 360 mg remains 

The next 60 minutes (after 2 hours) = 360 * 0.1 = 36 mg is eliminated and 360 - 36 = 324 mg remains.

Simpler way -

  • 1/10 fraction is excreted in 60 minutes → 9/10 remains after 60 minutes.
  • 2 hours (120 min) is 2 times of 60 minutes.
  • So 400 * (9/10)(9/10) = 324 mg remains after 120 minutes.

Related Pearl: Zero order vs First order kinetics of drugs

First order

Constant amount of drug is eliminated per unit time

 Constant fraction of drug is eliminated per unit time

Rate of elimination is independent of plasma concentration

 Rate of elimination is proportional to the plasma concentration
